Early Access Review

Honest review incoming if you want seriousness.

I really wanted to give it a thumbs up...

The game is enjoyable, not great... but enjoyable. Unfortunately, yes there a ton of issues which are making it feel hardly worth 20$ even. They give you a warning that says it's early access and to expect some issues, but there's more than some" if you will. I'll break down some basic pros and cons (I have not played RCT3

my last was RCT2 if that helps judge any of you guys looking to possibly jump back into this franchise.)

Pros:
- You still get to make a theme park and make rollercoasters.
- Menus seem pretty clean and pretty easily navigated.
- Some of the customizable options for paths and such are cool.
- Probably couldn't be stated enough

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most of the positive reviews of this game are getting down voted out of existence, so I am going to try and be as fair as possible.  Most of the negativity surrounding this game is based on how overwhelmingly buggy it is right now.  That is 100% true.  But it’s still an awesome game.

I can already feel all those negative fingers twitching over their keyboards waiting to drown me in hateful comments, but let me explain my reasoning first.  I agree: THE BUGS ARE EVERYWHERE.  Early access may even be a little misleading in this one.  When I hear early access, the first thing that comes to my mind is one of those new indie games that’s totally functional, but needs a lot more content.  This is not that.  This is early early access… This game is Super ****ing Mega early access.  We are basically alpha testing this bad boy.  If you are not willing to occasionally fight through bugs or lose a coaster once or twice, don’t buy this game.  The fact that they are still charging full price for something so incomplete is my biggest issue with the game right now.  Almost every aspect of this game has at least one significant issue that needs to be worked out.

However, I ended up giving this a thumbs up because all of the problems are seem to be superficial.  When they are fixed, I am 100% sure this game will be fantastic.  All the bugs, such as, the faulty AI, the wonky EID ratings (excitement/intensity/nausea), the path placing issues, etc. that everybody is complaining about are all very fixable.  I have played many games (early access or otherwise) that were just inherently bad.  Bad concept, bad controls,  un-navigateable menus, bad whatever…  But keep in mind, this game is Super ****ing Mega early access, and the core of the game, the most important part, is rock solid.

And what is the core?  To me, the most important part of any theme park simulator is the coaster editor itself.  I have seen many negative reviews claiming that this one is over complicated and hard to use.  I struggle to even wrap my head around these claims.  When I first started playing this, before reading a single review, my first thought was, “Man, this coaster editor is ****ing amazing! It’s so easy to use!”  I hate to step on people’s toes, so I’ll stomp them instead.  If you put any actual effort into figuring out how to use to use the editor instead of giving up after 5 minutes, anyone in their right mind would be forced to agree that this is by far the most elegant and free form coaster editor yet.  There are practically no limits to what you can do.  Besides, even if the node editor somehow isn’t for you, the prefab piece editor is still present and works just fine.  Although I encourage you to take all other complaints and reviews you read seriously, it is important to me that everyone laugh in the face of any person that says the coaster editor is hard to use ;).  Kidding…  By the way.  But, seriously the coaster editor is awesome.
Since the other reviewers have so completely covered the specifics of the many bugs, I don’t feel compelled to cover them in my review.  In any case, I am confident that given time, they will all be fixed.

CONCLUSION

This game is not even close to being done and full price is fairly unreasonable.  DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES BUY THIS GAME IF YOU WANT SOMETHING FULLY FUNCTIONAL.  Give it more time, it’ll get there.  But if you’re like me and you get a kick out of seeing a game in its early stages and watch it fill in, give it a go.  If you want to give a game a negative review because its buggy while in early access, maybe don’t buy early access games in the future…  You clearly don’t appreciate the development process.  (people complaining about the bugginess to price ratio excluded)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While Planet coaster is vastly superior in terms of graphics, object placement, freeform coaster building, ride and peep animations, terrain, bugs/crashes, and a charming atmosphere even at its alpha stage, we still have to wait until the end of the year for a game with any sense of challenge or park management.

In the meantime we have to hope that RCTW improves to satisfy our park management cravings while we wait.
These pros and cons are against other major FINISHED park management games like RCT 1, 2 and 3.

PROS (THINGS THAT ARE BETTER THAN THEY WERE 12 YEARS AGO):

-There are curved paths.
-You can build a truly freeform coaster if you have the patience of a saint.
-The water dynamics are so impressive that I assume that they were already part of the Unity Engine and not the RCTW developers.
-There is a car park at the entrance. I like this


CONS (THINGS THAT ARE WORSE THAN THEY WERE 12 YEARS AGO):

GRAPHICS AND UI
-If there were no curved paths in this game, it would almost be GRAPHICALLY IDENTICAL to RCT3 (2004!)
- I get memory leaks where the game eats up to 26GB of my RAM. I am guessing not all players have 32GB ram to deal with this issue!
-The interface looks VERY bland. I am not asking for candy crush but I’ve seen accounting software that looks more exciting than this.

PERFORMANCE ISSUES
-My FPS is actually fine for the first 1000 peeps on max graphics. As soon as I get over 1500 peeps (easily achievable with 2 of the 9 park tiles), my game becomes unusable. The game freezes for 5 seconds every 30 seconds, crashes around every 15 minutes, and takes over 2 minutes to save the game (no joke).
(I have i7 3930K, GTX 970, 32GB RAM, SSD)
-Once my park starts to be a decent size (3 tiles or 2000 peeps) the game can no longer save or open it without freezing.
-I have not heard anyone with over 2000 peeps in their park claim that it is running smoothly.

How can I be motivated to spend time building something that I can no longer use once it starts to get interesting?

PATHS
-Building paths can be a pain when connecting to other paths or building up or near hills.
-Changing the path material means destroying anything connected to those paths (LIKE SHOPS) as the game will not allow you to place the path directly next to them again.
To fix: Add a material paint brush tool in the path menu and avoid the issue altogether.
-The game is SO PICKY when it comes to snapping benches, bins and shops to paths. They won't snap to positions that look perfectly acceptable and by default they seem to want to snap off the path onto the grass.
To fix: Allow intersecting geometry and free placement of path scenery and allow shops to be freely placed much closer to the paths. Let your users judge what is intersecting and what looks good for them.

PEEPS & STAFF
-The peeps animations are very wooden and they don't walk as families or groups like they did 12 years ago.
-Peeps sometimes stop walking in queue lines and hold up the entire queue for a few minutes.
-From birds-eye level the peeps stutter around the park at 2fps
-Sometimes all the peeps in the park disappear all at once and gradually start spilling in through the entrance.
-Staff are often seen sliding around the park without moving their legs like ghosts.
-Staff are often seen walking adjacent to the paths, phasing through all the scenery like ghosts.
-Mechanics are often seen congregating at ride exits, phasing through each other like ghosts.
I am pretty sure the staff are ghosts.

RIDES
-THERE ARE NO LOG FLUMES
-THERE ARE NO TRANSPORT RIDES, how hard can it be?
-While you can build rollercoasters piece-by-piece like you could in RCT3, parts like helix sections, loops and barrel rolls are missing.
-Coasters built or edited with freeform tools lead to a very un-smooth ride when finished. Something as simple as a descending helix can be a nightmare to build smoothly.
-Adding a lift-chain is way harder than it needs to be.
-It is not yet possible to change the colours of shops and non-coaster rides.
-The pre-built coaster stations are much larger and more realistic than RCT3 but you cannot choose where to put the entrance and exits.
-Tweaking an existing coaster can be dangerous. Clicking on a section of track to make a banked curve sometimes causes the camera to move which causes that piece of track to move way out of place. You then have to spend ages putting it back into place to avoid an unwelcome s-bend in your coaster.
To fix: GIVE US AN UNDO OPTION! Alternatively, allow us to lock certain axis’ when needed.
-Deleting parts of a coaster can be very tiresome after it has been built.
-Building pre-built coasters from the menu is an absolute nightmare in any park that is not perfectly flat and barren.
To fix: Give us an option to snap lowest part to terrain height and automatically bulldoze any scenery that would get in the way. At the very least allow us to see the ride supports during placement so we can see how ridiculously high off the ground the base of the coaster is going to be.
-Pre-built coasters do not display any excitement/nausea stats.
-All my coasters have ridiculously high nausea ratings while I think it looks quite safe.
To fix: allow us to see that nausea heatmap on our ride while we are building it if we want. At the very least, give the guests time to visit a toilet at the ride exit before puking everywhere. There are never any staff nearby to mop it all up.

TERRAIN
-Adjusting terrain under rides or roller-coaster supports is totally forbidden
-There are very few terrain materials available. This is like an hour’s job for a texture artist.
-There are no waterfalls like there were 12 years ago
-You cannot build tunnels like you could 12 years ago

SCENERY
-No building blocks/wall sections like in RCT2&3. I don’t want to have to trust an amateur Maya modeller for well-optimised and decent looking models without ridiculous stats from the steam workshop every time I want to build architecture. I want to design things myself. Look at what planet coaster lets you do!
-Selecting scenery items freezes the game for up to 5 seconds each, and occasionally CRASHES THE GAME ENTIRELY
To fix: if you don’t have budget to optimise your game any further, at least allow autosave.

If you can bear these problems for a few hours, zoom out and look at your park from above with all of its curvy paths and freeform coasters it can actually look quite realistic.
The fully working park management aspect is a fun challenge and is just as addictive as the original games.
Since no other title can claim both of these points at the same time yet, yes I would recommend this game to keep you busy until Planet Coaster comes out at the end of the year, after which, you will probably never touch this game again.
However, as I am unable to open saved parks (loading screen crash)  and experience memory leaks after they start to get big I cannot yet recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Started with the open sandbox. Quite enjoyed it. There were a lot of bugs and glitches, but no dealbreakers as it's still early access.
But when I started a scenario and looked at the way those parks are built: horrible. Seriously, who builts a park like that?!

The coaster builder really needs some work. When I build a coaster over water, it crashes. When I try to make a coaster as realistic as possible, it crashes for unknown (probably ridiculous) reasons. The prebuilt coasters are built really bad and therefore should definitely crash, but they don't... They really look like a 2 year old designed them.

Other problems I encountered:
- Peeps couldn't enter a coaster, the entrance was properly built but it seemed like there was an invisable barrier.
- You can only adjust the direction by 5 degrees when building a coaster. Normally this wouldn't be a problem for me, but sometimes it gets stuck at (for example) 42 degrees when you need 40 degrees, so you get ugly wobbles in your coaster.
- Coasterphysics when it comes to speed: it just keeps going... really could use some more loss of speed over the course
- The breaks on the coaster builder don't make sense: you can't fine tune them at all, and are almost impossible to use midcourse
- Result of the break issue: running more than 2 trains is almost impossible
- The image rocks a lot sideways when riding a coaster
-  Paths are difficult to build: when you want to connect two paths, it restricts you in only a few possibilities.
- The game randomly crashes: so be sure to save your progress often!
- Peeps keep walking around hungry, even though I placed an abundant amount of foodstalls/restaurants

This list could go on a while.
For now, I wouldn't recommend this game, as it's not worth the price.
I really hope these problems are gonne be resolved. I know it's still early access, but there are so many problems which make me question if it will be fixable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Time for an honest review.

Normally I would not have recommended this game when it first released, but over the past 2 weeks the game has been updated with bug fixes and optimization that has steadily improved the experience. The fact is that this game has a solid base to build off of, and that is what people need to take away from it. I own both Planet Coaster and RCTW, both are hardly finished and both, in my opinion, have a positive future ahead of them. Also, Hats off to Nvizzio for keeping in touch with the community and rolling out updates as quickly as they can. With all of that said, I'll list my pro and cons.

Pros
-Coaster editor/maker in this game is EXCELLENT, Sure its a bit finnicky sometimes, but it's damn good and can only get better, I prefer it to the piece by piece editor in PC, it's one thing I hated about RCT3.
-Decent variety of scenery to start and I'm sure this will be expanded upon
-Solid amount of flat ride content with a new one coming every 2 weeks in Major patches (Yes, I believe them, they have stuck to that schedule so far)
-I'll probably be crucified for this, but after the latest update..graphics have improved markedly, and I'd expect that to continue
-The Management aspect is there, could be better but it's decent for EA.
-Terrain tools are easy to use and effective, need an option for underground building though.
-There is more but I'll leave it at that for now, new update is scheduled to be rolled out Tuesday or Wednesday next week so I'll edit this review at that time

Cons
-Peeps need work (Animations/texture/etc)
-Optimization at this point is a bit shaky, people across a wide array of system are getting mixed results, once the park gets large it really starts to slow down, apparently this is getting addressed in next patch, I'll update if that is the case
-Pathing is shoddy at the moment.
-AI behavior is pretty poor in the current build, mechanics don't always fix rides, janitors are slow, etc.
-Water quality sucks. lol.
-Can't change ingame graphics while in your park. (Seriously guys?)
-Can't place scenery on elevated paths (Again, really guys?)
-Coaster ratings need work, every coaster I make is a vomit comet
-General bugs and such

-Overall, I'd recommend this based on the rate it is improving and the committment Nvizzio has shown to the franchise. I'd expect good things as time goes on.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs a fan of the Rollercoaster Tycoon series after 11 years since the last installment this was absoluetly heartbreaking. The peeps don't look as what would be expected, the realistic coaster supports are just never there with any of the games in the series unless modded in. The limitations in the options menu is saddening. Seeing the difference between Planet Coaster and RCTW; RCTW isn't the same and its missing quite a lot for what this game use to be. As a fan i'm heartbroken to even suggest to anyone who could be a fan as well. I'm giving it a chance and hopefully the developers will listen to its fans who have patiently been waiting for years for the next installment and make this series worth playing again. Its gameplay has some good ideas within the game, but it greatly needs improvement. I'm giving this game a 6/10 in my opinion. It has a long way to go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I tried to give this game a legitamte go. Go in with an unbias take on the game.
Yes, this is Early Access, but nothing in this game feels like it will be special when it's done. It's essentially a worse version of RCT3 without a grid system. It's also much more awkward to work with than RCT3.
Planet Coaster is the way to go with this generation of theme park games, it doesn't have everything yet, much like this game, but what it does have is stunning. It looks beautiful, it runs beautifully and it has a clear vision.
Please avoid this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll make this quick.  Here's a list of Pro's and Con's:

Cons:

No walls to build structures with.
Poor range of textures to paint the terrain with.
Cannot create tunnels for rides, paths and queues
Can't change the look of the stations
Can't change the look of the park gates
Decor offering only consists of 1 lamp post and 5 candy canes!
Only 5 Facades!
No smaller parts to create our own centre pieces with (ie. a large rock skull). Instead there are just large pre-made centre pieces to use.
Again, no smaller parts to create our own specialty pieces. Just pre-made ones to use.
Coasters cam is not smooth and feels jerky around corners. (no I don't mean frame rate)
Coaster building can be irritatingly fiddly at times.
The delete tool is terrible, you can only delete one item at a time.
Removing small bushes is really difficult.
Small choice of coasters.
Not a massive graphical leap forward since RCT3.
Some texures look shocking close up
Crashed a few times when placing paths (but this is an early access game).
Other than the coaster builder (spline) there are no improvements over the RCT3.

Pro's

Coaster builder (spline based) could be great if the mechanics are ironed out.
Looks visually better than the video that was released a year or so ago.
Shops are okay.


Summary.

Don't waste your money on this just yet, hold off for 6 months in the hope they add loads more items to play with. It's a very steep price to pay for a game that feels like it's still in alpha. It's not a complete broken mess as some other reviews suggest, it's just got very little content to keep you interested for more than 4-5 hours. My general feeling is that the developers are completely missing the point of what people want out of a theme park simulator - it's like they've sucked all the fun out of the game by taking away the creative freedom of themeing a park. By themeing I mean creating something from scratch, not simply placing two pre-made centre pieces side by side! My main gripe with it is that it's doing anything to build on RCT3 - even if they add lots more content, it will only be on par with the previous game in the series.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before reading this be aware that i also own the alpha of Planet coasters but gave both games a very fair chance.

I purchased RCTW because it was due to release last december well before planet coaster release date.
The beta came out and well i thought it wasnt bad, and that they were just hiding the features from us to keep as a suprise, turns out its cause they didnt actually have anything.

In its current state this game is completely unplayable. I have an absolut beast pc but the game lags so hard all the time even with an empty park that i cant play for more then 10 mins.
Path making is the worst iv ever seen in any game PERIOD, is the snap function some sort of inside joke? because its ALWAYS ON. paths do as they want and there is no room for people to get creative as there is no clipping allowed, the grid system is just some sort of crule prank and the peeps animations are reminisant of early gameboy graphics.
Don't get me started on placing buildings, just.. just dont. it's not even worth explaining how frustraing and down right crap it is.

One pro i will give this game is that the way you build coasters is really really fantastic, its so simple and feels so natural to me. Shame the game can only achive 2 fps on a 980ti and i7 so you cant enjoy that either. It honestly has gone backwards from the beta weekend. Please Atari get a new developer on this ASAP as Nvissio seem to be the most budget and clueless group to ever make a game.

Playing the alpha of Planet coaster, well it already has a ton more content, far better graphics and runs like a dream. It leaves you to create anything you can possibly imagine. trust me when i say you should pick it up its just the game we always dreamed of, made by the original devs of RCT3 and their passion /  love and attention clearly shines through on planet coaster.

EDIT: alot of people say that the 2 are totally different games, but that isnt the case at all, obviously they have differences but they are the same. its crazy not to think that. My biggest beef is that this game had a release date last year! and what they have now is easily 1 or 2 years away from release. As well as cheating all the november beta testers who i bet are all the ones leaving the negative reviews as i am.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's a good and a bad thing about this game..


Bad: It exists.


Good: So does Planet Coaster.



If you are looking for an actually good successor to the earlier RCT games, you should have a look at one or both of these two games:

- Parkitect, if you prefer the isometric view and style of the classic RCT and RCT 2.
- Planet Coaster, if you liked RCT 3, or you simply want a flat out great 3D theme park building game.

Stay away from RCTW, as I don't think this game will get any better in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

We're sad that we have to give this a thumbs down. My husband & I have been Atari fans since we got our first Atari Game System back in like 1981. Anybody remember Pong? Yeah...we're old...
We bought the Deluxe version of this back in Nov thinking the release date would be Dec 10th.  We aren't upset about spending that money, however, we're shocked at what this has turned out to be so far.

The Pro's
1.) Early Access- good on Atari to recognize that they needed to put something out there.
2.) Performance- we have a great computer that my husband built, so no performance issues like others have had.   Occasional choppiness, but hey, it's a computer game.
3.) Graphics-the parks actually look really pretty.
4.) Coaster builder- far from perfect, but we actually made several cool coasters & each one took less & less time. The problem is that both the coasters & the pieces to build with are disproportionately large & the test stats are way off. (What exactly is the safety rating about, does anyone know?) I hope some of this is fixable & being worked on.

The Con's
1.) Navigation- we shouldn't have to use the keyboard to scroll around the park. It's not 1989. And can I please have an Undo button? I make a lot of mistakes!
2.) Music- I know Matt said they're working on the custom music, but can we please put a rush on that before my head explodes? The music from RCT3 was so superb, I'd love to be able to import that into this game. Does anyone know if that's possible?
3.) The Vomit- really? Every peep pukes coming off every ride? And now they pee on the path if they can't make it to the rest room? Sorry, but it's disgusting & childish.
4.) Paths- we don't even know what to make of this. Very cumbersome. And we can't place buildings right on the main path. Not liking that at all.
5.) The Peeps- it's like Night of the Living Dead went to a porn flick. What's with the weird moaning? And can someone please make the kid stop crying? I think my ears are bleeding. The peeps have no personality at all. They don't appear to be happy, sad or anything in between.
6.) Rides- again, many seem disproportionately large. It just seems as if things aren't properly scaled. The fact that we can't move the entrances & exits is very odd. Why not? Also, the rides seem pricey, so why do we have to purchase the sign going over the ride?
7.) Complaining- there's too much of it. It appears as if you all have taken a page from the first Zoo Tycoon, & not a good page. The animals were great in that game, but the peeps made me stop playing because of the constant complaining about things you couldn't even fix. Please don't make that same mistake with this game.
8.) Buildings- way too many restaurants & the builings are huge. Seriously, who goes to an amusement park thinking, Gee
date: I hope I can get a great Moo Goo Gai Pan while I'm here!" And if you eat sushi

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't buy this.

Yes, I know it's early access. But it feels like an Alpha.

I'm running on a GTX 970 and i7 3770k and the game is horribly optimised, the highest graphics settings look only a small upgrade from RCT3, the coaster builder is overly complicated and it's almost impossible to get a smooth track flow, not to mention that inversions are near impossible to do well, the game crashed when I tried to delete half of a coaster. I'd wait to see what future updates bring before even thinking about buying.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDo not, I repeat do not waste your money on this game.  First time I've ever written a review on here but that's how disappointed I am by this game.  It has some many glitches in it, graphics are terrible (possibly worse than Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 which came out years ago) and for a game is just not enjoyable.  Feel so conned by this, though have now learned my lesson as the game is just not ready, I guess, hence Early Access, which from a major developer is pretty shameless to still charge full price.  This game will take months and months to fix, do not spend your money on it, I made that mistake and am now regretting not getting a lovely bottle of Malbec which would have been so much more enjoyable.  By the time they get this fixed, Planet Coaster will be out and that already looks 1000x better.  Please save your money, don't even think, ah I'm sure he's wrong, I'll give it a go, I repeat, SAVE YOUR MONEY!!! ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dear developer,

thank you. I mean, I really want to thank you. I bought this game in November, at this time, you told us it would be released on the 10th of decembre. It wasn't. Okey, I thougt, no problem, they need time and I wanted to give you more time. I thougt, when the game finaly will be released, it will a be a FINISHED game. BECAUSE I PAYED FOR A FINISHED GAME! 45€!!! Yeah I know Early Acces CAN be great, BUT NOT FOR A FULL-PRIZED GAME, WHICH WAS SUPPOSED TO BE FINISHED!!! So okey nevermind. I know Early Acces games, which are very good indeed, they are nealry completed, just with a little performance problemes and allready with a lot of content. Fortunately your game does not have this! Haha! So until now I just threw meaningless phrases around me, like the frame rate in this game is throwing up (pun hahah) all the time, so I will just tell you, what I don't like. But one more thing, ALL these things are in case tiny little things, RCT3 does not have this problemes, so why do you start including them now?! Why can't I build entirely straight ways, after I build an attraction? Why is everything so freaking big, it looks ridiculous. Why is everything so big, but the park space so small, I can't even build one big rollercoaster. Why there is so little content? Why is the performance just so bad, even on the lowest settings? Why can't I build a rollercoaster through a rock and in the ground? Why is so much missing? And so much more!

So the biggest question, why can't you just wait until you finished the game?! I would have wait, even a long time, but nooooooooo, you just gave me a half-ready game, which doesn't perform well for, wait for it, wait for it, the legendary full-prize of 45€. Nice, well done. FORTUNATELY I did not bought the game on steam so I can't even give it back. So yeah basiacilly I will just wait now until the game will work better and if you can't fix it, planet coaster will come and hopefully they will make it better. BUT you can still fix this all, work on the performance, just reboot RCT3 and make the a few well needed changes and PLEASE keep the things that worked. Man I am just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ becaused you ♥♥♥♥ed up so hard, I am not even regretting that I bought the game, I am just sad and disappointed. So fix this and I will come back later and maybe and HOPEFULLY I can delete this review.

Sincerly

A sad fan

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please save your money and buy RCT3, a much better game that has a lot better camera motions. While riding the sorry excuse for a coastercam, the camera jolts forward all of the sudden. The coasters themselves make no sense because when it says intensity Im not sure we have the same understanding for that. The amount of detail is amazing, infact you can zoom right in and see lots of little details about the peeps but thats the only good thing about the peeps. The peeps complain about EVERYTHING, I had ~50 peeps in my park with all wide paths and they complained it was crowded.

Please keep in mind that this game is in fact /EARLY ACCESS/ but it's no good right now. I played about an hour and have now requested a refund because it's, in my opinion, not very good.

If you are going against the 1,066 negative reveiws (as of April 4th 2016 at 8:25PM).. Make sure you have a VERY beefy computer. I'm above the minimal requirements at got ~20-15 FPS

Please developers work really hard, because what scared me was this game was almost the full release 5 months ago.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here’s the thing. I paid full game money and got a pre-Alpha build. I expect more from Atari. This is why you see everyone everywhere saying not to pre-order games. Reminds me of when the new Sim City launched, now Maxis is dead. I get that we’re on the 3rd dev now but this is insane.

Don’t buy this game. It is not worth $50.

First off the graphics are sub-par, at best, and even on low settings the frame rate is awful. There are terrible issues with building scale, little food stands being as big as full rides for starters. There is barely enough content to make a themed section of a park.

I basically used up all the rides in 2 zones. You get 9 zones. WTF am I supposed to do with the rest of the zones? Make my own coaster with 20 FPS and a terrible coaster builder? The coaster builder sucks. It is not intuitive. It doesn’t let you add special tracks easily; you can’t make the kind of coasters you want. I was trying to make a simple Six Flags Superman style ride. Can’t do it. RCT3 could do it. How does a full version of the game not have at the very bare minimum what the last version had? RCT3 came out in ’04 and you want me to believe you can’t have all that stuff added into a new game in ’16?!?! If they had just taken RCT3 and put it into a new engine so it looked better and ran smoother, I’d be more happy than I am with wasting the money I did on this garbage.

Pathing is awful. There is a lot of really weird snapping and even using the grid it’s hard to make straight lines. Curved paths almost seem easier which doesn’t make sense.

The delete tool is garbage, and… oh what’s that you want to play one of the scenarios? Cool. Have fun trying to place rides anywhere. If there are trees or tiny little bushes you can’t plop stuff down, you first have to use the god-awful delete or move tools to get rid of the plants. One by freaking one. You would think you could just right click and the game would know you want to delete that stupid bush but apparently that’s too much to ask for.

The list goes on and on. You can’t get your staff to do what you’re paying them to do. There is literally no guidance for how to please people or how to keep them from puking after every damn ride. Even the giant slide. The economy is dumb.

Don’t buy this game. Odds are Atari is going to pull the plug on it rather than give it dev time it needs. You would literally be better off taking $50 and and burning it for the few moments of heat it provided you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state RCTW is a complete flop - there I've said it. I am keeping in mind that this is an alpha, however; it is stil just as dissapointing to me. When you look at Roller Coaster Tycoon you recognize a franchise that is well known for being composed of quality games. Well I'm sad to say that after RCT4 - Mobile and the Alpha of RCTW that this may now be a false statement. As a lifelong fan of this game (I've been playing it since the original and since I was old enough to understand how to play video games) I am remaining cautiously optimistic about the future of this game, I see its potential and the ability of the community to greatly improve each other's experiences through the vast network of custom scenery objects now available on the Steam Workshop.

In its current state I'd rate the game no higher than a 5/10 and here's why:

- The coaster builder is VERY clunky, occasionally it becomes impossible to continue building as you need to use the presets to place a piece before you can freeform it. This causes issues when your piece wants to dive underground, yet you wish to freeform it and keep it above ground.

- Staff buildings, now some will say this really isn't an issue (and I agree to an extent) however, by making staff members simply components of the building we place we lose our abilities to both customize them and set specific routes for them, two things that were nice about RCTW's predecessors. I do like the idea of the staff buildings and it adds a little more realism, however; for it to work for me the same level of customizability present in its predecessors must also be available.

- FPS drops, now I have a top of the line computer (one capable of running Fallout 4 on near maximum graphics settings) so running RCTW shouldn't be a problem for my computer AT ALL. Unfortunately the reality is that I'm plagued by random FPS drops and input lag" at least 70% of the time I spend on this game. The worst part is that it happens in almost entirely empty parks - Atari you really need to work on this.

- Lack of flat rides
date: I understand that this is an Early Release (alpha if you will) however it would be nice to have some more generic flat rides that aren't soo heavily themed. Perhaps an option to toggle what the ride's theme is? I'm not sure if anything will be done about this but if you're going for one specific theme your options are quite limited.\n\n- Scenery placement
recommended: all of the previous games had this issue as well. Planet Coaster is the only one I've seen that has done this right soo far. I'd love to see scenery that we can place anywhere so that we can properly theme rides/areas. What is the point of having a giant tree with a hole that looks as though you could run something through it if you can't put anything through it?\n\n- Lastly I'd like to say that I feel this game should be MUCH farther along than it currently is. No I do not know anything about video game developement and yes I know there were three developers working on this game. Nvizzio
hoursPlayed: if you're reading this please take what I've said and will continue to say as constructive criticism. I love the RCT series and I want to see this become a AAA title

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As so many of my fellow millenials, I grew up with RCT in the late 90's and early 2000's. It is a great franchise and still loads of fun. All of you may know that the fourth installation in the series was avidly awaited by many a fan. After a troublesome development history, yesterday the game came out in early access. It is facing stiff competition from Planet Coaster and Parkitecht, so comparisons between the two are inevitable. Nevertheless, in the promo-video's, dev-diaries, etc, the devs vowed to come with something worthwhile.

So what came of it? To put it bluntly: An unfinished, unpolished alpha-build that is rife with bugs. The potential is there, especially in the coaster builder, but the detail, the path-tool, the management-aspect, the graphics  and the camera-handling are far below par. It is essential that this is going to be adressed in the near future. The communication by the devs towards the coaster-community is in this regard not very encouraging. I think it is only fair that the devs have to come with an open and honest statement about the development stage and a feasible time schedule which lays out at what times what issues will be fixed and what kind of content will be added.

RCT world has potential. If they get the coaster tool working in a proper way, it even has the potential to outshine Planet coaster in at least one regard. But so far, this product is not ready for sale and an embarrasment for the franchise. Let's hope that the devs will quickly do what needs to be done. Come clean to the fanbase and coaster community. Only then can they regain some credibility....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before you spend your money because you just could not wait anymore for the next great RollerCoaster Tycoon, just know this is not a Chris Sawyer RCT (He is working on another RC game). This means there is very little familar aspects from the other RCT games.

As this beta game (really alpha), there are many things that you can not do - you can not customize stalls - you can not customize Roller Coasters enter buildings - they are pre-made. There are very VERY little props to build things to customize your park. No control over staff, no control whats being sold in vendors, strange placements of path items, (lights, beenches - etc). Many bugs - the biggest is the park paths are almost impossable to make 90 degree anges nor snap evenly to other paths. Its very annouying. I could go on and on

All this being said - if you want to help the devs make this into a nice game and willing to get fustrated a lot - try it out if you can afford the high price for a very unfinished early bata game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, the game feels incomplete. You can sense the power of the spline coaster-building system, but there are PLENTY of fixes that need done before this can be recommended.

PEEP AI is horrible, as is their animation. They all seem like zombies. No animation. No character.
PEEP thoughts does not seem to work.
Should be able to hover over attraction and get information (i.e. number on ride; number in queue; wait time.)
Should be able to right-click to remove an object when in build mode.
Janitors and Mechanics seem brain dead. They walk past trash; they don't fix rides. Perhaps patrolling zones needs to return.

All-in-all, having fun playing game with my 6-year-old son, but I think the game is far from complete. He thinks it's great and I guess that's all that counts.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had high hopes for this game and waited a very long time to experience another rollercoaster tycoon game due to me being a big fan of the origional 3. Once beta of this game came out and all the negative publicity started, I thought for sure the developer would truly start caring about how to fix it and make it all that it could possibly be, especially with fierce competition from planet coaster (which I bought beta access for at the same time as buying RCT world). After playing both I was truly amazed at the level of complexity planet coaster gave it's peeps and the level of detail involved in the game even at such an early stage of developement. I unfortunately was not impressed with RCT world, I wanted to like it soo bad, I wanted to ignore the negative publicity it was getting and keep an open mind and stay positive about how this game could one day be truly amazing, but after the negative beta release which I figured would tighten up their boot straps, The game just doesn't deliver, especially at the cost their asking. I found pathways to be incredibly difficult to place, especially at the entrance of the park where nothing seems to connect, or connect straight for that matter. Also peeps look very bland, If you compare it to PC, its a no brainer, there was no time or thought put into peep movement, intelligence, or even just simple gestures. I found rollercoaster building to be fun and intuitive but when you finally finish the coaster and ride it, it studders and shakes on the track which gets annoying, which was also mentioned in a recent review video. The graphics seem so outdated and bland and when you zoom out the peeps skip frames as they walk and it looks terrible, BTW the graphics were cranked to max and i run dual R9 390x video cards in crossfire. The game may one day be extemely fun to play and easy to use, which i truly hope it is because I will definitely buy it again (I refunded it), but at this stage it is not worth the price tag and it seems the developer has not improved much since beta, so it's difficult to see this game improving from it's early access state, i truly hope I am wrong though. I would not recommend this game at this stage especially with planet coaster right around the corner and looking very promising, so far iv had nothing but fun with that game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a hardcore themepark enthusiast, and Roller Coaster Tycoon fan, I have to be honest about this game.
It's not good... in fact, it's very bad.

I really want to like this game as I loved every game in the RCT franchise, except for the spin offs. (Mobile and 3DS)
But this game is barely playable, even on a high end pc.
The FPS drops are huge in this game, even when your park is extremely small.
And I am noting this as I can play most of the newest game on the highest settings with a solid 60 fps.
But, back to the point. This game... I don't know how to describe it other then it just being... terrible.
Trying to build paths (Yes paths...) drops my fps to about 1 frame every few seconds. I literally can't place the paths.
Then there is the shops wich are impossible to connect to paths.
Same for benches and what not, almost impossible to place how you want them to be.
The AI isn't only bad, they also look horrible... the quality of the peeps is just... terrifying.
RCT3 had better looking peeps then this game.
The coaster builder, well... It's ok. It's not good at all, it's extremely buggy.
You can't make a nice looking coaster if you don't place all the nodes by hand.
The flatrides look ok atleast, if that is any good if the whole game is bad.
There are many good ideas in this game, don't get me wrong! But this game is not worth €45,99.
This game feels more like it's worth 5 to 10 bucks. ( If it is even worth money at all )
And now imagine this... This game is in Beta. This game plays like it is pre-alpha. But it is in Beta...
Planet Coaster, is in pre-alpha. That game feels more like it is in Beta. And most of the features in that game are missing!
I hope this game can become somewhat good. But right now, I have a feeling it won't.
The only way to really fix this game would probably be to start over most of the features that are already in the game.
Everything needs fixing... that's all I can say about this game. I honestly think it would be best to try and start over the development.
Because most features in this game don't work as they should.
I'd rather be restricted to building paths on 90 to 45 degree angles then to have to deal with all these bugs and lag.
I'd rather have the grid back again, then have the problem of nothing placing properly.
Honestly, I would be happy if they literally made it like the previous game with better graphics and what not.
But I think this game is just a lost cause. I tried to give it a change. But it's just, really bad.
And this is not the developers fault, they had to work on a game that was broken to begin with.
So yeah, just don't buy this game, save yourself some money. Don't buy it because of the title saying RCT.
It's nothing like the old games, and not nearly as good. If the game does get better, I will update my review.
But until then, please don't buy this game.

Edit: I have a feeling this review is getting downvoted by people that didn't actually play the game.
If you want to try it, go right ahead, I just don't recommend you waste your money if there is cheaper/better alternatives.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of people have issues with details such as park management, mediocre graphics, horrible staff and peep AI, etc.

I fully agree with these, but was able to look past this. For me, making free-form coasters was the absolute dream. I'm a bit of a coaster freak, and I finally had a chance to rebuild my favorite coasters around he world in my parks. I could not have been more hopeful, and after hours and hours of figuring out the finicky coaster building tool, I finally created an exact replica of El Toro at Six Flags. So when it had an intensity rating of 21.7, ultra-extreme, and no peeps would ride it, I was understandably disappointed. My next few attempts produced similar results, though they were all exact replicas or closely based off of many of the prominent coasters in the world today. To put hours into this difficult process only to have the majority of my peeps not ride it and a massive pile of vomit in my exits is, well, not good.

Fine, gameplay mechanics be damned, I would do what I could do build an aethetically pleasing park incorporating realistic roller coasters. I put even more hours and hours into this process, only to have both the parks I built crash the game before being able to load. All of my time lost.

Update after update promising updated coaster mechanics and improved realism and all we get is this bull. I wish I hadn't played this so much already so I could get my money back. A decade-long disappointment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I must admit that, in general, I am disappointed with the game so far. I understand it is still in Early Access and I'll still give it a chance to fix its problems until the full release, but it is definitely not what I was expecting given that I've been playing Roller Coaster Tycoon games ever since the original in the 1990s. Still, I'll try to list my impressions about the game as unbiasedly as humanly possible.

I really like the interface. It's simple, it's clean, it's modern and it's elegant. It's refreshing to see a modern take on an interface when, even today, most games still go with tacky and bulky interface designs.
Pathing needs a lot of work and I'm finding it really hard to get my paths to be how they I want them to be. It's pretty hard to get nice, snaking queues, for instance.
The graphics are okay. Not great, but not horrible. But then again, I think graphics are the least important thing in a game. While in some cases quirky graphics may contribute to ambiance, in most games graphics just don't matter and RCT games are games where it doesn't matter, imo.
I actually really like the coaster editor. It's a pretty powerful tool once you get used to it.
Staff control is very basic at this point and could use improvement.
I'm not the best guy to really assess performance as my computer is already somewhat outdated at this point in time, but I feel it could be better. Considering I can play XCOM 2 with acceptable framerates in a medium graphics setting, I was expecting to run RCTW more smoothly than I do. In particular, loading times seem to be particularly slow on my machine and I've had a few crashes when loading Scenarios.
To sum it up, in its current state, RCTW still has a lot of issues. It has good points and bad points and, while I am willing to wait and see if the issues will be fixed in future versions of the game, I can't really recommend it in its current state.

reviewText:

Well they pushed the release date back about 4 times before we got the general Q1 2016 release date, which i thought for sure was them trying to hide that they had killed the game in production. I played the game during the first Beta weekend and it looks like they just added in the peep textures, a couple flat rides, and just released it again.

There is a metric ton of stuff missing, and menus and buttons are still in weird places, And seeing as this was going to originally release in December 2015 this is unexceptionable. I mean fence builder was the biggest complaint from the First public beta and guess what...There is still no sign of it in the game other then on a to-do list on their website somewhere.

This is still a beta build, but for how long they have pushed this game back you think there would be more than 10 coaster types or even building for that matter.

I think they tried to get the jump on the market by trying to release the game a year early. Even if you ignore how ridiculously bugging it is then its still missing content. Stock RCT3 Had more content at launch then this game does 4 months after it original launch date and multiple betas.

Most of these complaints are about the studio behind this game and how poor their development cycle is if this is all they have to show for multiple missed release dates and multiple open closed betas.

Never will i buy a game from Atari anymore. This is bull****!! People please read...

The frames drop even harder than a bowling bawl tossed out of a window!! Not even a steady 30FPS on medium graphics. And that with a i7-3770K 16GB Memmory, 256GB SSD and a AMD Radeon R9 290X graphics card.

Then they tried to make the visitors smarter by making their own choices and going directly to the thing they need. So if they are hungry, they would go to a stand for food. If they needed to go to the toilet, they would go to the toilet.

Well i think that the one who wrote this system for RCT World was a very very drunk man. The system fails in every way. Even the waiting lines are bugged. People tend to stay halfway the waiting line and dont walk on.

Then the coaster building... Luckily they kept some off the old handelings because building with the mouse is not done! And here is the way you build a couster who is actually fun to ride:

And then, omg are the rides made of plastic? Every ride i build got broken within a few minutes real time. I allmost got up to 30 mechanics for 20 rides and still they got broken and could not be fixxed fast.

This is my first time writing a review. Most of the time i think the people will get it if a game is bad or even worse. But such a big name as RCT... What a fail... reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has been some time since the release of RCTW Early Access and I feel the game has reached a level where a review is warranted. There have been many negative reviews, and I can see the frustrations that led many to leave such, but a lot of those seem to have dismissed the game after a few moments of play. Not giving the game a chance to show off its potential.

And in Early Access, potential is what we want to consider, The foundation that RCTW has laid is such that it may very well grow into that potentail we can glimpse. Should UGC become full, and each day we see more pieces added, should Piece by Piece building with the UGC be solved, and each update we see that happening. Then the foundation could lead to overwhelming success.

At present, for those who are creative, the park builders, I would say the game has enough that you can find many hours of contentment playing it. For those who are problem solvers and want to play scenarios, we are not quite there yet with needing AI to balance better, with the scenarios to be tweaked better.

But for the $50 price, it is closer each to day to be the successor to RCT3. At present the trajectory that it is on, may never get us to being equal or better than RCT3. But perhaps one rung below it. Though should more coaster types, more rides, more more more be released, then it might even surpass RCT3 for at present the graphics are better. Should the gameplay expand, UGC be optimized and the others items that we can see the potential to better happen, then yes, we shall have a GAME!

Early Access Review

I cannot recommend this game in its current state, it's an enjoyable game while it works despite the issues some people have raised about not being able to place paths squarely on the grid etc. As well as bad graphics and some of the more humorous visual bugs I have encountered like one of my park visitors getting stuck underground after riding the slide - I can look past these things.

Some of the issues I have encountered however are just completely game breaking, for example; After building my first coaster and testing it, I opened it up for the peeps, they began to queue but nobody was getting on the ride, I tried closing it down and opening it again to see if that helped and while at first it seemed to, once the first load of peeps had finished riding it, they refused to get off. I then tried to edit the coaster to see if i could spot any obvious issues that might be causing this which turned out to be a bad idea because after doing so EVERYBODY in my park started glitching out on the spot and couldn't move.

I appreciate that it is an early access game and I will look into posting the bugs I have encountered but really for £29.99 the game should at least be in a playable state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a die hard fan of the RollerCoaster Tycoon series I was extremely excited to try out the latest installment in the series. I avoided the reviews and Lets Plays on youtube purposely so that I could judge the game by its merits alone.

That being said, there is unfortunately a lot wrong with the game.

The path system is a disaster and half the time it refuses to let me place paths in places that are unobstructed.

The peeps are completely lifeless while they are on rides and you can watch them cycle through various terrifying facial expressions while remaining dead silent the entire time. (Its honestly only a bad soundtrack away from being a horror movie.)

Perhaps this is just a glitch on my end, but half the time buildings and rides don't actually show you whether or not they are closed which led me to accidentally forget to open half the stuff in my park. (Oops!)

I also noticed that the days seemed... Shorter? Like, almost ridiculously short. I feel like they could be slightly longer. In order to see my park at night I have to lock the time set to night time or else you'd miss it if you looked away for two seconds.

There are so many little things that could be fine tuned, that would make this such a great game. I want to like this game so bad because a huge chunk of my childhood was spent playing both RCT2 and RCT3. RCTW is just not holding up compared to even RCT3.

I'm hoping the developers really are serious about improving the game because it has so much potential. Until then, I cannot recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To begin with, I didn't read the reviews first so my point of view wasn't tainted right off the bat. Honestly though this game doesn't live up to the franchise. The graphics are better than RTC3, but not 8 years better. The motion of the rides and peeps is not smooth. The graphics appear more cartoonish, less realistic. The game frequently hangs up or freezes and it loads very slow. Not nearly as many options as previous versions (ie no transit rides). The curved pathways are neat, but nothing lines up properly when using those tools (hedges and fences don't follow curves). Hedge and fence pieces are all one length, which leaves gaps. Limited tree options and no bushes. Peep movements are not natural, nor is their vomiting habits and urinating on the pathways (seriously?) I could go on and on.

I want to like it, because I loved RTC 2 and 3, but it just is not there. I realize this is early access and I think the devs can fix many of the problems, but I don't see them going back and redesigning all of the graphics to the level you might expect them to be for a game created in 2015-2016. They really have a lot of work to do, and as loyal as I am to the franchise I don't see them pulling it off properly. I hope I'm wrong because I messed with it for an hour longer than the refund policy allows...
voteText: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is far from finished. It's so far from finished that I can't believe they're saying it's full featured enough and they're just releasing the base game so they can add more features later on. No, the serious problem here is that the base features that are available right now just plainly don't work, and even some simple things just don't exist (you have zero control over staff, for example). I can see the potential here, but so much stuff is just so broken. The real redeeming quality of this game is the coaster builder, but just about everything else doesn't seem to work.

I'm so glad the devs decided to dump this into Early Access, because otherwise I would've felt so betrayed. I still feeled betrayed though, by the high price for such an unfinished game. I really hope the developers get their act together. I could barely even start my park because I spent like 30 minutes trying to understand the convuluted and idiotic path building system, and my paths still look awful. Even the wonderful coaster editor needs some polishing, it doesn't really give me enough realtime information and my coasters kept flying off the track.

Here's my first look at the game:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nwTBWBjcHFM
Clearly I wasn't in the correct mindset to be playing a buggy game (yeah let's play what is essentially an alpha right after major surgery), but at the same time this game is barely even ready for Early Access.

I continued that first look with a video dedicated to the wonderful coaster editor here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gZS0TyjgQEA . It still needs work, unfortunately, I was really hoping that it was going to work out of the gate. It IS fun though, but you generally end up making puke machines that rate low on the in-game excitement scale.

Would I recommend this game to friends? Not right now. Would I maybe recommend this game to friends in the future? Probably, as I feel like there's a lot of potential for this to be a modern version of the first three RCT games. Will this game ever be worth $50-60? No, probably not. You guys are reeaaaally pushing it with that price point, I would probably pay max $30-40 for this, even if it were full-featured and polished.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe RCT series has been one of my favorite simulation game series for a long time. I was ecstatic when I heard this game was coming out and preordered it....a year ago. Now fast forward a bit after the two messy beta weekends where the game was nowhere near completion. Then when the game was delayed from December (I think), I sent out a refund request to Atari so that I could get my money back for the many disappointments and they started to work with me. After giving them my receipt information like they requested...I didn't hear back for weeks, I sent in another request to get my money back and nothing. I figure it's because they knew the game would be releasing soon...and a few days later, they released that it would come out on March 31st. So, whatever, I am abandon my refund request cause what the hell. And then I play this piece of ♥♥♥♥. I know its still early access but come on everyone. This game barely runs and I have a nice enough rig to play Fallout 4, GTA V, Borderlans Pre Sequel, and Skyrim all out high to intense graphic settings with no problem. This? The FPS drops to around 15-20 when more than 2 rides are placed, or I'm building something, or a significant amount of peeps enter the park. This is early access, but this is not okay. This game should be able to do the basic things, and it just doesn't deliver. I will review this game again once it gets out of early access, but for now I am done wasting my time on this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Waited for so long for this:

Here's why I liked it:

And here's why I didn't:
1) Buggy. Humans float, top end restaurants will NEVER attract any customers no matter what you do. EVERYONE pukes after leaving a roller coaster. NO ONE uses a bin. Takes FOREVER to load. Beyond a certain stage, the game starts to freeze and react slowly. Once, I even had the fortune of having ALL MY GUESTS leave my park suddenly. Terrain flattening doesn't work for some terrains. Annoying as hell. Sometimes you can take a loan, sometimes you can't.

2) Buy a roller coaster that's pre-designed, and you can't change the number of trains, or cars.

3)You can't place the entrance and exit elsewhere.

4)Path has selected spots to join to existing paths, which is stupid.

5)You can't place a shop next to the path, YOU MUST ALWAYS JOIN IT WITH A NEW PATH.

This game clearly has potential. As it stands now, it's a pile of rubbish.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright after reading through some reviews that were negative and searching for the positive ones to no real good avail I have decided to write my review. YES this game has the Roller Coaster Tycoon title but does it really feel like the RCT we know and love? Not really to be completely honest. I was so excited for this game to release and my s/o was generous enough to buy it for me when it was available for purchase so I didnt really spend my OWN money on it. But I do feel for those who did pay for it themselves with their OWN money. I have enjoyed the game so far to a point but I have run into a few issues and these are kind of major ones.

Coaster Customizations:
This is a big one for me! I absolutely love building and designing my own coasters and I figured this point to point style system of building would lead to some REALLY cool coasters. And although it is a very useful thing its a bit confusing at first to use. But what I was really disappointed in is that there is a lack of pre-set parts for the coasters such as loops, corkscrews and twists. Yes they have some but then when you do use them they seem to have messed with the coaster a bit and changes the way it works entirely.

Another complaint with the coaster builder that has REALLY frusterated me is how the BRAKES SYSTEM doesnt seem to WORK PROPERLY (at least for me) now it may be something that I am doing wrong but I get to a point where I want to have the Block Breaks" so I can add a stop point for a second coaster to pause at while the other coaster is at the station. Ive done it in 2 and 3 plenty of times. But when I test the coaster it seems to give me the error that the "Coaster did not complete its circut" and then the second caoster never takes off? This is really weird to me and would like a bit of an easier block break system.

The final thing with the coasters and really the rides overall is that you cant really customize them too much. Like for example; you can change the colors of the tracks but you cant really fully customize the train cars
date: you have preset trains available. But I would like to see the ability to add patterns and change individual colors on the trians. Maybe instead of the individual color boxes you can choose
recommended:
try implementing a COLOR WHEEL with ALL the RGB colors on them?

Scenery options are a bit of a disappointment not much able to mess with there.

ALSO THE BIGGEST ISSUE I AM HAVING IS A HUGE ISSUE WITH MY MEMORY RUNNING LOW WHILE PLAYING THE GAME FOR MORE THAN AN HOUR!!

I have 8GB of Corsair Vengance RAM DDR3 1600MHz and IDK WHY I am getting the error that my computer is running out of memory....

Thats really all the issues I have with this game. I like it when it works
hoursPlayed: but it needs some fixing. I would recommend the game but not at this current time."

reviewText:
This game is really pretty, but I honestly can't recommend it. And yes, I realize that it's an early beta for the roller coaster builder. But the roller coaster builder (the core of the game) is absolutely broken. I wanted so badly to like it.

While the spline editor is a great idea, it just doesn't work in any feasible way. You'll pull out your hair trying to refine anything, and forget about making straight track. The result is an ugly, unrealistic, gangly, and awkward roller coaster that takes up way too much space and barely runs. There's no precision and the controls are so touchy that you'll find yourself screaming at your computer. Skill aside, it shouldn't take over an hour to lay down a lift hill--only to have the train randomly crash on a simple and shallow (forced by the game) pre-lift drop.

Please delay the full release of this game. Go back to the drawing board. Try compromising the spline editor with the piece-by-piece system to allow for the compact and interesting coasters the franchise is known for while keeping the smoother rides.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm nearly 39 years old and as a father of two young children I don't get to play too many PC games from my youth, but there are a few that I've waited many of years to play...RCT and Sim City being the priorities.  After the horrible Sim City release, I said I would never buy another game from EA and now Atari has done the same to the RCT series with World.

I'm not sure who they are hiring to program these games anymore (cheapest folks I guess) but I'm in complete shock at the condition/state of this game (early access aside).  Before these games get issued to the public the CEO should play for at least 2 hours because I can't imagine any CEO who cares about quality or name recognition would consider releasing a game in the current state of RCTW.  If possible, I would hope Atari would just scrap this game and provide an amazing update of new props, flat rides and coasters, etc. for folks to incorporate into the existing RCT3 (please consider).

My experience with the current state of World:  Load the game / before entering into a scenario or sandbox choose the quit button - a pop up appears and asks would you like to quit game" - Choose Quit - pop up disappears and takes you back to the main menu without quitting game.  The stinking main menu doesn't even work.  Nothing works. The limited coasters in early access don't line up very easily and each one I built had major graphical issues of all types

I'm just livid that another favorite game from my youth has been completely and utterly destroyed to the point of which you know another release will never happen.  Sorry - but I find it shocking that PC Game Makers like Atari can't build a game better then what it was a decade earlier...I guess the end of PC games is just around the corner.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rollercoaster Tycoon is an important game for me. It is that game what I install everytime something bad happened, when I'm ill or when I want to destress. Install RCT 1, 2 or 3 and you have a smile on your face in a minute I can guarantee you.

The game has it's own character. The colors, the happy peeps, balloons and the cartoony artstyle without being a casual game at all is proven a strong a concept and I think after many years this game is still a lot's of gamers favorite.
It was RCT that I saw on friends PC's screens, even on them who never play any other video game.

RCT World fails in every aspect to reproduce the freedom and creativity and addictive feeling of the older RCT games.
Even when the game did not suffered from technical bugs, 3D glitches, broken sound/music, bad optimization and way too less content it was a bad game. It's missing spirit, comedy, freedom and everything what makes the RCT series great.
The peeps are boring to look at. They don't have any style themself. It seems the dev team could not choose between realistic and cartoony and choose to design a mix of photorealistic characters with cartoony movement models. Everything moves too fast even on slow setting on a slow engine. I did met the sys req. for the game (the minimum) but whatever graphic setting I use after I place my first rollercoaster the game can't deliver anymore.

Object placement and path placement is ridiculous. The terrain tools very user unfriendly. You can't place path where you want, even if it seems to fit perfectly the engine don't allow you to place anything on random places. Tools you have like a grid and a snap grid makes this even more worse.

You can only place objects directly to the ground. You cannot place anything on top of something else. You can't even place banks, lights, carbage bins anymore on paths when the path is higher then the ground level. You can not build anything anymore in the game itself. (It's advertised that you can build anything in any other 3D tool and import it).

There is almost non to zero customization. You can't choose the main building, the entrance building, thematic entrances, place of entrances etc etc. It's all setup for you so the only thing you can do is build a prefab item. No creative building anymore.

You can't assign staff, can't train staff, can't change the colors of them. It's all setup. Same for food stalls, ticket stalls, peeps etc etc.

The management tools are not complete. The menu to read info about your parc is very hard to read. It's just a plain spreadsheet directly imported from the engine to the game. No nice menu's, no humor, no cartoony style and just a plain and simple click and place building game with a tycoon parc theme around it.

Last but not least the amount of content you get at the moment is 1/30 part of the original RCT games. You have 6 rollercoasters to choose from, 4 different terrain types (instead of 18 in RCT 3), a few thrill and a few junior and family rides. All rides are fixed and you cannot change anything yourself. But even if you could the amount of content provided by the game itself is so minimum. You can choose between some rocks and some trees and a handfull of decoration pieces.

Theme parc building should be something that makes you happy and should be happened smooth and relax. This game is slow, frustrating, ugly and simply misses anything that could make a game like this fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It really bums me out to write this review.

Let me start by telling you the blame for this fiasco is squarely on Atari. They hired a studio that had no reputation to build the game originally. They wasted a lot of time and money and didn't have anything to show for it.

Since Atari brought Nvizzio on to finish the game, huge improvements were made in short amount of time. I have a lot of respect for the hard work Nvizzio is doing.

Still, Atari set horrible expectation during the whole process and they've not done a great job of communicating with people following the progress of this game.

I'm fairly against pre-ordering games, but after the progress I saw Nvizzio making I decided to pre-order to show my support. They didn't deliver on any of the pre-order perks and went silent again for months. Until today.

Now the game is releasing in Early Access, which I'm typically a fan of, but I didn't pre-order an unfinished game. Obviously being Early Access the performance is pretty horrible, even on high end hardware.

So yeah, don't buy this game. Not yet. I think it will be great in a year or two, but right now it's just a mess and Atari doesn't deserve your money for how they've treated this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not a bad game, but it has serious limitations which are a) infuriating and b) extraordinary considering this is about the fifth version of the game.

My kids love the sandbox version, which allows them an unlimited budget to put together the teme park of their dreams and ride on the attractions they've created.  Frankly, $30 is quite a lot to pay for a kid's game.

The campaign game, whereby grown-ups attempt to achieve goals, seems buggy.  The first time I played it, it gave me the option to build a handful of rides, but no paths.  Even as the game was telling me that I needed to build paths so park visitors could reach the rides that I'd built, it was giving me no option to build a path.

The second time I played it, it gave me a paths option after a few minutes, and then a buildings option.  Then, after I'd built a few buildings, it took the buildings option away, and refused to restore it, even after I'd expanded the park substantially.  The game was telling me that my visitors were hungry, but denied me any opportunity to build restaurants.  The game told me rides were breaking down, but denied me any opportunity to build mechanic stations to provide the machenics to fix the rides.  Eventually, my park simply ground to a halt.

At no time did the campaign game provide me an opportunity to build a flower bed.  I see lots of screenshots above of luscious parks, with lamps, and decorations, and attractions, but my experience is that you can only create such scenes in the sandbox version in which everything is unlocked.  Althogh I played the campaign games to the point that I had fairly extensive parks, never could I have constructed the screenshots in the publicity.

Paths are the single, most-infuriating thing in the game.  In real life, you can build a path anywhere.  In Switzerland, they buld entire freeways across the Alps and through some of the world's largest mountains.  So why is constructing a dirt path across your theme park a great world of You can't do that"?  You need to make very certain in advance of where your paths are going to go
date: and you can't add to many extensions to them without extensive demolitionand reconstruction.  Visitors on the path constitute obstructions
recommended: so if you're hoping to rebuild a major pathway
hoursPlayed: you have little option but to close the park and wait for the traffic to clear.  This will take a very long time and represent a potentially catastrophic loss of income
voteText: but it's the only way you can reconstruct a path!  Other problems with path construction are too numerous to detail here.  Suffice to say that probably noting in this game will raise your blood pressure  more than path construction.\n\nAll this said

votesFunny: it's great.  But I find it extraordinary that the developers have allowed the program's very obvious weaknesses to go ahead -- or even that the program's weaknesses weren't taken with in previous versions.  By the fourth version

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment I have to give this game a no for recommendation sadly. I had hoped that it would be a great game! But sadly it is missing SO MUCH and it is no where close to properly optimized. This is the first game on my just built PC that actually lags when I am building stuff.

So to not just complain, here is a list for the dev's on what they may be able to do to somehwat salvage the game.

1). Optimize your ♥♥♥♥, I mean really optimize this game because holy crap.

2). There needs to be more variety for rides and buildings, this game is over 10 years old and the original roller coaster tycoons have more rides.... you need to be surpassing that. Things like swimming stuff should already be in the game and not something that would be DLC because they where already in Roller Coaster Tycoon 3.

3). Back to touch on something of optimization. You can't make a single path straight and that is starting to ♥♥♥♥ me off, nor can you place objects on paths basically wherever you want. This should not be an issue yet it is, I don't see how it can be an issue but you guys seem to have made it an issue.

4). Fix the terrain tools so the brushes are larger when you are closer so that you can actually see if you have gotten everything down to the level you want it or up to the level you want it. I am constantly having the problem where I think I got it all then I build something and notice I didn't.

5). Optimize the peeps, both workers and guests, so they stop being so dumb about things. I basically have to have a janitor/mechanic for every ride I put in the park because they seem to not move quick enough between everything. As for the peeps, every thrill ride and coaster I constantly have a path covered in puke even if I put a bathroom right next to the exit...

6). I think that you guys may be heading in the right direction but there is just simply not enough in the game at the moment to get my recommendation. This may sound harsh, and it is, but I wouldn't even want to release the game with how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ it is at the moment. Add things like research and development into the game to unlock things, don't gate them behind completing parts of the campaign. That is tidious and annoying when I have no real control over what I want more of.

7). Developers, listen to your audience and realize ♥♥♥♥ is going wrong at the moment. For example the grid, well since the grid isn't properly alligned at the moment it doesnt work, simple and easy fix but yet you guys haven't done it. Just please listen to your audience so that you stop getting such negative reviews.

reviewText:
I'm gonna recommend this game for the following reasons:

- The game is in beta stage, and they've made beta testing mainly to fix bugs, and find main issues on the way. However after i've seen this beta so far, there's still alot they'll need to improve, but the tools you do have are excellent compared to other coasters.

- It's like Cities Skylines of Roller Coaster games, mainly because the community is huge for this game, and steam workshop. A lot of people fear that there's only 10 coasters, don't worry just wait 1-3 months and you'll have pretty much every coaster in the world to play around with. Not only can you share what you've made, but also most likely see legendary coasters in-game. But for every coaster i guess they'll look on highway systems from Cities Skylines for an example where you could pick different interchanges from the community, in this game under speciality, you'll most likely find extreme versions of loops, corkscrews and etc.

- Even though the game is pretty good so far, as i said earlier there's a lot of features they'll need to add. It's almost impossible to make something 100% straight, and i will go cry in a corner if they don't add such a feature, because that's mainly one of the few things you'll need.

So after this review, i would say the game got a bright future, but it takes some time to get used to, i really wanted a tutorial in the beta, just to know how the mechanics work. It's nice to being able to tweak EVERYthing on your coaster. But they should add classic mode coaster building from the older games. All in all if it was up to me i would give it 7/10 for now, but it's only in beta and hopefully it will only improve from full release 10th dec. But lets see how the next beta goes, and if the game actually improved or they'll need to push the release date a few months.
