reviewText:
Early Access Review

How the mighty have fallen. RollerCoaster Tycoon, a brand once loved by millions already reeling from the abomination that was RollerCoaster Tycoon 4 Mobile has now been damaged further (perhaps irreparably) by the travesty that is RollerCoaster Tycoon World.

The whole game smacks of My first Unity project" with Atari/Nvizzio having taken every shortcut possible to produce this game for the minimum amount of expense possible.

What the game's current developers (Nvizzio Creations) have done in this game is to essentially throw in lots of copy & paste assets making minimal changes such as stores that are all but identical aside from a change to the awning and some garish object stuck to the roof in order to distinguish it from every other copy & paste building.

Then there's the guests
date: they wander your park with a blank facial expression urinating and puking all over the place or shuffling forward like zombies clutching their arm as if it's broken to indicate they're hungry. You'll spend half your time building janitorial buildings in order to try and keep up with the job of cleaning up the never ending stream of bodily fluids polluting your pathways.\n\nThen there's the horrible optimisation of the game
recommended: this will bring even the most powerhouse PC to a crawl as soon as you get more than a few thousand guests in your park
hoursPlayed:
all this with graphics that look like they belong in 2006.

I'm sure you're all dying to tell me how it's Early Access and it'll get better but please don't waste your time doing so. This game was advertised as 6 short weeks from full release back when they ran their first "beta" weekend at the end of October 2015 and Atari/Nvizzio demonstrated that they had fixed the problems with the coaster editor (the cause for the delay to early 2016) in a live Stream in December 2015 so if that was the only hold up why after an additional 3 months have they gone backwards and released it as Early Access?

Due to the fact that Atari have been living hand to mouth since emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy in December 2013 and have likely sunk a fortune into this over the last 2 years having 3 separate developers (one of which sued Atari for breach of contract and accepted a settlement out of court[www.pacermonitor.com]) and the terrible first impression that this game has made since it's release to Early Access
voteText: the chances of this game even recouping it's costs are slim to none. Knowing this and looking back at Atari's most recent abandoned games (Alone In the Dark: Illumination
helpfulPercent: Haunted House: Cryptic Graves & Asteroids: Outpost) it's hard to see why Atari would continue to support this game any more than they have any of these other abandoned projects.\n\nBuy this game at your peril
votesHelpful: it's unlikely to ever fulfil that long list of promised features and leave Early Access. I will actually be highly surprised if Atari keep Nvizzio on the payroll any longer than the next 3 months before they pull all funding and abandon this game too."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You could try and ignore all the many bugs, the rubbish graphics, the really awful looking guests, the amateurish animations, the bad AI, the cheap and often incorrect sounds, the slow map loading, the low framerates, and the blury out of focus camera to stop you noticing the lack of details in the models and textures, if you really want to play this game, but you're better off rolling round in a stinging nettle bush.

I realise that currently this is an early release game. however, this must have been done on a low budget and it is not worthy of being part of the Rollercoaster Tycoon series.  Many of the current issues were reported to the developers by testers months ago (why are they not fixed?).

If you want to play a top quality triple A Rollercoaster game then look at Frontier's Planet Coaster, the developers of Rollercoaster Tycoon 3.  Although, at the time of writing this review Planet Coaster is currenly in early alpha, it is vastly better than this disaster.

Honestly, save yourself money and anguish and avoid this game (and stinging nettle).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

We are huge fans of RollerCoaster Tycoon, however, we are done with this franchise and want a refund.  RollerCoaster Tycoon World  is a FAIL on so many levels---a few examples are: there is no edge scrolling so you need two hands to play the game; the graphics look like cartoon graphics, not what was presented in the trailer; the game  play space to too small for the sizes of the pre-made rides, too many trees that need to be deleted because the rollercoaster takes up more than half of the park space (that is filled with trees!) ---the list goes on!  We suggest that you go back to the drawing board using RollerCoaster Tycoon 1 (Deluxe) as the base game and improve the graphices on that one ---even that would be better that what you have provided.

If you are planning to be new to the franchise don't waste your money on this one; buy the first two if you want to have clean and simple fun and the third one if you prefer a more graphic experience,  This one is not worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am a huge fan of RCT3 and I was dreaming of the release of a sequel since a couple of years after its release in 2004.

Up until yesterday before the release, I was only slightly frustrated it was taking so much time for the game to come out (it was originally planned to be released early 2015) as I really wanted the game to be as great as possible and did not mind Atari taking time to make a game that would deserve to be called RCT, especially after I got to play the beta back in November 2015 when I saw that they were very far from having any part of the game finished at all.

But after such a long wait when I finally got to play RCTW yesterday, I went through extreme excitement to denial, followed by disgust and finally ended up laughing nervously in front of my screen.

To make it simple, if RCT3, a 12 years old game was released today, it would still be by very, very, very far a better game.

In RCTW, everything is broken:

- The graphics of the peeps, structures and the land when zoomed are absolutely disgusting and can compete with games like Super Mario 64 released 20 years ago (I am barely exaggerating)
- The roller coaster building system is completely broken and it takes hours to complete one that has many chances to end up not working properly at the end.
- It is very buggy, I mean so so so so so buggy, I had to relaunch the game 3 times in 2 hours I never saw anything like that before.
- Despite the fact that they look like they were made using MS Paint, the peeps will look like either vampires (Vendors at stands with red eyes) or zombies (they walk like zombies when they hold anything), or witches (janitors cleaning vomit with a broom and hovering when moving). Looks like they got the horror theme right at least!
- The non roller coasters rides are not only very few but look worse than the ones on RCT3. The way peeps act while on some of them is completely unnatural and it just hurts so much looking at it.
- Unless I missed something, there is only ONE song that can be played for all the rides. They give you the option to change it depending on the theme but essentially, it is the same song just slightly different! And if you have 2 rides next to each other and play the music on both, the music is not synchronised and I let you imagine what it sounds like!
- Even when I got frustrated and tried to be nasty with my peeps this would not work! The peep picking tool does not work, taking one and putting them at the opposite part of the park teleports them back to their original place after a few seconds, peeps in cars that are ejected from the coaster will be teleported to the exit, and drowning peeps (Yes, I was very annoyed at this point!) by adding water does not work, they either keep walking underwater or may eventually stop moving and start jumping" in the water indefinitely.

A few extras:
-Most park management options from RCT3 are gone.
-Peeps disappearing
hoursPlayed:
queuing the wrong way.
-Female peeps (even male?) make porn sounds.
-Sounds of babies crying all the time or children sounding like they are being tortured.
-Background decors unfinished.

I am stopping here but I could add more
voteText:
and that is after having played the game only 2 hours!

But I know what some of you may want to say: "it's normal it's an early access!"
Well
helpfulPercent: before you go any further
votesHelpful: here is a thing: Atari had planned to release the game early 2015
votesTotal: and after being postponed multiple times
votesFunny: we got to play the beta in November 2015. More than 4 months later
commentsCount:
I cannot see ANY improvement whatsoever that has been made. (I actually think it is even worse as during the beta we did not get the chance to see the monstrosity that are the peeps as they were only "ghosts" back then.)

Atari had multiple chances and a lot of time to improve the game but fact is they just did not care so I cannot see how this game will be any better in the future. I requested a refund of the game and advise everyone not to buy this game.

A very disappointed fan.

"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At this point in time, RollerCoaster Tycoon World just isn't ready. To be honest, for a game that was to be complete by this point in time, only to be shunned into Early Access again, and to be as buggy as can be - I don't think this merits spending the $20 that I did (I bought this game through a CD key on a different website, so I cannot refund the game, but hey, it was $20). If you are planning on spending $50 on the game at this time, please don't. It's not worth it. $20 is pushing it at the time - I know there is the opportinuty for this game to get better, and if it does, I will go back and I will change my review.

On a more positive note, the game is very stable - I don't think it is quite as efficient as it could be, but again, that is an expectation for an Early Access game. I think to be fair, that is something that will get better over time. I had no issues with the game crashing or anything like that - it was laggy until I adjusted graphics settings, but overall it was fine. There are a ton of graphical bugs in this game though - Roller coasters suddenly having peeps go away for no reason, that kind of thing.

Overall, I'd stay away for now. Give it some more time. I think there is a chance it will get better.... but I can't say for sure.
voteText: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nYou know to be completely honest I loved RCT all the way up to RCT3 Platinum. But honestly now I feel its gone into the wrong hands. I really think I know where it went wrong, Atari. The game was originally created by one man, then in 2 Frontier came in to make it even better, In 3 it was still great when Atari came in, but when Atari seized power all was lost. Atari made some good games, unfortunately Rollercoaster sims are not their thing. I don't want Atari to feel horrible or like it is a lost cause, because quite frankly some people are still going to enjoy it and some have already bought it, but this project is going to lose them money. I played through a friend, and thought it was fun, but when I saw gameplay for PlanetCoaster my experience was over taken just watching the video. Here is the fact Frontier knows what they are doing, they are making PlanetCoaster, and they therefore changed the name of the true RCT. I think in all fairness your money is better spent there. If you aren't a mechanics freak like me and most others though you'll still enjoy RCT. I am not reccomending the game however, because it hasn't met my criteria. Sorry to the Atari RCTW team, hope you can find better luck in a different and hopefully following project (If this one doesn't send you spiraling out of business).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is not ready to be released even in Alpha.  It actually offers less content and features than the game it supposedly succeeds (RCT3).   To ask $50 for so little content is asking way too much.  This is not the way to make your fan base happy Atari!  Requested refund and am going to wait for Planet Coaster - which shows so much more promise.

Cities: Skylines turned out to be what most people were hoping for in the last SimCity.  Let's hope that Planet Coaster is the true successor to RCT3.  Sadly, RollerCoaster Tycoon World does not appear to be it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Welcome to a game that looks worse then Rollercoaster tycoon 3.

I normally never ask for a refund for a game, but holy cow this game is a mess that seems more like coming out of a scam indie studio then a well-known Atari backed studio that seemed to have control on the development and was finally giving us another great rollercoaster tycoon game, but even in early access this game is so broken that it would require a major overhaul so big that we would not see it for a long time and they do not seem willing to do that.

I can live with graphics that are not top end, i can live with certain framedrops and lag in a early access game. What i do not however can live with and support is a broken game where it´s not just the above that is the problem, its also animation, core gameplay elements like guests actually going to a store, guests that run around like headless chickens because the queue is not long enough, pathways that are just poor. not to mention ridecams that made me look at the date just to make sure i was not actually back in the 90´s.

These things was even in a old Rollercoaster tycoon 3 but it seems that the developers have forgotten that we are writing 2016 and not 1996.

So can i recommend this?, not a chance in fact STAY FAR FAR FAR FAR AWAY. Unless they change their game drastically this is a failiure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly, I think a lot of the negative reviews are from the constant disappointment. For the game to be delayed 3 times and end up being early access.... Who wouldn't be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about that? The game is for sure not finished and doesn't run very smooth, but it has a lot of potential to be a good game. If the developers actually use the early access to perfect the game, then yes, I will recommend it. If the game gets stuck in early access and never goes anywhere, then there will be a lot of angry RCT fans.

Last, the game doesn't have much content at all. I really hope they double if not triple the amount of content in the game. To charge 50$ for this game is kind of a joke. Let's just say the additional content/DLC better be free for game owners.

For now I'm going to give it a thumbs down, but I will quickly change it to a thumbs up if I see the developers are actually making progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I fell in love with RollerCoaster Tycoon, I gave hours of my adolescent life to RollerCoaster Tycoon 2. I had to fight my wife for the PC when RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 came out because she got addicted too. I love this franchise! However, after playing RCTW for less than an hour, I have requested a refund.

I might purchase it again when it leaves early access and is a proven, solid game. Until then, I am sorely disappointed. I am unable to trust Atari with those titles that I grew up with, those fragile memories from my childhood. This saddens me deeply.

In the meantime, Planet Coaster kicks ♥♥♥♥. The true spiritual succesor by the developers behind RT3. Go buy it, NOW!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having played and enjoyed the RCT franchise for most of my life, I was overjoyed when I heard this game was in development. I never thought a Roller Coaster Tycoon game could be butchered so badly. Boy, was I proven wrong.

This game feels like a bad port of a knock-off RCT game for a mobile platform. There's barely any content, the graphics are sub-par, the UI is clunky, the guests lag the game, and you can't even move the camera with the mouse. They said this game was 80-90% done upon release? And after numerous release delays, they have the audacity to try and hide it behind an Early Access tag at the last minute to attempt to cover up how flawed the game is. There is no excuse for this.

This game does not deserve to be called a Roller Coaster Tycoon game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWell this game is not what I expected it to be, first of all i've been playing the game for an hour now and I still haven't successfully built a path, the controls are so difficult to use and the tutorial isn't much help either with a measly three step guide that was certainly no use. Another issue I seem to be having is that due to my unsuccesful building of a path i'm having to delete an awful lot, this however came with yet more difficulty as the demolish cursor wouldnt snap right to the path. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Every review I see on here is bashing on the graphics. Honestly I'm not here to look at a pretty game I'm here to make a park and have fun. So graphics aside. This is my review.

I've only played a bit and I'm not impressed!

Camera: The camera in the game is awful. You use the WASD keys to move. Why can't I click and hold left and drag? When you zoom in it gets blurry and looks awful.

Pathing: Don't even bother trying to put a que line or anything down. It's annoying. It doesn't work. Just don't. Also why can't I right click to delete stuff? Speaking of...

Teraforming: OMG KILL ME. What do you mean I can't move the land up? OH because of that little stupid rose bush?! Well just move it up with it or just delete it. Instead you have to go to the delete tool, delete the tree/bush, go back to terrain, then and only then can you move it.

Que Lines: Why do I have to BUY the ride sign? Why isn't it just on the end like it is on EVERY RCT?

Overall: So sad. Wanted to like it, wanted to think everyone was wrong about it. But no. This game (I know it's early) Has a lot of issues. It feels like  the people behind this game have never even played a roller coaster tycoon. Off to check out Planet Coaster.

reviewText:
For this beta they wanted to test the coaster builder. It works fine if you get the hang of it, but for some reason the coaster will never be finished. I tried to build 1 coaster, but it totally randoms fails at random places. Yes, it even failed for me with chaining up before the drop or sometimes even when leaving the station(physics problems).
Sometimes it made sense it failed, but then you tweak the place where it failed, you can tweak everything thats next aswell..

Had some other issues aswell:
-Needed to change my graphic card settings to get the game even running(otherwise you see a nice blue screen and   after some time you get kicked back you desktop).
-Memory leak, after some time the game is not playable anymore, checked what it was but 8GB ram wasnt enough....
-Game Speed affected the rollercoaster.
-Camera is sometimes hard to control when building the coaster.


It's the first beta, but they wanted feedback on the coaster builder (How people like the new system of building coasters). But if you can't play normal to test this thing then I say this game ain't ready to launch yet.
Hope this game will release later then the date they stated.
So for now I don't recommend this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If a player keeps from viewing others' views and opinions and allows an open mind before entering this world, then I think they can find themselves having an adequate time playing for a few hours. This goes especially to those players intending to do super-basic stuff like building basic rides, planting basic scenery, do minimal to no landscaping, etc.

But when a game has so many glitches, so much lag, and so many errors and incomplete aspects within it, you have to sit and wonder who's bright idea it was to release this horrifically broken piece of software at the price of a full-fledged, fully-built, fully-complete-and-ready-to-sell-to-the-masses video game. I understand the game is listed as Early Alpha
date: so this should be expected, but coming from a video game that was originally intended to be released summer of last year, I was at least hoping for it to be polished enough for more serious gameplay.\n\nI found the game okay to play at first and that the reviews many YouTube gamers were giving it to be just a tad bit exaggerated. But do heed their words, and do heed the words of the Mostly Negative" reviews found on the Steam Page. In the end
recommended: it's really not worth it.\n\nI intend to keep my copy to play at another date and hope that they will improve it over time
hoursPlayed: but it will likely gather dust now and then until I feel ready to suffer through the tremendous lag and superabundant number of peeps puking for my generic janitors to clean. Your $50 could be better spent elsewhere. I promise

You know you have problems when a really early PlanetCoaster build is far more polished and feature rich than RollerCoaster Tycoon Worlds beta early build.

All of the comments and opinions I have are with me knowing that yes it is an early access/release. Although I know this, it really isn't an excuse considering we have passed the original full game release date, and second full game release date.

WAIT UNTIL THE GAME IS NOT IN EARLY ACCESS TO PURCHASE!! unless you want to pay for a game with a new glitch or bug around every corner and you end up refunding it anyways from pure frustration.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is terrible. It still is nowhere near release. You can't edit hardly anything on the pre-built rides, coasters, and structures. The peep graphics are choppy at any eye height beyond right over top of them. The coaster building interface is junk - it lets you build ridiculous track segments while defying logic and sense. The graphics are poor - RCT3 was better. The on ride cameras are choppy when turning or changing slope - very poor. You can't see the ride increase or decrease speed either, it always looks like it's going the same speed. The building system overall is bad, clunky, impossible to place things where you want them. The game is so far from ready, and there doesn't seem to be any promising sign that it's going to get any better. This is all coming from a very disappointed, huge RCT fan from day 1. Bummer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a long time fan of the RollerCoaster Tycoon series, it really sucks that I have to give this review. I've been patient, given Atari plenty of leniency after reading all of their blog posts, and I actually bought the game expecting to get something that's at least enjoyable to play. (Luckily I got it for $30AU elsewhere)

Sadly, that is not the case. After months of broken promises of the full release of the game, we get this steaming hot mess in Early Access instead. And it's not fun.

The peeps look horrendous and the animations are all awkward, and there are quite a few instances where staff will appear to glide across the map. When you scroll out completely the peeps look like pixels moving jaggedly.

The coaster builder, while innovative, is really not that pleasant to work with. While I enjoy being offered more flexibility in building a roller coaster, I still have a very hard time getting the pieces to work just how I want them to, and it doesn't integrate well with the piece-by-piece builder - which, by the way, doesn't have the option to place pre-built banked curves. Moreover, there's no way to change the speed of a whole section of chain lift at the same time - Why isn't this feature present here when it was present in all previous RCT games.

The stalls are oversized, the transition from individual staff to staff-rooms is terrible, the path system, while innovate, also lacks from terrible implementation and lack of piece-by-piece building, the rides look tacky, blah blah blah...

I could go on for ages, but to sum it up, it's...not fun to play at all. I'm not vibing it like I did with the first 3 installments, and I honestly would have faith in this game, but considering the amount of times Atari's been blowing smoke up our ♥♥♥, I can't give credit to anything they say anymore. AAA game my ♥♥♥, Mattlab.

I could only justify buying the game if it was $10, but that's stretching it. Don't waste your time on this game right now. If you have a real itch to immerse yourself in a beautiful theme park sim, fork out the extra money for Planet Coaster.

Total rubbish - Un-finished, unmarketable dross.

I dont write steam reviews; Mainly becuase I am rubbish at them. In fact, my reviews are on par with the state of this game......

The animations are awful and the UI is clunky. The 'Early Access' branding of this iconic game was always a mistake. Loyal fanbase back in the forum have been kept in the dark for months, but were informed by dev's the game was under going 'optmising and polish' a few weeks before the announced 'Early Access.' This was clearly an attempt to keep up with the competition, that released an Alpha before Atari and an attempt at trying to control media and user opinion with the usual cavet of 'Its early access.'

Poor choices, poor devlopement and poor management have left this title lacking in all of the areas the old games excelled - Avoid right now, Come back this time next year when the title may be in Beta stage, with better graphics, performance and UI.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although this game is currently in 'early access' i'm not going to be too lenient on it as I originally pre-ordered it to come out in December 2015. For me, it has recreated the old 'Rollercoaster Tycoon' games but just removed the fun.

Pros:

- Despite what some people say, the rollercoaster builder is actually quite nice to use and I was able to create some good designs with it.
- The ride cameras can sometimes be fun (if the framerate keeps up enough!)

Cons (Where do I even start?):

- Such a simple task of building paths is such a pain.. the game is so fussy about what connects where, and even with grid and snapping, I was unable to create a simple straight path system
- The ride a building placement is equally as unpredictable, refusing to allow buildings to be placed in open areas next to paths, also not automatically joining to a path when placed directly next to one.
- The staffing system has been 'dumbed down' and the janitors walk off and do what they want. You find yourself constantly building new staff buildings as the staff have seemingly disappeared and I cannot find a way to track them individually.
- There is little to no customization on certain rides (especially pre-built ones).. Again, this removes a large portion of the fun.
- The game seems to include food and souvineer stands from 4 set themes, limiting your creativity.
- Only 3 maps that you can start from scratch on.
- No autosave feature, so I lost over an hours work due to a power cut. In 2016 I would have thought this would be a standard feature?

- Now for probably the biggest con.. graphics and performance... For a game that was supposedly meant to be 'retail ready' by December 2015, its appauling. The graphics look like a mobile phone game, or a PC game from 2004. Also the performance on highest settings is really bad. On my GTX 970, I can get around 30-40fps scrolling round my park. When I zoom in to watch the customers glitch around the footpaths and disappear into rides, however, i get as low as 15fps. The framerate is also very unpredictable when using the ride cams.

I could go on and on about how I am disappointed by this game, but I'll cut the review here. I was looking forward to this so much last year that I didnt cancel my pre-order when I heard about the beta. I also eagerly downloaded it the minute I saw it was avaliable. I tried to enjoy the game and ignored the criticism, but all it did was make me want to play 'Rollercoaster Tycoon 2'!
voteText: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While leaps and bounds better than what they threw at us back in October, this game is still lacking any sort of strong feeling. If anything, this is what they should have started with. While all the features are there, even more bugs are present. Paths to not work properly, peeps look awful, the camera feels worse than a classic N64 camera. Not to mention, the parks are SO SMALL. All of the premade coasters aren't very interesting and also quite small. You may be lucky to get 2 coasters in the same park.

Coaster builder again, while much much better, is still a disaster, and the camera doesn't make trying to build exactly the way you want it any easier. Placing a premade track piece, and then going into freeform mode causes the previous piece to deform and angle awkwardly. Nothing is very streamlined at this point.

I have not tried anything else other than placing a few flat rides and staff buildings (another thing that shouldn't have been included, as it takes up already insufficient space); because the game crashed when trying to change the options.

This game needs at LEAST another 8 months in development to get everything sorted out, and done right.

As many have already said, Planet Coaster is already 1000x what this is looking to be. I hate to be one to compare between two different games, but it's really true. If you want a good Theme Park simulator, or even just want to be able to build cool, interesting (not to mention large) coasters, RCTW is not for you. Hats off to Nvizzio for trying, but you've missed the mark for a second time.

Cheers everyone, see you in Planet Coaster

reviewText:
So I played the game over the weekend pretty much none stop and I can say I was super excited about this game. The graphics are pretty awesome.

I like some of the news things they have put into this game but it still is nothing like the original. Which to me this is a good and bad thing. It is great that we have so much more customization to this game. Circle paths, large, small, medium paths, lights, trash cans, benches, etc.

I enjoy the fact that you can make a roller coaster now almost as you wish and it is not constrained as it was in the old Roller Coaster Tycoon. But with that being said, the magic of the old games is not completely present here.

I want to build a roller-caster, test, add my scenery, my queue and be off. I don't want to spend almost 2 hours on building a coaster and than not be able to finish it because my train car is always hitting a bar that was placed in the wrong area by the game. I don't want to spend close to an hour and a half just to complete laying out my track. I want to put able to select the section of the track and place it how I like. There are alot of advantages to this new UI and I do recognize them but I am not a roller coaster designer. I am a average player that wants to build a roller coaster in the game as quickly and have it enjoyable. At the point, it is not that enjoyable to build a roller coaster because it is super frustrating.

Here is an example on why it is so frustrating, If I am building my roller coaster and I am zoomed out to see what it looks like. If I click on a portion of the map where i would like for my track to be laid, that game from now where lays a very large piece of track randomly that the end of the new piece of track is laid down all the way to the edge of the park. WHAT?!!!!! That is not what I wanted. Now I have to zoom back in to make the track smaller, than angle the camera just right, and than either shift and any of the 4 number to adjust the track as I want. That is just ridiculous.

If you are going to show a grid, as I like building on a grid, don't give me just a small piece of grid. Just display it on the whole map.

For sure there is a learning curve for this game. But so far my initial review of this game is not all the stellar when building coaster. This is something that is NOT going to change for this is pretty much the hole core of the game.

I am still at a maybe..... I wouldn't recommend this game but at the same time if you are a die hard fan as I am, I wouldn't turn you away either.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a huge RCT fan, this is a tough one. On one hand this game is (head scratchingly) in early access. On the other hand, they've had multiple games in the series to pull from in terms of content and roadmapping as well as several delays before the official release date. As an early access game, it's not bad. It's completely playable with the money and simulation basics in there to actually run a park.

However, as an RCT game it is a major letdown. We were promised an evolution in the series and what's here is simply the framework for the next step. Is that a bad thing? Not exactly, if something isn't broke then don't fix it. But it's nowhere near what Planet Coaster is doing. Right now you have 3 themes and over half of the scenery/props are locked. I'm not sure if they are locked behind some sort of in-game system or locked out because they aren't finished yet... the game doesn't say. My park ran smoothly enough for me but after I had built 3 coasters and 8 flat rides, I had 1,300 peeps in my park. At one point my menu disappeared so I had to exit out and reload from the main menu. After it sluggishly reloaded, the framerate was in the single digits. Making it unplayable in my eyes.

As for the coaster builder, I didn't care for it much at first. I made a clunky and ugly first coaster. The second was a bit better and the third was almost exactly what I wanted. It's not a bad system and I actually think it works great once you learn how to use it. You can attach set pieces, just like in the older RCT games, or you can go off the grid and make whatever you want! You just have to play with it. So, the coaster builder is on the short list of positives for this game.

The biggest problems I see right now is the amount of content, lack of in depth management tools (staff management, etc.), ugly peeps, and poor optimization. Luckily these are things that can be addressed and fixed. The menus aren't particularly eye pleasing but that's not a big deal.

Also, the mission objectives that are given to you in game are so HUGE they sometimes occupy 75% of the screen so you can't look at the tasks while playing with your park. You have to look at them, close it out, try to finish the task, then open it back up to see the next one. It's mind bogglingly annoying!

The truth is that there is a lot of potential here but right now it's not worth the asking price. Wait for a sale or the full version to see if they can polish this up a bit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first glance (30 mins in) I am a bit disapointed. Remembering though that it is EARLY ACCESS - but also remembering that they were going to release the game about now as 'finished'.

Definitly not a finished game. Graphic issues everywhere. Glitchy and lots of clipping around the place. Peeps tend to hover and not walk about. Staff members do the same. Paths clip. The on-coaster Cam needs a fair bit of work - there is no detail in the coaster, but the scenery is good looking a far.

The ambience is a bit quiet or sterile so far. It seems pretty dull for a theme park, even with a few hundred people in. You dont hear the hum of people, just the random moans and screams of some ladies - which sounds like pornography tbh. And lots of money cha-ching noises from your rides. I was expecting a bit more immersion and realism.

At this stage I'm on the fence. Im not excited but it has some potential. I am considering a refund and trying Planet Coaster Alpha instead - it looks more polished.

I would give it probably a 5.5 to a 6/10 in its current state, but I will give it more of a go over the next few days and update. My advice though... is to wait. The Atari team could turn this around and make it into something great.

*UPDATE* I gave this game a really good go and played for a few hours and have decided on requesting a refund. Already I feel I have played enough and done everything. It doesnt feel like an RCT game - theres no atmosphere. The coaster builder and camera is also horrible and VERY hard to use. 3hrs into the game and I dont feel like playing anymore - now you all know thats not right - not to mention my fingers are sore from clicking (the bulldose system sucks too).

I may consider re-purchasing down the track if there are some significant improvements, but until then, the Planet Coaster Alpha actually looks a lot better than this is in its current state, so Id suggest at least taking a peek at that.

The best way to describe it is: RCTW = SimCity 5 (a major let down). Im hoping Planet Coaster = City Skylines.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW

So here is the thing, I love this series, all the way from RCT to RCT3 and the process that this game took to get here caused me to cancel my pre-order, buy Planet Coaster and play it on release date. However after the launch I got curious and re-purchased the game and here is what I think....

NVIZZIO HAVE A LOT OF WORK TO DO!!!!

Pro's:
Well it feels like it tries to be RCT
Area themes are good

and well in my opinion that's about it for pro's

Cons:
THE COASTER BUILDER IS A LOAD OF BULL - How did you screw this up??? Press 1 and scroll mouse wheel to raise and lower, press 2 and scroll mouse wheel to tilt, press 3 and scroll mouse wheel to pitch and pressing 4 and you guessed it scroll that mouse wheel and it does something else. This is the WORST coaster builder I have used, its just so clunky and time consuming compared to, dare I say it, Planet Coaster's which they hid in Beta due to they thought it wasn't great but let me tell you it is the quickest precise builder I have used. It systems don't fully work, I struggled to get two trains running on one track, it kept failing with no information on how to fix it, the coaster preview while building is clunky, you click to build and then the preview of the next piece dissapears, it only reappears once you click and then click to build again. It's just pretty much, in my opinion, the worst coaster builder I have ever used.

THE RIDES - Okay I get it realism is in but they just don't feel real and oh no the signs, the terrible ride signs. Yes you can rename and it shows up on the sign but there is just no character to them. It feels robotic and no this wasn't a sci fi theme.

THE GRAPHICS - Just no, this is not 2016 worthy level of graphics, I can see that maybe you were trying to capture the feel of RCT3, or it's just an optimization" thing but seriously that's why the game was delayed and it STILL SUCKS.


This game could have been great
recommended: but competition in the market from Planet Coaster and even Parkitecht did not do this game well. I mean Planet Coaster literally beats it on every level
hoursPlayed: yes it has flaws but that's what development time is for

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game still has a lot of problems. At this moment it's really an early access.
There are really some good things about the game, the way you can design you're own rollercoasters looks good and is fun to play with. The paths are a lot better than in RTC3, you kan now make corners and lay them down as you like them, make them bigger or smaller.
It works and looks OK, but it does not make me really excited about the game yet.

The controls are really bad. Most is done through the keyboard, it works but the right combination of mouse and keyboard makes it really easy to control.
The mouse controls you have like zooming in with the scroll wheal is way to sensitive.
When giving it a single little scroll it goes all the way down or up. Maybe it's a setting, but I would expect this to work like it should with basic settings. I have found the side screen scrolling with the mouse, so that makes it somewhat better, but overall the controls are really not great yet.

The graphics are not great, it looks OK, but it's not the graphics you expect from a game today. Beside that it the graphical performance is not so good. Lot's of frame rate drops.

Peeps are sometimes walking of the paths trough bushes and trees and some look like there are floating over the path.

Sounds are missing from peeps when you ride allong. Sometimes when you ride allong with a rollercoaster you keep hearing the lift chain all the way in the ride.

But at the other hand I think this game can have a lot of potential, but it does have a long way to go.
If they make the graphics better and put some time in bug fixing, better controls and some more content and senarios to play it really can be a nice game to play.

I would not recommend the game yet at this moment, the main reason for this is especially the price and what you get for it at the moment.
On the other hand, if they will really make the game a lot better to play in the upcomming months with more content and features without extra costs the price is acceptable, but that's is something you will only know in time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most of the negative reviews of this game are completely unwarranted. I've been a fan of this franchise since the very first game, and this has the potential to be the best one yet, even though it does need a lot of work. Most of the people who seem to hate it either seem to ignore the fact that it's an incomplete early release, or simply didn't have the patience to actually learn how to play it. Finally, I think it does measure up to it's main competitor, Planet Coaster.

First, let me say that if you're expecting an easy-to-play, piece-by-piece builder like the previous two where everything always comes out perfectly square and symmetrical with complete ease, you're going to be disappointed. The node-based coaster builder can be tricky, and it takes some work to get parallel tracks or symmetrical scenery arrangements. However, most of the people complaining about this seem to have completely ignored the snap and grid options. Once you learn to use it, I actually find these elements superior to analogous elements in other simulators like Cities:Skylines. It does take a while to learn to and optimize the path building, scenary placement, and coaster-building features, and it's a bit more difficult to use, but the trade off in difficulty pays off with the high level of freedom you have.

Now, something very negative about this game, it is EXTREMELY buggy in its current state. It crashes a lot, the frame rate is really low, a number of the features (such as the coaster's physics engine) are woefully incomplete, and the AI in guests and maintainence needs a lot of work, but it is important to remember this is an incomplete game. It's probably more buggy than most games that are called beta or early access, but that's more the fault of Atari's marketing than the game itself. If they work out these bugs, it has the potential to be a really good game.

The best feature of the game by far is the coaster builder. Judging by other comments and You Tube videos, most of the people complaining about it seem to have absolutely no clue what they are doing and haven't even tried to learn how to use it. It is in my opinion the best coaster builder out there right now. It's less complex than No Limits, and gives you way more freedom than the builders in the first three or the current version of Planet Coaster. Granted, the physics engine is probably incomplete and what's right now there is probably a place holder (there's very little friction on coasters, the breaks are way to powerful) and there are some bugs with the coaster builder (frame rate slows way down, some features cause it to crash, and there are a number of bugs with the breaks). It's also somewhat difficult to learn how to use (though should come somewhat naturally to those familiar with No Limits), but again what you lose in easiness pays off in what you gain in freedom. Again, don't expect an easy piece-by-piece builder, but do expect to be able to build really realistic coasters. I love the mixture of node and piece-by-piece builders.

Since I also have access to the early bird version of Planet Coaster, I think it's worth doing a point-by-point comparison between the two. Granted, both games are incomplete, so all of this is subject to change, but it's worth mentioning how I think the two stack up against each other.

So far, here's what's better about RCTW:
-Better Coaster Builder with way more freedom than you have in PC, but PC's builder isn't even in alpha yet so this can change.
-Better path builder. PC's path builder is easily the worst part of the game, it's so wonky and very difficult to build decent looking paths.
-UGC. As someone who spent hours looking for and working with CS in RCT3, this is a huge plus. The integration with Steam Workshop is great, and it allows to add elements of piece-by-piece building in RCTW that aren't there yet. Also, it expands the potential for customization in the game in the future way out there.
-Better looking flat rides.
-Better camera controls. Though PC has very similar controls to RCT3, RCTW's controls are more intuitive and don't clash with other controls in the game.

Here's what's better about PC:
-Better overall graphics. Even though some elements in RCTW are more detailed, the lighting, shadows, and such in PC are way superior.
-Better sounds. Sounds like guests on coasters are having sex in RCTW, and coaster sounds in PC are more realistic. Also, it sounds a lot less cluttered.
-Better Scenery builder. Piece-by-piece building allows for a lot more freedom in building buildings and the scenery in general looks better.
-Better AI. Peeps act and move more naturally, and there are fewer bugs. It gets you to think about the layout of your park a lot more.
-Way less buggy, and better optomized overall.

Here's what's neutral/debatable between the two:
-Stalls. The Stalls in RCTW are more realistic, and the feature of walk-in resteraunts is a huge plus. But, the stalls in PC are more customizable.

-Coster stations. Like stalls, they're more realistic in RCTW, but more customizable in PC. Granted, RCTW's devs said they're planning on allowing for blank coaster stations for mor customizations in future updates.

-RCTW has more features, game modes, and such as of now but that's just where it is in its development.

Overall, I slightly prefer RCTW but that's mainly because the main reason I've ever played these games is for coaster building and, as it stands now, RCTW has more features overall, but PC just needs to catch up in development. Both have the potential to be great games.

In conclusion, do not by this game if you're looking for a completely ready-to-play, fully optimized, and easy-to-play game. It still needs a lot of work, and is difficult to learn to master all the controls. Most of the reason why people seem to hate it is a mixture of bad marketing and unrealistic expectations of how complete it would be. For casual gamers new to the genre of theme park simulators, it's definitely not worth the price. But if you truly love simulation games, and have the patience to work through the bugs and actually learn how to play, and want to support the development of a potentially good game, it's definitely worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is hugely dissapointing.

Finally another edition to the iconic loved series comes along and this is bearing in mind i played the beta weekends and felt disappointed then, it hasn't got any better.

GAMEPLAY -
Load times are somewhat slow, i run on a i7-4790k, GTX 970, 16GB RAM and just loading a blank sandbox park takes me 42 seconds, yeah not the end of the world but loading a blank park.. Lots of framerate drops too for seemingly no reason. I see no difference in the gameplay mechanics, the grid facility is pointless as it doesn't match up with anything, they say they completely overhauled the coaster builder since the beta. Well again i see no difference in the coaster builder now compared to the beta, it's really not good, it's incredibly difficuilt to get any smooth turns/curves/corners. Alot of placements of objects, scenery, paths etc. aren't 'allowed' when there is nothing blocking them from being placed. It's just frustrating, it's all these features that are the most fundamental part of the game and they still just don't work. Everything is just very tedious and frustrating to do, it should be easy! But instead, i feel it's very very poor.

GRAPHICS -
I wouldn't even go as far to say that they are OK, i understand graphics aren't everything, however after Roller Coaster Tycoon 3's release date of October 26th 2004 the graphics feel like more of a remaster apposed to up to date graphics. It just feels lazy, and it simply doesn't look refreshing or exciting. Nothing new or high tech going on here. Framerate drops all over the place even on low settings, changing graphical settings hasn't seemed to help in any scenario.

CONTENT -
Unfair to say considering it is now in early access and more content will be released, but don't expect a lot to begin with. There is barely a campaign. There are specific 'scenarios' such as 'Turn a failed park around' which are ok but not exactly a lot of thought put in here either. A sandbox mode which is great to have still so thats a positive!!

FEATURES -
Really the only noteable new good feature, is the curved paths and having the ability to not be restricted by a grid (however as previously said, neither work as you'd expect) other than that, there isn't a lot of difference. The social hub is a good idea to be able to share creations but i haven't seen it working yet so i can't comment.

OVERALL -
Bringing the franchise back again sounds like a fantastic idea, and what the developers are telling us and raising our hopes for just hasn't happened. Everything feels lazy and sloppy, just as if there is no passion put in anymore. It's such a disappointment, if you are a Roller Coaster Tycoon fan i can't imagine you are going to feel anything but disappointment which i hate to say. Once again, it's early access so there are features yet to come so this is as of now, but considering it has been delayed and now shoved in early access. Things don't look good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just don't buy this game if you're a fan of the original series.

I feel like this game is a complete letdown and I will explain why:

- First; The Coaster builder is terrible. Yes, they added the familiar piece-by-piece building that we all know form the original games. Which is fine. The spline based coaster builder is a pain in the ♥♥♥. The main issue that I have is that the piece you are forming is attached to the camera. So when I'm building a coaster, have the piece where I want it, and want to check from another angle I can't because the piece will slide along.  Furthermore, I've spend 10 minutes to tweak the brakes in order to make the coaster pass the test. I don't want to spend 10 minutes on tweaking the brakes; in real life if a coaster has it's desired speed it will open the brakes and let the train pass through. The stations are troublesome too as I can't change the length of them. So if I want to have a compact coaster I can't because the station is gicantic. Other strange things will happen to your coaster as well in freeform mode; supports where going straight through the tracks and my axes where inverted at some point so every new piece I placed was all messed up. The experience was just frustrating.

- Realism is not great too. I don't think the developers took any time watching real rides and Roller Coasters, because if they did the game would look completely different. Some rides that are included do not even exist in real life, whereas all of the rides in the previous installments did. Even more, the Roller Coasters look afwul too. They remind me of the toy Coaster Dynamix models, with the supports being constructed by plumbers. I'm a mechanical engineer myself so I know what works and what doesn't. What we're seeing in RCTW doesn't work in real life and that bothers me a lot.

- All rides look more like they belong on a carinval instead of a theme park.

- The lack of water rides. Where are the log flumes, the rapid rivers etc? I mean, come on, those are essential ride in theme parks! Why aren't these in the game?

- The path system is a mess as well. Paths won't connect to the places I want them. In the previous installments you could snap paths together to make a plaza, this isn't possible in this game either. Also the three widthts are way too limited.

- The guests look terrible. Even horror movies are less scarier than these mutants. They can't be drowned as well, but I'm not counting that.

And finally, but most important: The game is missing all the charm that the previous installments had. And I think that is the part where this game really dissapoints me most. A utter shame, luckily I can still play the old versions and I will continue to do so as this piece of empty software is not worth both my time and my attention. I was done with this game within half an hour and I believe that says enough.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAtari, Atari, Atari. What have you done to the RollerCoaster Tycoon name... How many years, and how many developers, and you come up with this? Even with your focus groups for a year you couldn't fix these bugs? Freeform path building is broken, ride animations are terribly bugged, the coaster builder is actually not very easy to use, food buildings are literally the same design as each other with a different food item on top, peeps are weird and sometimes don't show up, the prebuilt coasters are boring and look like they were designed by a child intern, and above all, the game is poorly optimized. Even on a high powered PC, the graphics are just mediocre. What I do like is the selection of facades, foliage, etc. and the financial statistics, but that does not justify a $50 purchase from anyone at this point. I thought that waiting this long meant that the game would be ready, but I was so wrong. Maybe I will purchase it again one day, but I am requesting a refund. 2.5/10

I bought this game way back in September of 2015, i was looking forward to it's release for so long. Then when it was realeased i was so excited and i couldn't wait to play it and then i seen what a crappy job they did and i couldn't believe it. (Eg: The peeps look terrible and are very glitchy, they also don't follow the path ways properly, neither does the staff.
At points the staff and guests didn't walk but they just floated around the park, the rides are very choppy and some of them don't seem fun at all.

I know it's not done yet but honestly how could they think that this was good enough to release? I have loved RCT eversince the first one came out. I played this for a few days and i finally got fed up enough to the point where i just stopped playing it. What a let down, after all of this time waiting just to end up getting a kick in the junk. I thought Atari would have more heart invested into the game than this but i guess i was wrong.

They need to give our money back and start over from scratch. I don't think i'll be getting my money back at this point but it's ok, i'm willing to accept that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am a life long RCT fan, a huge fan of the series. I have player RCT 1, 2 and 3. And I have been VERY EAGERLY looking forward to RCTW!! I pre-ordered the Deluxe Edition of the game to get the extra bits and pieces and to give some extra funds of support to Atari and Nvizzio. It was a very expensive price for a game but I thought it would be well worth it... I was wrong!

Yesterday I got the game, RCTW installed and I launched it, and within the space of ten minutes I was totally deflated by what I saw...

I work in software development. I have used BETA's to get feedback on software from BETA Testers. I have taken part in software BETA's and early access. And yes, the software is buggy and needs a bit of polish, but I am STUNNED that the state RCTW is currently in is what Atari and Nvizzio only recently classed as a nearly finished game that was getting some polish and optimisation. Are you serious!?! REALLY!!!

I know RCTW has gone through some rough patches. It's passed through the hands of a number of developers and I have backed them all. I had real admiration for Nvizzio as I saw the work they were doing and it looked great!! But I can tell you now, the RCTW game I have on my PC right now doesn't look anything like what I saw in the videos and screenshots used to promote this game. I didn't get to play the BETA back in October as I was away, so seeing RCTW today is my first real introduction to it, but what I see in RCTW today looks worse than what I saw of the BETA.

The graphics seems to have degraded completely! The peeps looks terrible!! There are animation glitches, gameplay glitches, sound glitches, and the game just doesn't grab a hold of you and make you feel good about playing it. There is no soul to the game at all. The whole atmosphere is just wrong, no, it's missing completely!!

If this was BETA 2, I would have been stunned by the poor quality of it...
If this was really early access I would have been stunned by the poor quality of it...
But the fact that Atari have said, prior to the current" early access release
date: that this game was nearly finished and it was just getting some polish and optimisation for release... WOW!! I can't believe that THIS is what Atari classify as being a polished 2016 PC game.\n\nSo I have a question... What happened...?!? Seriously
recommended: what has happened here? How can this version of RCTW that is "nearly finished and receiving some polish and optimisation" look so poor

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNot reccommending yet anyway.... this game has promise, but at this stage that is all it is... i love the RCT series and played all of them on PC since the first and put many hours in.... The major thing for me at this stage is the coaster builder, you can do anything with it which is great, but the problem is you can do anything with it and it is so hard to build anything complex or overly quick without it going wrong... you cannot delete multiple pieces of track, you have to select each one, it is pretty much impossible to build one using the track building as per RCT3, this has taken a backwards step IMHO, the people in the game are idiots, they are complaining they are hungry outside a huge selection of food shops and still complain, there is sick everywhere and no janitors ever clean it up, you cannot scale, or amend prebuilt rides or flats, the drop tower should be much higher and you should be able to amend this to suit, no monorail or trains (Yet, hopefully they will come).... I guess the main question should be what has changed since RCT3..... not a huge amount really.. yes the GFX look a bit better and the menus are different but is it really 10 years newer???? I guess the answer is no and unless they sort the coaster builder out so it makes sense and you can do what you want to do then i guess its kind of a backwards step vs RCT and when that came out.... I hope the DEV's can bring this into the 21st century as i want this to be good, but its just a bit lacking in every department.... this is an early release so i am holding out hope but i was hoping and expecting so much more..... PS if anyone can tell me how to do a straight bit of track using the builder then im all ears!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can't recommend this game at the moment. I was prepared for it to be different to the other RCT games but it's just no good.

The staff huts don't seem to have proper pathfinding for the staff so I can have a large hut with 10 janitors and the paths are absolutely filthy. I've got about 40 janitors and mechanics in a reasonably small park but rides remain unfixed for absolutely ages and the paths are rammy.

I've set the inspection times to 20 minute intervals, my rides still breakdown all the time and then remain unfixed for ages, even when right next to the mechanic hut.

I can't see any way to easily see what staff I've got and where. I placed a large entertainers hut... 1 month later  (game time obvs!) I saw 2 entertainers leave the building. And there were 6 'employed' apparently but no sign of them months later.

There's no way that I can see what excitement levels or intensity the rides I'm building have before I actually build them. I don't know whether I'm getting value for money or not as I used to use that information to determine how much I can charge for the ride etc. Also doesn't say how big the ride is going to be until you actually select it.

I was playing the campaign on frolicking forest, deleting trees and shrubs was a frickin nightmare and levelling the ground left me with several rock outcrops that wouldn't flatten so it was a little bit pointless. You should be able to delete trees and bushes by dumping a ride on top of them and all land you own should be able to be flattened easily.

I want to like this game but I don't right now. I know it's early access but it should be better than it is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is in reference to the Early Access build released March 30.

The good news first: The core engine is fairly solid, and is more than adequate to build a robust park-creation sim upon.

The bad news is that they haven't done that yet. There's very little of the Early Access build that can be considered robust. The press release for the EA build boasts 4 different themes, and tons of scenery; the '4 different themes' bit is technically correct, but only because they didn't include the word 'complete.'  The 'tons of scenery' boast is an outright fib, unless they were estimating the raw, real-world tonnage of the simulated rock formations and generic foliage that comprise the mass of your 'theming' options.

Actual theming options -- statuary, themed plants, facades, animatronics, landscape textures, etc. -- are extremely slim. As a strange contrast, there actually IS a fairly robust selection of fences and path textures, quite possibly more than were available in RCT3, so if you were hinging your plans for a dream park on pavement options, brother, this could be your train.

A building sim lives and dies by its building options, and RCTW just doesn't have them, yet. It's hard to imagine what Atari was hoping to accomplish with this EA build; while this move ostensibly beats Frontier's Planet Coaster" to the Steam marketplace
date: the lack of options can only result in unflattering comparisons and bad press.\n\nI remain optimistic that the missing theming options are forthcoming (particularly if they have any hope of properly implementing dark rides

reviewText:
Early Access Review

RCTW tries to build off the success of the first three iterations of the franchise, but fails to do so.

More than ten years ago, Frontier developed Roller Coaster Tycoon 3. It was the best theme park simulation at the time. RCTW just doesn't feel the same. As awesome as it is that there's no restrictions to building on a snap grid or straight angle, the mechanics of the coaster builder are very flawed. What would take you 10 minutes in RCT3 to build will take you over an hour to build in RCTW. Additionally, RCTW coaster builder is so poor that after you're done, you'll be required to tweak for another 30 minutes, most likely.

Animations of peeps are incomprehensible. They are extremely cartoonish and stick out like a sore thumb. Staff is flawed as a system (build a small building to take up park space) and they are not efficient and will require many patches to get it right.

Yes, this is an Early Access, but the game is broken. Badly. It looks bad, it plays bad, and overall, you don't have much fun as you play. It just doesn't have a flow like the previous titles. I spent 2 hours playing and felt like I accomplished nothing. Management needs an overhaul. Coaster builder needs fixing. Animations need to be re-done and a physics engine needs to be reworked.

I look to Planet Coaster (Frontier is developing it) for the theme park simulation being done right.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought RCTW simply to see if it's truly as bad as everyone says. The answer is yes. Yes, it really is that bad.

Grid snapping doesn't snap things straight - or even to the gridlines, for that matter.
Grid snapping snaps things so they overlap others so they cannot be placed.
Paths randomly snap diaginally to random points and won't let you simply make them straight.
Animation is insanely jerky. When people walk, it's like watching a stop-action animation. And it's intentional.
The people just don't look fun / entertaining anymore. It's like watching a bunch of manniquins. Dead inside.
Can't choose where to place entrances or exits to rides, so you can't place rides where you want - you have to place them where they fit. This means you are going to have paths that wrap clear around rides in the most ridiculous ways, just so guests can reach the entrances.
Can't place shops up against paths. You have to place the back of the shop against the path (assuming the grid will snap correctly), then wrap the path around to the front of the shop. Or place the shop in the middle of the grass, and draw a path to the front of the shop.
Menu navigation pop-ups are so huge, the words hover over your selections, so you can't see what you're clicking on unless you move your mouse completely out of the way.
Seriously, just WTF all around.
These guys completely botched this game, and destroyed the RCT franchise. It's absolutely nothing like the originals in all the worst ways. I'm just beside myself right now. I don't understand how this is possible. Even for early access, this is a complete disaster.

RIP RCT.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This Game does not live up to its promise. They pushed it back and back since they cannot meet the deadlines apparently. Then they have applied the smart marketing trick of making it early access: meaning no money left but they desperately need it. Which would be ok I guess BUT:

There is the tiny problem of an important feature missing: stacking scenery to build buildings etc. Their response: I could go into a 3D software and create my own models of scenery but in game I cannot because it would be too complicated. So a major NO! Rides cannot be customised at all (except for colors and a couple of trees) and thus it feels like a smartphone game rather than a real RollerCoaster Tycoon (even when just considering the graphics). Maybe they will activate that feature in an in app purchase way or add high resolution textures as a DLC. But they stated that they will add rides and scenery and tweek the physics, but that the basics of the mechanics are pretty much done.

If you are ok with all of these limitations, I can recommend you the game because it does exactly what you expect. If you don't, then keep far, far away from this game!

Finally, on a personal side, due to this clever" marketing trick and these false promises

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI know this is an early release version of the game - but honestly, it is even light years behind the previous instalment in the series, RCT3, in terms of graphics and game physics. In terms of usability, it is far too complex in places that could be a lot more simple, too, and for a game that I've wanted since I was about fifteen, this has really let me down. If this was £10, then I would say it was worth the expenditure. But this much money? I definitely would not recommend it. I have honestly never felt this let down by a video game in the past, and I can see a lot of people jumping to this game's direct rival - coaster planet - Upon its release. This is the kind of quality that I would expect from a tablet game. I'll check back in the future and see if RCT can revive my faith in the series, but as of now, it's looking extremely unlikely. Farewell, RCT, and farewell my hard earned £30. You will be missed!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In short, the game is still broken from every point of view, and looks worse compared to an alpha version of its competitor, Planet Coaster.

I've been playing this game for some time now and on the positive side, it IS addicting to play the game. It's great to finally have a follow up in the Rollercoaster Tycoon franshice and for now i'm happy its here.

Some complain about graphics, but I don't really mind looking at what amount of details I can put into the park and how large the park can get. The cartoony still looks great in this game and scrolling down to human level is beautiful in my opinion. I really want to give kudos for the devs for not resizing the levels into a Sim City disasteres small squares.

But there is were it stops. Looking back to the beta, and now the Early Access (not release) no progress has been made at all. Building coasters is still as broken as it was in the beta. Random impossible twists are added as soon as you place a new piece that looked perfectly fine before placing it. And for some reason, a simple circle coaster is good enough to make everyone vomit and not liking your track. The only thing they fixed since the beta, is that they blame the user for not making a good coaster. THAT IS NOT FIXING THE BUG!

The game is this bad, that even connecting two paths that run side by side is nearly impossible to do. It just doesn't connect! How can this problem still be in the game! Even when it starts to work, its a big hassle to make it do what you want to do because it just doesn't do what you want.

In case you're into making the park look nice with a lot of small details and such. You're out of luck with this game. For example, adding benches or lights is a BIG PROBLEM. It's really incosistent and just doesn't allow you to create something nice. The game is keep saying you can't place an item there, when it is able to do it on the other side at exactly the same place and conditions.

AI is also broken. People are 100% hungry, and walk like they really are hungry. But even with a street full of different shops to eat (with prices at $0, and food quality high) they won't eat. The cleanup crew randomly walks through everything and everyway, but barelly cleans something up. I've got over 500 people hired, and it's still a big mess. They even walk over the vomit or trash not doing anything.

I even got a coaster that went broken as soon as I opened it. Even over 500 mechanics, even a few buildings next to that coaster wasn't going to help me having it fixed. And fixing it manually isn't possible. So I had to redo the coaster. Great!

The other big promise is that you can use User Generated Content. Thats great, but they have no search or filter functionality. No sorting, nothing. It's as bare as it can get. And even than... even than, they can make it crash the game almost everytime you try using it. Losing your game process.

Thats anothing thing. In what age are we living in? 1995? Are we still getting Oops I forgot to save

Early Access Review

I have been a fan of the previous three instances of Rollercoaster Tycoon, but this new one... well, it is bad in almost everything.
Lets start with ride/road placement. It is almost impossible to place a ride or shop on an existing road. It just does not work! you have to delete the road, place the ride, and redo the road. And it is hard to get nice grids...
The next biggy is the graphics. Nowadays, I expect a photorealistic rendition of the park, but it looks more like a bad video game out of year 2000... I mean, even the older RCTs had better graphics (if not really 3D graphics, but that is beside the point).
The only good thing that I can say about the game is the new freeform functions, but that is about it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far I'm not really seeing anything to noteable. Considering that I have a computer that can barely run it is also a fatctor. By the specs I clearly should not be able to. On that note heres an actual review.

My pros:
Has basic needs to fufill tycooning needs.
Build on a freeform track system.
Testing tells you where ride fails.
The money to buy things seems okay(pricing of staff and general buildings)

Cons:
Despide the limit of offered coasters and flat rides you can still do a bit more with community driven items.
Breaks and lifts are finicky.
Ghoast screams and yells.
Snapping buidlings to paths doesn't seem to want to work for me. Hence the buidling of stringy paths in some of my RTCW screen shots.
While it warns you were it fails, it'll take about a whole session of playing to correct and make the ride look good.
Peps still wont track right.(at least for me)
Sectioning off parts of the coaster to make shorter sessions of breaks and lifts, as well as doing the same to adjust speed or force is actually really frusrating becuase you can acidently move the track around becuase it'll want to edit that part of the track.

If your looking for a fufilling sandbox game that makes you work for profits, this game might be for you, however the bugs may very much outweigh the need or want for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I feel like this early access release was a valiant effort on Atari's part to fix all the problems that were definitely evident in the first beta. However as I have come to play this early access now, some of the problems within the coaster design and potential layout of an entire theme park have almost become worse.

In the first beta of this game I knew the coaster builder needed quite a bit of work done, I did slowly start to get used to parts of it while I was building and managed to get a few functioning coasters going in my park. This new release of the coaster builder places a very opaque sphere where your cursor is to build the next piece, but it is very hard to adjust and manover the placements. It also becomes very jumpy when trying to edit previously added parts to the coaster. Also there is no way to turn it off if you just want to go by segments which I felt was a good addition they said they were going to add in. I would be much happier if I had a button to manually jump between the two, ironically it would make building a coaster much more seamless.

The other big issue I have is that we no longer have the options to place entrances and exits, I'm not sure if this will be adjusted before release but it removes a degree of customization out of theme park building which we have always had in the RCT series.

I also find the pathing system a little too jumpy. Even the old RCT 1 and RCT 2 pathing was better.

The benefit to the game that I find is finally the implementation of buildings for mechanics and janitors, instead of just dropping them in the game like the old days.

It will be interesting to see how much they need to radically change when they exit out of this early access program. I may pop on occasionally over the next little while to see if they take in anymore of what the community is describing as flaws to the game. And if they are successful, I could definitely see myself spending a good amount of time on this game much like my oodles of time spent on the previous games and change this review to a positive.

I guess time will tell.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs someone who has been defending RCT with how slow they have been releasing this game, I am compeltely disappointed in the Early Access. First of all the tutorial is a FAQ of text. Altering the terrain really tests your patience with such a tiny brush size and no strength option. You cannot flatten terrain with trees and bushes, however to delete them you have to click on every single bush and tree (which the majority of the time the cursor doesn't sync to what you're trying to delete) - there is no drag a box to delete or brush tool deletion. There is also no undo button, which is extremely handy in building sim games. Laying pavements are frustrating when there is no freetool option and the grid tool is buggy. Camera controls are very limited to WASD to move the camera and scroll wheel adjusts zoom and angle. Basically, TLDR: Worst than previous RCT (buy RCT3) and it's a terrible Early Access Game, save your money until proper release and see what everyone says about improvement/ save for Planet Coaster which looks epic.
