reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, where should I even start? FIrst of all I played what they called the 'beta' back in november which was a huge disappointment. I couldn't even start the game or it would crash and if it did start it would crash after a few minutes of play time.

Now, that is the only possitive thing I could say about this game atm; it didn't crashed (at least for me). Besides that this is the most expensive early access game I have ever seen and bought and also the most awfull one.

The graphics look like crap. When you zoom out you will notice a square box which is around half of the size of the screen in which all the graphics are rendered, and outside of this box everything looks different/vague. Also the peeps are very pixely and walk like a bunch of idiots.

The interface is just as annoying and malfunctioning as in the 'beta'. Buttons and sliders that won't work and even in the graphics tab it's hard to get to 2560x1440 because it's outside of the settings box.

Both the road builder as the coaster builder are also buggy as hell as, for instance, it is nearly impossible to connect a waiting line and a exit nicely next to eachother to your main path.

I would understand if you would say 'Hey, why be so hard on the devs this is an early access game!', but this 1.2GB game they delivered to us all for $45 doesn't even deserve to be called a beta, let alone be called an early access. I believe the devs should be ashamed of the state this game is in and how little they seemed to have learned from the 'pre-pre-alpha' last november. At least I'm done with this game and getting my refund to save the money for a game that is worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not Early Access - it is a shame.

I pre-ordered the game back in october 2015 and expected to get a full game in december 2015 and access to 2 beta-weekends. Now, 4 month after the planned release an only one beta-weekend later they sell this title as early access. At first they must have known in the beginning of december that they wont release the game in 2015, the beta was terrible. Sadly there are almost no noticable improvements over the beta. The performance is bad, graphics are bad, the UI looks like it was made in 5 minutes with MS Paint and the overall content is underwhelming and unpolished. The path system is unintuitive, just like the coaster builder. The animations are horrible, Peeps in RCT3 still have more beauty to them than in this so called game. I did not test the economy in this title - I just coul not force me to play this game longer than I did. It is just terrible.

Atari lied several times. It is ashame what they did to their customers, fans and the RCT franchise.
Shame on Atari - R.I.P RollerCoaster Tycoon

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Comparing development (continuously updated review)
As most people tend to compare quasi-similar games to each other, perhaps it's best to provide a review that does so without any bias or prejudice, as the vast majority of reviews lack the most important elements these should have: honesty and objectivity. So let's get to it.

Both Rollercoaster Tycoon World (RCTW) and Planet Coaster (PC) are halfway through their alpha stages (or beta, the difference in meaning has become insignificant over the last years) and both games show great promises and annoying bugs at the same time, which is completely normal for any game under development of course. PC has just seen the release of its second alpha (the second out of three) and RCTW has had major and minor updates over the last two months, since it has entered early access on Steam. Let's start with pointing out what PC delivers and lacks at this point in time.

PC is a game which features a more or less cartoonic graphic style and is mainly focused on building custom scenery and constructions by using various structural elements and decorative items. This way no two parks will look the same and the possibilities are numerous (not endless, as that's technically impossible), especially with the latest update in which it has been made a lot easier to fine tune the movement of objects on multiple axes. The amount of different structural elements to obtain such a desired beautiful park is quite decent, although it remains to be seen how many will still be added in the future before its final release in autumn 2016, as the amount of newly added objects was amazing during the first alpha, but rather disappointing in the second. Another main focus within the game is the animations of the park guests. These are far from optimal at this point, but it's obvious to see that the creators tend to accomplish guests who accurately reflect their mood, appear to be responsive to their environment (including the rides of course) and behave as natural as possible. This feature still needs development, but it's too soon to tell whether they succeeded or failed, as the park management (which includes this feature as far as I'm concerned) will be released in the third alpha stage next summer, so I will leave this part of the consideration for now. Moving on to the flat rides it seems the developers were bereft of any resourcefulness, as most rides are mere copies of previous rollercoaster tycoon games (RCT 1, 2 and 3) and in the second alpha they even added a second Ferris' Wheel, whereas one would have been more than enough (and don't forget that another flat ride - the Whirley Rig - is also a Ferris' wheel to tell the truth). Is it really that hard to come up with rides that are actually different from predecessors and at least somewhat different from other rides? Let me give you another example: the newly added Insanity ride is just a copy from previous rollercoaster tycoon games and it's also remarkably similar to the Hammer Swing. Why don't they add rides which they've actually come up themselves instead of merely copying others and/or existing rides (just compare the Brain Surge from Nickelodeon Universe to the Psychola ride in the game). To be fair, the same mistake was made with the development of RCTW, as they added two slides (whereas one would have been more than sufficient) and they failed to provide rides which are different and interesting enough from my perspective, just as the developers of PC did. The number of flatrides is still quite low within both games, but I'm sure this will improve on both fronts. Finally, let's move on to my biggest disappointment of PC: the coaster builder. It contains some nice features, such as being able to change colours of the tracks and the supports (although the colours of the carts can't be changed for some unknown reason) and there's a good amount and variety of coaster types, but the building itself is downright frustrating and tedious, as you constantly have to move the cursor from the screen to the interface at the bottom of the screen and back again to build track sections. The building process is also rigid and doesn't feel natural due to a lack of flexibility and a poorly designed interface. This feature has barely been improved upon since the release of Rollercoaster Tycoon 3 in 2004, which is clearly an impairment in this game. The second alpha delivered us the finished coaster builder according to the developers, so apparently they deem it to be completed.

Let's now move on to RCTW. This game features a style similar to parks like Six Flags or Hersheypark (as opposed to PC which is more in the direction of Disneyland or Disney World) and is mainly focused on the coaster builder, although various flatrides and scenery items have been included of course. The coaster builder is not perfect (which will be improved in upcoming updates), but building coasters has quite a natural and flexible feel to it, does possess a good interface to make use of all the different functions the spline based building tool has to offer and provides the option to change colours as well. This feature has clearly been improved upon since its last installment of 2004, whereas PC failed to do this. On the other hand, the flexibility and possibilities PC offers for scenery items and custom constructions are not included in RCTW, as the latter does provide a freeform placement system, but is not aimed at allowing players to make their own buildings within the game at this point in time. This feature will be added to the game later on, probably once the game is pulled out of Early Access, which will happen given the amount of regular updates since its release (although many claimed it never would). Moreover, the animation of the peeps (park guests) is fairly poor in RCTW in comparison to PC. They behave and move unnaturally and need quite a few improvements, but the developers are still working on this. My aforementioned criticism on the flatrides also applies to RCTW. Several other missing features are more striking in both games, however, as both games don't include water, dark or transport rides (although both the developing teams promised to add these to the final product of games) and both games don't contain any kind of weather system or simulation (this feature has been promised for RCTW, but not for PC at the moment).

So, which game would I recommend to you ? Both, as long as the promises that have been made regarding both games are met. Which game should you buy? That's up to you (I bought both games). To me it all comes down to preferences. Do you prefer a theme park builder which mainly focuses on beautiful scenery items and custom buildings just like Disney World, then go for Planet Coaster. If the building of amazing coasters and parks such as Six Flags is more to your liking, then go for Rollercoaster Tycoon World. I truly believe that both games are on the same level at this point in time, as both contain both good and bad features and both offer promises and bugs, which is utterly normal for games under development (as I already said). Let's hope that we will have two good theme park building games coming out at the end of this year.

Despite all of the negative reviews, this game really isn't that terrible. Although there are some annoying bugs and some funky features, none of them are really game destroying. There's been a lot of hate about things not snapping correctly, or things not snapping at all, and although it is a bit annoying, there's really easy ways to work around it. So yes, it is buggy, it still has many problems, but in reality, none of these are truely game destroying bugs. Me and my girlfriend think this game is absolutely amazing and look forward to playing another 6 hours tomorrow. Let's just hope for some basic fixes too, and I'm sure this game will pull through, just like the others did! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have updated this review with content relating to the Early Access release. It is following the beta weekend review.

BETA WEEKEND 1What do I think of Roller Coaster Tycoon World? I was hoping it would be great and wow everyone, but this game is never going to be ready by the posted release date, if the roller coaster module is anything to go by. In attempting to build a wooden roller coaster (simple enough, right?) I never once was able to complete a circuit with the train. The physics engine in this is horrible, and if I try to make a tight turn with banking, the only think i ever see is 'SLOPE TOO STEEP'. I think I hate this game. Absolutely hate it. I know the devs are desparate to make some money on this, but this game is not okay. Unless the second beta is better, I'm going to be one of many thousands who return their pre-release orders.

SO MANY DERAILMENTS!!! (literaly)

Early Access: Day 1In my first experience with the now long-term beta of this game, I must say it's really in need of optimizations. As of right now, this game is still not ready for a full release (thank goodness they went EA if they HAD to release it now, but they could have waited...). So, how has the fourth installment of the Roller Coaster Tycoon franchise fared? Not as well as I'd hoped.

The Graphics
They're not bad, but they're not good either. Visually, they're very pleasing. However, the peeps are flat skins (clothing is not a separate layer) which is disillusioning. In addition, the feel of the ride textures leave the tiniest bit of nagging that something's missing. Overall, though, the graphics are actually very good to look at. BUT, good luck getting a good framerate even with a Titan. The game set my settings on high and I run a GTX 970. There is 1 setting above that which a single GTX 980 or Titan should be capable of running at 60 fps. For the graphics, to be honest, I'm surprised my computer couldn't run 60 fps.
There is a plus, though. Since the devs know framerate is bad, they went and added a tickbox that reduces the graphics demand in favor of a more playable framerate, so that you almost never dip below 20 fps. Almost. When building new things in a park that already is a bit crowded, you can dip down all the way to the 1-3 fps region.

Gameplay
Well, it definitely feels like a more open and controllable world than previous RCT games. Because nothing is stuck to the grid, a whole new variety of layout options become available. That said, because of the size of the park, a whole lot of creativity has been thrown out the window. It would take dozens of this park to fill the parks you built in RCT 1-3. This park is only big enough to house 1 large coaster or 2 smaller ones (what the ♥♥♥♥, right?), in addition to your arsenal of small rides needed to keep the less extreme peeps happy. Speaking of those peeps, the way they scream when on a ride is all at once, so you just have an occasional scream that hurts your ears instead of constant enjoyment from your peeps.

Building Tools
The path and stall building tools are fairly intuitive. With the freeform option, you draw in any direction you like. With the grid turned on, you can keep everything aligned to a coordinate system (perpendicular and parallel to the park entrance, mind you). With snap turned on (this will turn off grid, and vice versa), you can place your paths at 90 degree angles to each other, even if they're not on the grid angle. It also allows for a few other things, like placing stalls directly onto existing paths, and more controllably placing trees and other objects adjacent to paths. All in all, having the three building modes is very useful, but I would like a localized grid aligned with a path I just drew if I had both grid and snap enabled. That would be very useful.

Specific Building Tools:
The path building tool - While this tool is great for building paths on the ground, you don't have nearly enough control with the path height. The only interval for heigh is 7 feet, which is too much, especially given the small spacing the grid has.
The Flat Ride Building Tool - Well, it's just placement and angle rotation. On the other hand, unlike in previous RCT games, you can't choose the locations for the entrance and exit to the ride, which was part of how we were able to tightly pack tons of rides into a small space in the last games. And given how much smaller this game's parks are, we really need as much control of the arrangement as possible.
Roller Coaster Building Tool - The roller coaster building tool really isn't bad anymore. Unlike in the beta weekend, coasters no longer crash for no reason, and the tool is relatively intuitive. That said, the station platforms are very sparse in selection and have MASSIVE footprints. There's already a significant queue and a horrendously long exit walk for every single station platform. And you can't pick where the entrance and/or exit come from, or the direction of the train. Also, track banking doesn't actually listen to what you say. For example, if I have a tight turn on an incline with steep banking, the track is actually rendered as flat and level. Decrease the banking, and the track banks outward (why?). Most of the time, using the building tools is fairly intutive. You have pre-built segments that you can adjust the scale of, or you can click on the ground away from nodes and build your own track. Working with nodes is intutive, but not getting to node mode. If you make a mistake, I have no clue how to abort the new piece without quitting the editor entirely. But on the plus side, you can create and delete nodes in the middle of the track without disconnecting it all. Overall, it still needs a bit of work, but coasters don't crash for no reason, and using it is largely intutive.

ConclusionThis game is labeled appropriately as something that's in Early Access. It's glitchy somewhat, and some of the controls don't feel quite finished. That said, there are other problems with this game. Flat rides don't have configurable exits, roller coaster stations are massive and just as unconfigurable (and lacking in variety), and the park size is WAY TOO ♥♥♥♥ING TINY! Will Atari and Nvizzio Creations pull it all together? Maybe. I wouldn't put any money on it happening this year. I would LOVE for them to pull it together and give us something amazing as though they've been holding out, but it really doesn't seem like RCT is on top any more. Planet Coaster, even being in alpha, is already incredibly customizable, allowing for every building to be custom made, a huge park size, and lots more detail. On top of that they're the brains behind RCT3 who did a very good job for the first 3D implementation of the series(no offense, Nvizzio). I expect a lot more from Planet Coaster in the near and far future than I do from Roller Coaster Tycoon World. For now, I'm getting my refund.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, before I start with my review, I want to clear up one thing that many people who gave this game a negative view missed: YOU CAN EXTEND THE SIZE OF YOUR PARK IN THE SAME FASHION AS YOU CAN EXTEND YOUR CITY IN CITIES SKYLINES. Now that's all cleared up, lets continue.

Okay, so there's only 2 problems I have found so far; 1: The game isn't fantastically optimised, but is still more than playable at medium settings. 2: The roller coaster manual builder is quite tricky to get the hang of initally (however after a couple of goes, it's really easy to understand). Aside from that, the game is absolutely amazing, I've been on it for 4 hours straight so far and I'm loving every minute of it, I can't wait to see what workshop content will bring and how much the game will improve over time! So far it gets a 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wow, talk about bandwagon! Having played both Planet Coaster and RCTW, I really cannot understand how so many have the gift of projecting what one game will become and the other won't. Admirable! I certainly don't have that divine ability of reading into the future. In all honesty, they are both in early development and one has as much potential as the other. I must say that RCTW has absolutely delivered what they have announced for this milestone, and it's not bad considering this stage of development. In other words, they have been true to their word and that's a plus in Early Access. Everything depends on how it will evolve from here on (and this goes for both games). Lots can still be done and devs have a good blueprint with which to work.

Performance and stability must be enhanced. AI and balancing (namely for the coaster testing  indices, finances and management) need adjusting. Peeps need more personality, humor, player interaction, and better graphics/animation. UI could also use polishing. The rest is added content and more options. All these points have been addressed since this first Early Access release. Despite all this, for me the game is playable and fun. A handful of coasters, stalls, services, management and a good sized surface area (you can unlock areas around your initial park land) are there to play around with. Only the future will tell if RCTW or PC win the race. At this point 6/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everyone in my park disappeared and then I got 500 people rushing through the entrance. Now i'm rich.

Serious review:
This game doesn't deserve all of the hate it recieves. It's not a bad game, it's enjoyable but not perfect.

Pros:
- Better rollercoaster creator than RCT3
- Menus are simple and easy to navigate
- Enjoyable

Cons:
- Poorly optimised
- Graphics are quite bad. This may be a pro eventually as in the latest update they improved the graphics.
- Limited customization options.
- Crashes often - If you buy this, save your park every 5-10 minutes so you don't lose your progress.
- The price is too high for an early access game.

- Bugs. Bugs everywhere. So far i've come across at least 15 bugs. Some are amazing, some are terrible. Here's a few bugs i've come across so far.
. Mechanics ignore my broken rides.
. Everyone in the park disappearing and then re-entering the park.
. Can't disable heat maps".
. People get stuck in the floor. This happened to my mechanic
date: a few of my janitors and even some of the "peeps".\n\nYes
recommended: Planet Coaster IS better than this game. Yes
hoursPlayed: it will likely always be better than this game. BUT

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So what is there to say about RCTW, right now the game is in early access and I cannot at this moment recommend the game, there are to many bugs, to many things that plain dont work and seems to be too much reliance on UGC. The problem is and its the biggest problem this game has to face it is widely hated there are more people playing RCT3 than this, this means less people making ugc and less people there to entice Atari/Nvizzio to continue supporting the game.

If I really had to put a value on the game I'd say $10 - $15 so if you can pick it up in a sale for that amount I recommend you do. As I have said this is in early access with the promise of it being finished incl. Peice by peice builder, water rides, transport rides, etc..

I will continue to update this review as long as Atari keep updating the game and if they achieve all their promises this will surely be a game I recommend. Just not yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite the fact that i'm not playing sandboxes like this one much, i found it very enjoyable and easy to start: controls are pretty easy, and if you ignore micromanagement of the rides it doesnt affect gameplay much, so you can just build stuff and enjoy hundreds of people filling your park :) Note for all the oldschool tycoon lovers reading this review - i was not playing any of the other rollercoaster tycoon games before.

+Tons of different rides - extreme or for all ages
+Steam workshop included so expect a lot of custom content
+Very easy to use everything after like 5 minutes from the start of the game for casual gamers
+Rides looks great :)
+I found building rides and connecting everything to everything pretty easy so that's nice :)
+This game has a lot of microcontrols for your rides, some kind of economics even people reviews, so i think for hardcore park simulator lovers this game is cool too.
-Human models and walk animation looks not very nice yet :)
And yeh, this is EARLY access review - when i loaded the game 1st time - half of the quest texts were like XXXXX XXXX A W S D XXXXXX - after support contact they released patch for the text the day later :) So most of the problems you may face should be fixed pretty quick i guess.

About of what i read in other people negative reviews:
- people say this game loads zillion hours and then crashes - so far i played something around like 10 hours and got no crashes at all - loadtime is like a minute or two for the level - for an early access game i think that's okay, specially if you take into account that after you load into the level there is no additional load times :)

-people say that this game is like 2fps - i have pretty average PC and at the graphic settings set mostly to max i had okay fps, i dont know what you have to do to have something like 5 fps here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay so I have been a huge fan of the RCT games since the launch of the first one.  That being said, I know there are a lot of things that are still sketchy with RCTW.  I was not fortunate enough to have been able to play this during Beta.  However, I wish people would not be so impatient and give it a chance.  I realize RCTW was in the works for a VERY long time and I was one of the people who was very much looking forward to its release.  I think for an Early Access game, it's quite good!  Some of the best games I have played have been Early Access games and while they were a bit low grade at their release, they are absolutely amazing now!  I believe RCTW has more than enough potential to be one of those games.  The devs did state that some things were limited due to the fact that it is Early Access and that they are still putting work into it.  There are definitely some graphical issues that need to be worked through and I would like to see the ability to change the colors of rides and incorporate our own music.  I can also see the some minor glitches in free form tracks and paths where it is difficult to create the exact shape that you want.  However, I feel that overall, it is a wonderful game!  I am really shocked at all the negative Early Access feedback.  It's EARLY ACCESS!  Meaning.....the devs want to know what the community wants to see done to create a better gaming experience.  They don't want a bunch of nasty comments about how their product was a flop and you should just go play some other rollercoaster game.  That is not at all constructive.

Anyway, yes, I would highly recommend this game and if you go into it with an open mind, looking at its future potential and not its current failures, then I think you will have a lot of fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Confused by some of the reviews on here.  There are top rated reviews that have nothing about the actual game, so I figured I would write my own.

My first thoughts 7+ hours into playing this early access build of RCTW are that I am rather enjoying it and cannot wait to see what the devs add on! Here are the pros and what needs work through early access, I'd rather not consider them cons yet as they can be fixed.

PROS:Once you spend some time going through the tutorial, building becomes easier and easier.  I had a few issues at first jumping in, but once I took the time to go through the tutorial, most, if not all of my issues were solved and made easier.
The social hub is a nice feature and easy to share blueprints for coasters.  My girlfriend is far better at building coasters than I, and I was able to grab her builds from here.  There were also others in the larger community that caught my eye.  Plenty of talented people out there and awesome to be able to use their coasters.
Scenario modes are awesome! I like the variety of different problems the player has to solve in the different scenario options.
The U.I. is nice throughout and clean!  Always know where to click for what I want.  No confusion even from when I first started.
Game ran well on my Laptop which has a tendency to overheat with most games.  I see people listing better specs than I, but claiming their performance was poor.  Perhaps they should adjust their settings, because I'm wondering how in the world they had bad performance.  There is an occaisonal fps drop, but it was rare.  Probably something that will eventually be optimized by the developers completely.  No where near unplayable as some of these reviews would have you believe.  Trust me, I'm on my laptop. It's fine!
Good amount of pre-built coasters and rides.  I expected the early access title would have less, but there is plenty to choose from.  That isn't counting the social hub and custom builds.
Options were good.  Can adjust various audio levels, graphics,etc.  There are even options to favor fps over graphics if you should need that for your set-up.
Notifications can act as a to-do" list that you can easily clear or X out one by one.  It let me know when there was something I could be doing better in my park.WHAT COULD BE FIXED IN EARLY ACCESS:like with most early access titles
date: you can expect some bugs.  The main ones I ran into were peeps sliding rather than walking on occaison.  Peeps in general could use more work.  They would have strange graphical glitches within the riding cameras on most rides.\nSetting theme music on rides could sometimes overlap with other rides' music and create messy music.  I guess in a way it makes sense
recommended:
but I wish this was more seamless.
Nausea levels could be tweaked on the peeps.
Some odd instances where rides or peeps & staff will stop working for a moment.  Fixes itself within a minute or so.
Overall
hoursPlayed: I would recommend RCTW.  I enjoyed the previous titles
voteText: and this one is fun and easy to jump right into.  Though in early access

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Loading in the game is terrible. It SEEMS to lock up when trying to load anything.  BUT if you play a video on youtube in the background or have anything else that is constantly moving the cpu forward then the game loads and runs like a dream.

Paths can be better. It seems that they are too clunky. I want square paths as a design.  Gaining money seems slow too. The alert system is in your face all the time. Slow it down a bit or make the notification smaller.  Let us set an unspecified chain speed. Or lets us hire more than 3 maintence at the start. Even when i had minimal coasters they couldnt keep up with puke. Area to build park should be 3-5 times larger to start with. One time coaster takes up a third of the map. paths take up another....soooo stalls and crap for the other third and you are kinda maxed out.

I want a highlight delete tool. A highlight terrain modifier for flat options.

Need way more graphics options.  Need a way to set view distance and different shadow qualities.  Will be updating as i see what else.

Early access is nice...But the game wasnt even close to done.   Maybe at a beta standpoint.  NEEDS some work with everything. Maybe make it clear that you are going to be spending quite some time on the game. because everyone thinks that you guys might cut and run. They want assurance They want to know that you guys are making the game becasue you are fans too and are not there becasue you have to be. That has to come across. More nuance is needed in telling people what you are trying to do. Not just we are gonna do this Thank you.

Well, a lot of people can't read and are expecting a finished game with now flaws despite it says EARLY ACCESS which is the steam intern description for beta/alpha/whatever.
Granted, the devs are way beyond their original time schedule, but I highley doubt they were lazy and enjoying their time. You know, at the end of the day, they need the money earned by a good release.
Currently the devs are really hardworking, listening to the community and their ideas/whishes/critiques and updating the game quite frequently. So in the end I look forward to the finished game.

45$ may be a bit much for a game, that's not ready yet but -again- the game was scheduled to be ready for a while now and the devs can not simply offer the game for less after many people preordered the game for more. And in the end, the devs are humans with families, you know ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS REVIEW WILL BE UPDATED AS THE GAME DEVELOPS.
*****************************************************************

I suppose to start with I will honestly say I am LOVING this game. So many people forget or don't realise that Nvizzio have only been working on this for about 18 months or so, proir to this 2 others had tried and failed, so there was and still is a LOT of work to be done before the masses get a finished product. This isn't something that will happen quickly either.
At the moment it needs a speccy PC to run too, as it uses rather a lot of memory at the moment. Some users report upto 8Gb of RAM being used by just this game alone. Yes there are a lot of features this game doesn't have yet but these things will come, in time. And Devs are listening to the community feedback and more importantly, doing something about the problems being reported. They are doing Bi-weekly updates on the game, with a live stream to showcase the update content just a few days prior to each one. They too, like us want this game to be the awesome game we all know it can be. I am hopefull they can pull this off and will stick with it all the way through development.

So, to recap.
In my honest opinion its a good game. Yes it has quirks at the moment and there's a few glitch's here and there and the massive memory usage. But I am enjoying it and creating some wonderfull parks with some awesome coasters. I would recommend to others to play, but bare in mind this game has a long way to go and its not perfect at the moment. This is still an Early Access game.

reviewText: I was looking forward to a new RCT for YEARS, which is why this game is such a disappointment. It looks really pretty but that's really all it seems to have to offer. As many others who played the first beta"-weekend says: the coaster editor is a mess. It's hard to use
date: making cool functional roller-coasters is impossible
recommended: nothing really works and building is no fun at all. I really like the concept of spline based building but right now I prefer the old style building as that was FUN.\n\nEven if you look past all the bugs that makes your game crash and the loading times that take forever it's still way behind it's predecessors. And calling this weekend a "beta" weekend is a bit of a joke as well
hoursPlayed:
as the game feels more like an alpha or even pre-alpha game looking at it's current near unplayable condition.

reviewText:
Although RollerCoaster Tycoon is one of my favorite game franchies, this latest incarnation has me worried. I'm unimpressed with the pre-order Beta weekend. The game seems far from finished (although due to be released in a little over a month),

The game ran very slowly on my machine (8gb ram), though I was one of the fortunate ones that didn't have continuous crashing problems. The beta was limited to a very small portion of the game content and limited to two weekends of play between now and release. Overall the user interface felt laggy and clunky. The coaster builder was interesting but riddled with bugs and physics issues. Building a complete coaster that wasn't simply a lift, drop and circle back to the station was almost constantly met with incredible frustration. (And I'm not new to the genre, I still play RCT3 and building coasters is my favorite aspect of the game)

I am quite surprised by this beta release. I expected a nearly completed game, a smooth and lag free engine and an exciting preview of what awaited the final release. Instead it was an unfnished  mess of problems that felt like a very limited alpha test. I have requested a refund and will wait to see what the reviews are like after the game releases in December before deciding to purchase or not.

Early Access Review

Here are things that sucks about RCTW early access:

*You can't right click to move, only use WASD or arrow keys to move.
*When you tried to build paths, they will auto connect to the closest path.
*Game crashed when I change the graphics settings

Please WAIT until Atari fixes these problems. If the final release is worst, then I am DEFINITLY getting Planet Coaster.

I've been a fan of RCT since the original RCT I was 2 in 2001. One of my all time favorites was RollerCoaster Tycoon 2 because the game supports mods like Amazing Earl's rides like the swimming pool. I was also DISAPPOINTED with RCT4M because the game was like Farmville and had microtransactions to the game and RCT3D because of park limits in-game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a RCT fan, I was so excited to play this. I played all of the previous titles of the series and loved every second of them. But when I started to play this, I felt so disappointed.

I have a GTX 980. Why am I getting such low framerates with graphics that are so blurry? Take the peeps and workers for example; their textures are pretty hideous. The flat rides flooring doesn’t even match my current path designs. RCT3 managed to do this so why can’t this?

I was so excited for the scenarios and when I played them, it wasn’t enjoyable compared to how the scenarios worked in the previous titles. In RCT3 for example; had custom entrances, descriptive objectives on a simple UI objective board. But in this game, every scenario has the same entrance on all three levels with only a terrain change and has simple objectives with ugly white UI. I had to go back to RCT3 and RCT2 and play those scenarios again.

I say don’t buy this game now. Wait a few months/year. There are other coaster tycoon games that are currently being developed. Planet Coaster for people who enjoyed Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 (which is in early alpha and it’s prettier than this. However, Planet Coaster Alpha costs £49.) and for people who enjoyed RCT1 and RCT2 there is Parkitect (Alpha cost £15). Those two games are shaping up to be great coaster games. I suggest following their progress.

reviewText:
Excitement Rating: 2.00 Low
Intensity Rating: 1.00 Low
Nausea Rating: 13.37 High

Where to start...
Pros
-The game looks beautiful.
-Unlike my coasters, the game never crashed.
Cons
-There is not a single piece of help. No control setup menu, no help button, nothing. Everything I've learned was from messing around and viewing the discussions tab.
-Building a coaster just isn't fun anymore, more on this matter on bullets 3, 4, 5, and 6.
-Coaster troubleshooting is a ♥♥♥♥♥.
-You could fix your coaster into next Sunday and pass the testing phase, the thing will still throw itself off the rails randomly.
-When it does crash the cars of the coaster don't despawn, they just stay there and create more problems.
-Those color coded safety lines that appear while building a coaster needs serious work. Some completely sane and safe segments get red lined while a coaster segment with an obvious flaw gets white lined.
-Day and night transitions look really choppy and just bad.

EDIT: After some investigative button pressing G turns on the grid.

I veered away from anything resembling a bug in the Cons list because it's a beta, but this feels like an alpha at least. I also veered away from content issues because I know most content is shut off for the first beta. (with the exception of the grid for pathways, which I doubt is even in the game.)

This is a worrying start for RCT World and I hope the patches and hotfixs start rolling out soon. I'm holding out for the end of the second beta when we see the game in her full glory but if that doesn't deliver, as much as it pains me to say it, I'm going to have to refund my purchase.

TL:DR Save your pre-order money for another title, or wait until the reviews for the second beta come out.

I'll update this review as the betas move on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

These negative reviews are so bias it is insane.... Everyone of them talks about planet coaster,  a game that isn't even out yet but still people talk it up as if they've played it. I will also be getting planet coaster day one but It is not fair to this dev team who has obviously worked very hard on this.. Plus it is early access!

I'll start by saying I did not buy this for $50,  I got it for $20 so that definitely helps make it more positive for me and I believe it's important for me to note that.

I am running a GTX 980, i7, 32gb ram... I have yet to run into any major optimization issues. I have the graphic settings maxed out,  the game looks great and runs great. I really like the lighting at night.  If you're running on a much older machine and complaining about optimization issues then you just need to stop and git gud.

I don't believe half these reviews on here...Many of the negative reviews have less then an hour played on them or they're from the beta..

Gamers now a days hate on anything and everything. Seems people can't enjoy anything for themselves, so they jump on the hate train. Its very evident when half the negative reviews have the same language. Its truly sad. When it comes to this,  PC gamers have always been the worst.

This is an early access game and for what it is now,  I think its great and is only going to get better. The development team has already posted a day after release about upcoming updates directly addressing players complaints. I hope they plan on releasing a ton of content. Maybe even some freebies for us early access folks.

I'm loving it so far.. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the first two RCT games. I played a ton of hours on both back in the 90s.



I know already this will consume me.
👍😊

reviewText:
First off, this review is for the 1st beta weekend, in which the purpose of the beta is to show off the roller coaster builder and to get feedback. After launching the game for the first time, it immediately crashed during the loading screen. That’s definitely not a great start to a beta. The game is riddled with bugs that make the game unplayable. So far, this game isn’t even up to the quality of early-access alpha games by indie developers.

Here is a short list of bugs I’ve run into in just the first 2 hours:
Clicking a control point on a track randomly changes it rotation values, making it impossible to tweak the coaster without breaking everything.
There are memory leaks that cause the game to crash about once an hour.
There are occasional crashes during the loading screen.
Cars fall through the track on lift chain hills almost every other run.
Cars fall through the track of the station as soon as you hit test.
Fast forwarding time completely breaks the physics, causing even the slightest turn to throw trains off the rails.
The UI for lift chain speeds and booster/break speeds are the size of an ant. You can’t click it, much less read it.
The camera controls don’t work while editing coasters, and sometimes freeze up while editing paths, scenery, or terrain.
The rotation arrows for track editing are occasionally in the wrong direction.
The rotation values of track control points are almost always incorrect, also causes the white, yellow, and red highlighting to be incorrect. You can have a control point that looks like it should be 0 degree, and it will say it is 35 degree.
Intersecting paths of different sizes don’t render properly.
Wooden coaster supports don’t render properly.
Even with the max brush strength, it takes quite a while to fill a small pond with water. That was a horrible feature idea.
I’ve already documented 137 more bugs, but I’m just going to leave the list there. Overall, the camera controls and editing controls are too buggy to use reliably, and the coaster editing features of this game are mostly broken.

Since this was a beta to demonstrate just the coaster editor, and it is this bad, I don’t expect this game to be out this year unless they hire programmers just to fix bugs. I can’t even imagine how buggy all the other features are of the game. As it is, it looks like they have pushed the release date back again from Dec. 10th to Dec. 29th.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to put a break in the train of hatred this game seems to be getting. First off, yes. I have not played Coaster Planet. Does Coaster Planet look nice? Yes. So does this, however. Are there things that I'd like to see improve? Well sure. That can be said about many games and this, fortunately, is still being worked on. For what I've got, I'm more than happy. Now that my little rant is over, allow me to explaid why I recomment this game:

Gameplay: Overall, the game plays more or less exactly like RollerCoaster Tycoon 3. The game does try to move away from the grid system, however there is an optional grid you can enable to make your work more precise. While the grid feature does require some touching up to allow for things to be more exact, it still works and helps. The Coaster Builder is also updated to bring a, in my opinion, more indepth and detailed construction process. You no longer are restricted to certain angles allowing you to have a lot more freedom in your design. It will also display data on how your speed is distributed on the track, how fast you are going at a given place, etc. I had a good amount of fun playing with it. Going back to paths, you can also make curved paths this time removing your restriction to blocky pathways. Overall the game plays the same, just with some slight tweeks and updates.

Graphics: This seems to be another contested area. The game definitely went away from the cartoonish theme of old in favor of realism. This doesn't bother me too much (Yes, I've played every RCT game. Yes, I understand the style was cartoony in all of them. Sure, go ahead and call me a casual, not a fan, etcc.) The overall user interface looks clean, perhaps not super uber professional" with its art direction like some may desire. However
hoursPlayed: and I like it. A lot of what you would expect out of a RCT interface is there.\n\nOverall: There really isn't a whole lot for me to pick on with this game. It is exactly what I'd expect from a RollerCoaster Tycoon game
voteText: there are definitely some improvements over RCT3
helpfulPercent: but there are defintely areas to improve on. I will still continue to play it and enjoy it and definitely looks forward to what will come in the game's future. If you are on the fence of buying this game
votesHelpful: do understand this is a work in progress
votesTotal: and understand that it really is not half as bad as people seem to think it is. You will enjoy it nonetheless if you enjoyed past RCT games."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nJust to clarify, this is in early access, there will be bugs, I feel like the PC community would have figured that out already before giving early access games bad reviews because of bugs... ANYWAYS. After having spent the last 6 and a half hours playing this game, I can without a doubt say that this game is living up to my expectations... Having been a fan since the original RCT and seeing it progress to RCT3, a trainwreck of a game, I had high hopes for this game since Atari had 12 years to think and improve. Atari has improved. The interface is insanely simple yet effective, also it has a very slick design to it, props to that. All the editors for scenery, rides, shops, etc... is easy to use and simple. What I love most is the coaster editor. The freeform builder has just enough complexity to it that you may create whatever you dream of, within physical boundaries of course, but it is simple enough and straight forward that basically any 14 year old can hop on here and start building coasters. I feel as though this is finally the game I've been waiting for. RCT3 had some good features to it, like the ride cam for instance, as well as the magnitude of scenery and ride options. When I play this game, I feel like I'm playing a near perfect combination of RCT1 and RCT3 and I am okay with that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So this is the Early Access version of the game and not the completed version, I've played the previous games in the franchise which I spent most of my childhood playing and decided to try out the latest edition. I didnt expect it to be perfect as its still being developed but after around 10 hours of playing the game I pretty much enjoyed it!

The game basically takes me back to the original released in 1999 which was simple and focued on the rides and managment, this was the first I played and it was very entertaining. The customisation is also a work in progress as more themes have been confirmed by the developers as well as other stuff. The CoasterBuilder is also new and brilliant! It allows the franchise to evolve with players pulling and dragging the tracks making it more flexible. The second game in the series basically had lots of customisation and built on the first title however the newest game lacks themes and other objects but with more from the developers it soon might improve, the game also has user generated support so lots might be provided from the community of tycoon fans. The third game in the series bacially went 3d and wanted to expand everywhere which in my opinion didnt work and pushed many gamers back to the 2 originals, the UI and campaign were so bad I continued playing RCT2 as it seems the developers went crazy with zoos and water parks however with the newest game going back to its roots and starting again its seems the franchise can get back to its best! Many of the newest games features are very promising and deserve some time to be made perfect, Im willing to wait and share my experience with the developers to make the game decent and a standard which the originals set!

You've probably noticied that this review section is full of negetivie reviews, many just complain about the littlest bugs or problems that are not major and are expected as the game is in development! Im not suggesting they are not allowed a opinion but i thinks its alarming and unfair  that many of these players have only played the game for a short amount of time, I consider this not to be enough gametime time to judge a game such as RollerCoasterTycoon. Myself was actually confused getting to know the controls for the first hour however as I progressed it became more enjoyable, easy and relatable to the previous games in the series. The reason I'm writing this is because I would not want any possible players considering trying the game to be put off by a few comments that mostly include minimun issues, Its also  because most of these include the word PlanetCoaster" Which is a similar game but shouldnt be advertised by their fanbase on this review section. Many will claim its a better game but thats your opinion however most of these people have not played RCTW long enought to make a review as many have played for a matter of minutes as I have seen. It also seems many have just followed the trail of popular youtubers
date: not fully given the game a chance and can not spot a valid problem with thr game that matters deeply in their reviews. These sort of reviews are not reviews so I reconmend you read wisely and check out some videos online to make your opinion.\n\nOverall the game is playable and enjoyable in Early Access
recommended: It has so much potentical that will hopefully be developed with the fans
hoursPlayed: its been truely resurrected from the ashes and seems to be going back to its roots similar to the original base game. E.T might have killed Atari along time ago but its certain now that Atari is back and evolving with RollerCoaster Tycoon World!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played all the Roller Coaster tycoon games over the years. This one is a bit tricky at first. Expect to spend a few hours understanding how to make your first coaster unless you get some tips. This is more of a guide and review at the same time. Here are some tips. :)

Expect a little frustration building your coaster at first. When building your coaster:  Hold down the shift key, and use the mouse wheel to move it higher or lower. After you click on a peice of the track in build mode you can drag out that track and make curves, etc. and press 1, 2, 3, or 4; all these numbers do different things. Then you use your mouse wheel and to adjust. One of the numbers lifts up the track on one side for example (press 2, and then use your mouse wheel for example).

Also the camera is a bit quirky. You can go into options in the game, general, turn off auto focus coaster when building (so it doesn't jump everytime you click on the track), turn off auto zoom out camera if object is to large, and change your camera field of view if you like.

Also the graphics can be improved; changing them is a bit quircky. This is done by pressing escape, options, graphics, turn off better fps over graphics.. This makes the graphics settings go lower for some reason though. You then need to adjust higher the other settings AFTER you select this.

Placing a ride or object: Hold down the shift key, and use your mouse wheel to turn it around before you place it.

Adjusting the size of the map: Click modify terrain, and you'll find the option to expand there.

Also when you place a janitors building for example each building is used to hire the number of janitors for that building; differnent than RCT3.

This is a great game, but I think the issue is most people aren't taking the time to go through the tutorial. In addition to that the coaster building is a bit advanced; you can do a lot with it, but the key will be the first few hours.For beginners it's a bit tricky.

Is it fun? Yes it's a lot of fun to play. I'm enjoying my park the more and mroe I play it. The more I play, the more I want to play. It starts out slow and grows on you once you figure out what your doing. It's also fun to decorate/improve the park.

The graphics are pretty nice as well. I'm looing forward to this game growing, but as for now it's a good game if your willing to read a guide like this one and others you'll be fine. :) Also if you enjoy a challenge on coaster building you'll like this game. Expect a lot of crashes during testing, but it's gratifying and realistic.. You adjust angles of track to compensate, etc. It just feels nice, and it's a good sandbox style game.

There are a good amount of rides, and park finances.

Why are there bad reviews section: Most people don't understand the options they have at their disposal, and haven't read the tips/guides on controls. Changing the graphic options, and adjusting the camera are all fairly easy to do once you have read these trips.

I have experienced some crashes for example when making a huge roller coaster with lots of turns, etc. I'd say save every so often in case, but the coaster build is pretty fun once you get the hang of it. The game is itself seems to run pretty smooth though on my system; a 980 GTX, 16 gigs ram, and a 3.4 ghz quad.

The problem is if people didn't get it within 1-2 hours many immediately went for the bad review/refund option, but this one is worth digging deeper and playing imo. :)

Other than that I enjoy customizing the cars for the coasters or the colors of the paths or que lines. I enjoy the fact that the peeps have a mind of their own. Some dont like to ride certain rides, some only like roller coasters.

The Coaster Builder. - Took me alot of time to get used to, forgetting to use shift to make it rise, or tilt. I enjoy the fact that some coasters can spin, reminded me of *Thrillville off the rails*.

I enjoy the fact that the mascots seem to make everyone happy. I also enjoy that there are SO MANY differnt food buildings, theres like 4 different buildings just for tacos and salads!!!

One thing that I really really enjoy is that I can ramp the paths, like, I made a little river, so I boosted the path up to go over the river, and I put a wooden rollercoaster track under and over it, so My peeps can enjoy a good coaster on the entrance of the park.

The performance isnt 10/10, nor is the FPS, but it is playable....

Im surprised my FPS lasted pretty good with the ammount of items and peeps in the park, there were around 1,800 peeps in the park and over hundreds of differnt pieces. 6 Roller coasters spread out all over. 60+ food buildings, 8 mechanic buildings with 10 mechanics for each building. 5 entertainer buildings, once again 10 entertainers for each building. 9 Janitor buildings, 10 janitors for each building. atleast 80 plants and trees, a lake, and over 10 thrill / family / and Junior rides.....

Peeps arent to bad, yeah they walk through each other, but eventually theres so many peeps in your park you dont even notice it. Peeps - 8/10

Id rate the game 8/10

Path Placement - 7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please note that this is just my opinion... And that I haven't read what they're up to putting into it yet.

Pro's:
- I love the rides.
- I love the fact that now there's actually ''death'' possible when you build a rollercoaster, which makes it more challenging to build one.
- You can now move stuff without deleting it first compared to the other RC games.
- The campagne is fun, however, I think it'd be more fun if added more challenges to it.

Con's:
- Even on my brother's game computer it lags. I have one myself, whilst my brothers literally meets all the requirements. It is not recommended for laptops or so unless you got yourself a strong, good laptop(mainly due overheating).
- The paths are annoying to place. I tried putting a path from a building to the ''main street'' but it replaced the old path from the ''mainstreet''.
- The buildings look all the same, at least for the staff.
- I hate the staff buildings. They barely do anything and in RTC3 I really enjoyed the fact you could throw staff in your park and train them etc.
_
I've heard a lot of negative things about RCTW , but keep in mind it's still Early Access. From what I saw, they've improved quite a few things. I see a lot of people saying although Planet Coaster isn't done yet but better. I didn't play PC, and I don't care.

Both of them still need to be finished and I'm sure this game gets better as time goes on.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is really good. When it was released there's no doubt it left a lot be desired as there were numerous bugs but having bought the game and played it myself now it is developing into an excellent theme park building game. What is going to go massively in this game's favour is the ease of importing models into this game. Quite frankly the possibilities are endless. The amount of UGC is already quite high and will keep going but it would be nice to see some other tools such as a full map creator. I know you can create scenarios by using terraforming tools in sandbox but nevertheless would be nice to see a map builder. This game still needs some optimizing as well as it can run quite jerkily when on high graphics but seems perfectly smooth on medium graphics. This may also be partly down to my PC although it is quite new. It took a couple of updates to get there but good job Atari and keep the updates and content coming.

Hopefully they will add back in a good building editor again that is like Planet Coaster and it really would be the best theme park game ever.

reviewText: The coaster editor is terrible. I used to spend hours on RCT1, 2 and 3 building roller coasters and I'd enjoy it. There is nothing enjoyable about the new coaster editor at all. Lift hills are massive curves instead of being straight like they are supposed to be. It's difficult to place small pieces of track. It's like you are supposed to draw these massive curvacious parts of track. Just managing to build a wooden roller coaster with a drop and one air time hill was a chore. I built an accelerator coaster but there wasn't even an option to change the launch speed! I couldn't even find the ride camera.  There should at least be an option to use an editor like the one in RCT3 but you're not limited to a 90 degree angle.\n\nI'll probably buy it when it's on a Steam sale but I am requesting a refund for the pre-order I purchased. Also the release date was 10th Decemeber. Anyone notice it's been pushed back to the 29th now?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UNSATISFYING VERY EARLY EARLY ACCES
FIrst of all, I don't consider the game to be as bad as 70% of the community says it is. This review is written a few hours after EA launch, so still, a very early state of the game. The review will be updated as necessary.

I see what the devs are trying to do and taking into account the progress since the last beta, they are on a good way.

But somehow, I can't quite describe why, this game is unsatisfying. Like, you spent one hour to build an awesome coaster and tweaking it afterwards so the nausea rating would go down, still, 100% of the peeps puke as they leave. Why? Because they don't like my coaster?
There is some kind of lack of atmosphere. The peeps are very static in their behavior.
I don't say that the way they feel is badly calculated, but instead of displaying annoying smileys over their heads, let them do something.

Yes, the game is still very far from being perfect! But EA is what the game needs right now from my point of view. The game is not as bad as 70% negative reviews and seemingly 100% negative since the launch! With lots of effort put into it by the devs and the community this game can be amazing. So be patient, it's the first day of EA and some of the people behave like it was doomsday.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is alright and has potential, but it should look back some of the other games for improvement. Maybe im missing a couple features, but I cant be sure. I didn't play rct3 because It was kind of ♥♥♥♥.

Just a note: One of the rides is broken, the one that is supposed to swing the guests with the whole seating mechanism spinning (I cant remember the name). It sits at the top and does not release and just spins at the top of its rotation.

Reccomended hardware: Any mouse with an infinite scroll wheel

The one thing I love more than anything is the roller coaster design and the application of mechanics within them (though making loops and ♥♥♥♥ is hard).  The path building is also cool, but I never use the curved pathways because they never seem to work or let any other paths snap. You should also allow for automatic scenery destruction when creating the coasters, placing pre-mades or at least expand the destruction to only destroy scenery in xy range.
Things I hate are the laggy experiances you get which you can only assume is due to a memory leak or soemthing else.

The buildings are cool, though I hate the fact that you need to place a path for each and every one is really annoying. This is one of those features im going to test later with the grid snap and see if that helps out at all. The default station platforms are limiting, but the use of the brakes is a more realistic (and maybe better?).

I hate hate hate the use of the word peeps" and how the "peeps" thoughts don't stack. This is something that is absolutely needed. Also the use of the words People or Guests looks better.

Is this game worth $60 right now? Prolly not

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I typically do not write reviews, however I almost did not buy this game based on all the negative reviews that seem to be stemming from a fan fued between RCT and Planet Coaster. I was worried about the whole 'early access' and if this was even goingt o run properly on my older comptuters. I took the Planet Coaster comments seriously and did look into their product (I'm not sure how it is a 'game' yet... seems more like 'build only' platform which does not interest me) - I'll keep it on my Radar. ANYWAYS - the reason I am writing my review, was I almost did not buy RCTW because of all the mud being flung in this fued. It took several youtube video's to convince me that the product was ready... so here is is..

THIS PRODUCT IS WORTH IT - PARTICULARLY IF YOU ARE A FAN OF THE ORIGINALS.

There is enough working so it feels like a finished product. There are scenarious, multiple (10?+) coaster types, 100's? of rides, etc. The scenery selection is decent, however it is a little light on the themes.

The new coaster creator - You can either create a coaster the 'old' way (piece by piece w/ a button editor) or with their new spline based system. I work in 3D all day long, but first started with the 'old' way for comfort sake. In my second park, I only built w/ the new system.

There are SOME glittches. Paths sometimes don't want to snap together right, but they will 99% of the time, they just might not be 'pretty'. - they will NOT impeed the play of the game. General sim animation glitches, but again, this doesn't seem to impeed the play of the game.  Food/Drink stands don't snap to the edge of paths, so you need to place them and make a very short path to the path etc. etc. NONE OF THESE ELEMENTS STOP YOU FROM PLAYING!

Also, I'm fairly happy to report that so far they do seem to be improving the game w/ updates.

ANYWAYS - is you are a fan, and you're getting cold feet based on the reviews from the haters... hopefully this review will help you make a decision to buy. The only type of person I'd not recomend this to is someone w/ OCD that needs their parks to look perfectly symetrically and pretty. That's not going to happen yet. Play for the game itself, or play in sandbox mode to make really really awesome roller coasters. (which by the way you need a hack to use in planet coaster? WTF?)

The only thing I may add, is if you're going to have to starve yourself for a week to save up th $50, eat... or maybe eat PB&J and buy RCT3 (assuming it will still run on Windows 10) for the 20 or whatever to get your fix and see where this price will end up - but $50 for a game like this, is not a bad investment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I want to say a few things about this game really quick. First of all I have been a player of this series since RCT1 was out, I've had most of my hours in this series played in RCT2 but I've still played countless hours of RCT3. This new game has put a very sour taste in my mouth and it seem to have done the same for many other fans of the series. but looking at tis game as it is, it isn't awful. The textures and movement of the peeps are my biggest complaint and the pathing isn't very smooth and needs to be fixed. but other than that, this game has a monetary system and scenario and well made terrain deformation and water(even though the water doesn't look very good), It also doesn't run great but the just means it needs to be a little better optimized which is usually the last thing a developer does in a game. This game definetely has some things it needs to fix, but if they can tweak those few things, it'll be a pretty good coaster tycoon game.

TL;DR
The game has graphic issues and looks a little weird, but it has potential to be a good game

reviewText:
OK, background first: I loved RCT2, played it tons and just wanted a newer up to date version on that.

The beta is not this!

There are 2 main issues that probably won't be resolved because I disagree fundamentally with what they have done.

1. The Artwork resembles any bland MAC application with some grey boring icons and grey paths, grey coasters, low colour vibrancy where there is colour. It's like they looked at RCT2 and thought 'No, we dont like colours. We like grey and black and white. Borders? No, we don't like borders, we like MINIMAL feel'. End result: the game has no soul, no feeling of Theme Parks, you are like an engineer or town planner, NOT MR Eccentric Tycoon with a funny moustache and wacky clothing! And the game is called TYCOON, you would think the devs would know this, but apparently smart people can be stupid!!!!!

2. The coaster building is slow and fiddly. There's a number of reasons for this, but it's never going to be fixed as there's no QUICK way to build coasters like in RCT2. You have to do tests and after waiting 3-4 mins for the carriages to get to the corner in question, only then do you find out if it works or not. Then you spend the next 5-10 mins trying to minimise the g-force (which is the usual issue), but you have no idea if you have done enough until you do a test! This feels like a 'Pro Mode', or Kerbal Space Program, with realistic physics, and no way for you to easily tell if your track is ok. And I'm no idiot, I built 3 coasters today and first one only took 15-20 mins, but it was just stupid the effort I had to put in!!

No-one should fork over money for this if they liked RCT2. I loved that game, so the choice is yours. If you want a bland simulator then buy this game, if you want a game that is, you know, FUN, then play something else.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I feel like this game is going down a similar path to Diablo 3. The games and their developers have nothing to do with each other, but D3 received such a poor reception after it came out, and probably deserved it, but Blizzard fixed its problems. D3 is fantastic now.

This game is early access, and people argue that it is NOT complete enough to even -be- in early access, but honestly I'd compare this to Ark's early stages. The game is bug-ridden, poorly optimized for performance, has unbalanced systems and an average amount of content. It's being actively developed though: they release patches regularly for issues and consistently add new stuff. They don't address all the bugs each patch, but it's a process.

RCTW definitely has a chance. I'm willing to give it a 'Yes' now and see what fixes come out. I do believe that they can still change stuff like path building being wonky, having to remove every single little piece of foliage one by one to place stuff, and even some of the performance issues once they get proper feedback.

TL;DR People are mercilessly slaughtering this game without giving it a chance, but I think it's worthwhile to keep an eye on.

Early Access Review

-The graphics are terrible and the peeps look so wrong! It looks awefull.
-The decorations are very limited and I ended up ''filling in the gaps'' with trees and bushes.
-The coaster builder is horrible! using the piece by piece tool is pointless as it does not even give you as much freedom as rct3 did. The coasters that I took hours to build did not look good because of the odd shapes and corners.
-The buildings that you can place are very limited, too repetitive.
-The sounds are stupid, unrealistic and sometimes scary..

-There are up to four main stations per coaster type, that's it.. enjoy
-Your park customization and management is very limited!
-Flat rides are just placable.. that's the only thing you do.. place it, you can't even change the color of them!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short and sweet; if they fix the pathing issues, add some more scenery options, and allow us to recolor rides (currently you can only change the color of coaster parts)...I'd have no problem fully recommending this. Being that it's still in Early Access, I'm a bit more forgiving. However, by the time the proper release rolls around, if the current issues are still withstanding, then I'd have no qualms about updating my review and recommendation.

All in all, do your research about RCTW. Yes, Planet Coaster is all around a better theme park sim as it stands, but it's double the price to buy in to Planet Coaster's alpha. If you're on a budget, and want a new park sim, and can deal with it's quirks, I don't see why anyone shouldn't give RCTW a try. And with Steam now allowing refunds, if you dislike it that much, you can always get your money back.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PROS
- Coaster Builder: It's always been so easy to create a roller coaster in RCT, and this coaster builder definitely adds a challenge and makes me want to get better at making them. It can get very complicated though, particularly when the supports of (most noticeably) the wooden coaster get in the way and you actually can no longer see what piece you're making. I also found that when you ride the coaster in first person  there's alot of little bumps and mini-twists in the track that I hadn't noticed before, making the roller coaster seem really unnatural.. this may, however, be down to my inexperience with the feature.

- Variety: Not too bad, only about 8 types of roller coaster, such as Stand-up, Hyper, Wooden, Flying etc. I'm sure this list will grow however. Also a few flat rides which, again, will grow in time, but for now it's enough considering it's EA.

- Realism: Everything ACTUALLY looks right and feels real, everything is bigger, MUCH bigger, with realistic, big roller coaster stations, buildings take up way more than one square on the grid.. everything is just BIGGER. The parking lot out the front, the entrance itself.. the scale is just massive and really feels like a real theme park.

Music: Seemingly unimportant but I like it.

CONS
- Not as developed as I was hoping for: I honestly thought the game was WAY more developed than this.. it still feels like a skeleton. Know that I didn't play the beta though, this is a brand new experience of RCTW for me, so I can't compare it to that. I've been following the game since it's announcements but have nothing more to go on than screenshots and trailers. I was a bit gutted when I discovered the game was coming to EA.. Atari really do have no excuse for being this slow, I think they announced the game way too early that now it's annoyed people so much a lot of us WANT it to fail. I'm not one of these people, but I sense from other people's comments that they just want to see this game drow after putting so much hope (and a bit of money, too) into it! So yeah, this far down the line I expected much more meat on the bones.. but alas, it still feels very empty. (This may contradict my PRO for variety, but in that sense I understand the game is EA and will have little variety, despite the fact I wished it was further into development than this)

- Paths: oh my god. Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god. Words cannot describe.. They're the most infuriating thing and I can't explain why.. They've been very lazy with the paths, they don't build right, they mess up all the time.. oh my god, just paths. Sort it, please.. There was nothing wrong with simple click and place in the previous games or, heck, ANY other simulator! The grid also needs revising, I think, nothing seems to fit nicely.

- Visuals, ie menus and HUD: Wooowwww it's hideious. Like, actually hideous.. I don't know if they're going for a Sims 4 kind of minimalistic display in-game, which would look good.. but it just looks so random, maybe like they haven't really focused on that yet. The menus look cheap and Alpha-like.. think Cities:Skylines, just a grey, rounded text box with some words in. Put some effort in, Nvizzio! Get some sort of theme going with the menus, like the blue bubbles in RCT3! It just makes it look.. like a game!?

- Buggy: Yes yes yes, it's EA I knoooww, but considering (again) how long this has supposedly been in development (I get the feeling they just go into the office every Sunday or something to do 2-3 hours worth of actual development on the game) it's a bit odd to se a mechanic floating around and attempt to inspect a ride whilst it's mid-flow, getting kicked in the face multiple times by the flying chairs.. silly. The game just crashed on me for no reason either, to be expected in EA I know, but this far down the line? Not sure.

VERDICT
I want to give this games a thumbs up, just to show them that there IS somebody still rooting for this game. My biggest worry is that all these (overwhelming amount!) negative reviews will make them think Ah screw it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had a good time playing this.

I played the first 2 RCTs and expansions whay back on thier release and i had such a good time with those ground breaking games.  They were easy to figure out and enough detail and options to keep the entertainment value and replay-ability alive to even this day for many still.  Its a tough job modernizing those yet keeping the same simplicity.

I will admit that even going through the tutorial on the first coaster build, I was slightly getting frustrated...but...it was my first time.  I know eventually it will get easier and if i dont feel like making one then i will just use an existing one...just like i did with the earlier games.

I would recomend this to people who get into this type of game, and the ones who don't will just have to sit quietly and listen to me talk about it...because i had a good time playing it and i will put many-o-more hours into it.

as far as early release bugs and glitches.....the only thing i noticed in the first couple hours of playing was that when i zoomed out a bit, some of the rides would spin incredibly fast...to the point it just looked crazy.  you can tell there still needs to be some fixes but its definately playable....and fun!

one more note:  i would like to see and option for a simple path build.  maybe even a button that will straighten already built paths in accordance with a grid.  maybe highlight an area and snap all paths to make them straight.  maybe that is too hard to program...but would be nice.  Then again...maybe it is there and I didnt see it yet....guess i should get back to playing.
