reviewText:
(Written during Beta Weekend 1)

I can understand where people are coming from with the new coaster builder. It does take some time to adjust if you're used to the older games' way of building. From what I've experienced so far it's been great, but that's not to say there aren't any problems with it.

The biggest problem I've encountered so far are the restraints. For example, wooden coasters can barely be tilted whereas in real life there are some that do corkscrews just fine. Similar constraints apply to the paths placement as well; I couldn't make a path up to my ride because the game (as it stands during Beta Weekend 1) doesn't have stairs and as a result, you have to elevate your paths over a long distance. Even then I could only build a queue to the ride entrance and not the exit, for what reason I have no idea.

The physics seems to be a bit iffy as well. I made a drop coaster that curved upwards into a loop, but as soon as the coaster hit around 60mph it just fell off the track, regardless of how insignificant the curve was.

The decorations are good, although it would be nice to have local build limitations (such as hitboxes on other objects) displayed. I tried to wall off one of the gold statues but I had a pretty difficult time with it because of the hitbox being larger than what the model actually shows when you hold it.

The game itself was also having a few issues. When I tabbed out and back in sometimes my camera would be locked and the UI buttons wouldn't do anything forcing me to restart from my last save point. The ability to view your coasters in first person is also seemingly random; you have to test it and hope the coaster editor bar doesn't show up at the bottom so you can click the coaster again to get to the camera button.

Overall, it's a relatively enjoyable experience. If you do encounter any issues I would highly recommend providing feedback on the RollerCoaster Tycoon World forums. It's important to bear in mind that this is a limited development build and some of the issues we're having may already be addressed. Is it worth £29.99? As of beta weekend 1, no. I'd wait for release reviews if you're not interested in bugs.

Any further review past Beta Weekend 1 will be added below this. I'll keep editing the original during the weekend the more I play.
voteText: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game for my wife. While it isn't quite everything I had hoped for in this long awaited installment, it is still playable and we look forward to the updates and changes to come. My wife finds herself losing track of real time while playing. She's not the biggest gamer, actually, not a gamer at all so if this game can capture her attentionand I know she looks forward tothe next time she has freetime to play then to me it was worth my purchase. I have watched her play and I myself think that while there is still plenty of room to improve, it does look nice and for the most part operates fairly smoothly.

The ability to place buildings facing nearly any direction is a nice feature because in previous installments choosing one of four directions became relentlessly boring.

That being said, it would be nice to have better graphics options. I realize this game is more for a common crowd with average machines than it is for the game enthusiasts but it would be great for the game to make use of the available resources on upscale machines.

So, keep in mind, while this has been a long awaited installment in the franchise, this is still early access and there are going to be glitches and room for improvement. The only way to help shape the game the way you want it is to play, and provide feedback in the discussionboard for the developers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll recommend it, but I'd wait (from the time of writing this review) about a week, maybe a month for the developers to sort out the issues. It's a graphic-intensive game, so make sure your hardware is up to spec. Lots of issues to figure out still, such as jittery peeps, peeps without some animations, and at one point, I had all of my peeps disappear instantly, but I could still hear them.

Give Nvizzio time. It's Early Access, so it makes sense. But props to them on a decent first pass for release. This game holds a very promising future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is a lot of negative reviews about rollercoaster world and yes it took me a couple of hours to get used to how the game works, turn rides/shops etc around, but now ive got the hang of it im finding the game quite promising. I think the developers have got the right idea and have done a good job with what they have done so far. Yes its got some issues with gitches and sound and sometimes my people just suddenly freeze but this is early access. I like how much easier it is to build rollercoasters and i like all the personal touches that you can do with them, at the same time im glad theyve kept the pre-made rollercoasters. I also think the detail thats gone into the stations is really good. I was a little unsure about space but after 2 hours of playing i found that this was just me not knowing how to play the game yet, because you can buy more land by going on the terrain tool button, and i found if i pressed the letter n ( i play on my laptop) it allows you to place buildings closer to rides etc. I like what theyve done with the themes, and have been able to make a western and an adventure area with what is available in this early access game. I am looking forward to see what the updates will bring. The only negatives ive found so far is deleting items such as bins, lamposts etc im finding you have to put your mouse in a certain spot for it to highlight. Deleting the trees and bushes one at a time is also a little tedious as i cant find an option to delete a large area at a time, id like atari to look into putting a multi- tool delete option or something similiar to fix this. Ive also found that i cant place rides or anything if theres trees etc in the way without deleting them all yourself and then finding the ride you wanted again so i would also like the rides etc to automatically delete the trees etc for you.  nearly forgot but Im not liking the staff limit, im ending up with lots of staff buildings which only allow 3 staff and the cleaners dont seem to do anything because after placing 5 cleaner buildings my parks still a mess, I see them cleaning but it doesnt seem to make any difference, same for mechanics too. I know there will be larger building available but i can imagine me just having lots of larger staff buildings everywhere. Other than that im happy with what ive seen so far.

Since playing further ive had issues reloading a saved game it just crashes saying virtual memory to low to play game, but my virtual memory is fine. Also after being on any rollercoaster every person that comes of is sick which you can never clean up, all cleaners go there so the rest of your park turns into a tip. Also i cant seem to place benches etc on a higher up path.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been reading alot of the reviews already about the game and there seems to be a lot of hate and lack of understanding coming from some of the people who have played this game.

Let's start with the obvious, It's early access. Yes there is things that work really well and things that don't. it's all part of the development process and I'm sure the devs will get onto improving these features over the next couple of weeks and months leading up to the V1 release.

The gameplay for me so far has been relatively solid and no major problems that disrupt the game completely if anything it's mainly just minor superficial things so I'm going to list them out below.

#1 Pavements: These are the most frustrating parts of the game to build as far as I'm concerned and as a person who likes to keep things looking smart and symetrical this has been a hinderance does present a problem placing buidlings next to each other. my recommendation to the developers, allow pavements to connect to each other at any point instead of somewhere randomly in the middle.

#2 Bulldozer tool: I had to remove some trees and shrubbery in some areas to make space for rides, buildings etc. The bulldozer only lets you remove one object at a time with can be tedious when there is smaller things hidden behind trees. If there is possiblity for a bulldozer brush tool to remove large areas of clutter quickly that would be appreciated.

Overall: I think RCTW is quite a good solid build for an early access and it has potential to to get even better, I implore anyone that is thinking about buying this game that you should consider the early access tag and please make notes of any bugs/defects or anything you think would improve the game and let the developers know so it can flourish as a sequel of the much loved series.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying I love RollerCoaster Tycoon. I am a theme park enthusiast, and this series has always been nostalgic for me and 1, 2 and 3 are possibly my favourite games of all time.

So you can imagine how disappointed I was when I saw this, even as a beta. Rant to follow.

You absolutely cannot build a coaster. It is impossible. We thought it was just because they were bad at the Alienware stream but the coaster builder is impossible. All they cared about was bringing out the game and not making it realistic. You cannot build an even slightly realistic coaster. Wtf???? Fix coaster building right now, it needs a complete overhaul, it is impossible to use, literally no one can make a proper coaster.
I am refunding and i suggest you do as well if you bought it, and i suggest no one else buy it.
How dare they even release something like this, even has a beta?!!? This is what we waited 10 years for. A buggy mess where coaster building doesnt work.
FIX COASTER BUILDING., IT NEEDS A COMPLETE OVERHAUL. LIFT HILLS ARE LIKE HYPER COASTER AIRTIME HILLS FOR GOD'S SAKE. AND DON'T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THE DIVE COATER RESTRAINTS!!!!! ALSO THE UK FLAG IS CALLED ENGLAND".
My Question to Uglyfoureyesdeceptivelabb: Did you and your so called team of enthusiasts actually do ANY research? The restraints on the dive machine look like arrow looper restraints for some dumbass reason. So many many gameplay problems.
That grid feature... who thought of that? Were they all smoking weed while making this game?
Jesus ♥♥♥♥♥ucking christ how long away is planet coaster?
♥♥♥♥ you Atari

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I've put some hours into this game and I already encountered a lot of game breaking bugs. Peeps that get stuck, a complete reset of the peeps in my park, rides not getting fixed while I have no idea why not and worst of all the frame drops and sometimes even the whole game freezing up. It even managed to crash my computer entirely while saving a game. This only occured when my park was pretty big already though.

However, the parts that work are really fun. It feels and plays like a next gen roller coaster game, wich is exactly what I wanted. I don't know why everyone is hating on the new coaster builder. It's actually really fun and easy once you get the hang of it. I also really like the new scenery and it makes it that I want to make every inch of the park as pretty as can be. The steam workshop works really well with this game and while there isn't much on it right now I can't wait what people will upload so I can make my park even more awesome.

I'm giving the game a thumbs up because I'm actually really enjoying it, even in it's current state. That said, do realise this is not a complete game yet and if you don't want to be part of the ''play-testing'' phase you should wait until they at least patch out the major bugs. Because there are.. a lot..

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say after all the bashing this game has received prior to early release i was wondering if my £14.99 was going ot be wasted, having played for a few hours and got a feel for the game i have to be honest its not all bad, in it current state its hard to give a full and final report but to say there is a bit of work to do yet is not stretching the truth.

So far i have seen the cleaning staff walking the park cleaning without actually moving there legs, lots of peeps bounching and jittering but i guess those kinds of things will be fixed.  Sound seems to travel a lot from quite a distance away i could clearly hear the wooden roller coaster climbing a hill which should not be possible.

I would like to see mouse edge scrolling as well in the final game it seems to be missing from this version.

Yes the graphics are a bit roapy but not rubbish by an stretch of the imagination.  In general if like me you paid half price you wont feel quite so naffed of its not the best game in the world, had i paid full price maybe it would have been a different story.  I dont know how long before a final version is release but from what i ihave seen so far it stilll very much a work in progress with a fair way to go yet.

Planet coaster is a better looking game but is also 12 months away yet and 50 QUID FOR THE ALPHA ACCESS so this will fill the void until then quite nicely.

reviewText:
I was very excited about this latest chapter in the RCT series, but my experience with the beta has left me feeling extremely apprehensive. I don't know what the developer hoped to accomplish by having this beta wekend, as the game is very much not ready for any kind of testing, and definitely nowhere near ready for release.

My specific complaints echo every other reviewer here, so I'm not going to go into great depth. In short, the game just doesn't work. It looks very little like the development videos, and is currently lacking all of the features of a RCT game. The only thing available in this beta is sandbox mode coaster creation, but I found it impossible to actually make anything. I could never get coaster cam to work, and between the clunky creation tools and the vast array of bugs, I got frustrated very quickly.

I certainly hope I am surprised by the release, but for now, do not order this game.
voteText: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful

reviewText: As a huge fan of the RCT series, I am extremely disappointed in the first beta. The interface for building a coaster is extremely confusing and not straightforward in the slightest. There's no simple way to build a loop, delete a piece of track, or edit a piece that you've already created. It's almost impossible to build a coaster in a straight line, even with the grid tool. I was only able to 'ride' my coasters once and there was a weird box around the train that interfered with the line of sight. On top of that, the game is just buggy and runs really slow. At this point, RCT3 stands as a better game. I honestly regret pre-ordering this considering the state it is in right now, and I highly doubt this game will be playable by its release date.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bearing in mind this is Early Access I do find the current state to be playable.  There are still many bugs to be worked out.  My hopes are the developers will address issues reported by players and longtime fans.  I don't have a huge complaint on graphics as I expected the cartoonish style of art.  However, the details and movement of the people are bleak.

Some things to think about:
Poor optimization.
Road system isn’t always ideal.  IE: Doesn’t align or connect to grid.
Snapping" isn’t very intuitive and poorly aligns.
People are poorly animated.
Not a lot of content but there is a built in social share system
date: although it was empty for me.\nLack of in depth management tools (staff management
hoursPlayed:
I said it twice)
Deleting can be a pain.  Would be nice to see a drag and delete feature.

The concern is that it was previously said to be near finished.  I truly hope that was said in error and that development is still moving forward and we can expect to see updates and patches.

Unlike some others I find the Rc builder to be quite nice and challenging for a game that offers little challenge at first to even a novice as plopping down a few ready-made rides will easily get you by money wise.

4-5 out of 10 for me.  Disappointed but hopeful will be my mindset on this.

reviewText:
IF YOU WANT SOMETHING NEW, COOL, AND FUNCTIONAL, AND OWN RCT2, JUST DOWNLOAD OPENRCT2

Do not bother with this game.  It is flopping heavily with its loyal forgiving fans, and PCGamer and Atari themselves hyping this game up before it even came out seemed suspicious enough for be, but I bought it anyways.  Even with my middle-high tier PC, I feel like I was loading it on XP, ARK performed better than this.

I'm not going to complain about the coaster editor, I love the spline editor, and it was going really good.

What I will complain about is the crashing is way too sensitive.  Call it difficult if you want, but it's hard to get fast speeds and keep your coaster on the track when the hill collisions don't even work and it flies off the coaster before it even gets to the hill.
Your cursor and the spline editor will also magically de-sync, making the game unplayable, and for the life of me, I cannot figure out how to delete parts without having to delete the whole coaster.

The music is horrid and if it reminded me of anything, it reminded me of how bad the Sim City reboot was.  That's what this game is.

The beta doesn't even work in windowed mode!  You can't even change the resolution!  It's horrible!  The options menu is literally just the terms of service!!  And considering this is the most resource heavy game I've ever played on my computer, video settings are what you absolutely need the most!

Maybe it will become better in the future.  I was psyched for the custom content, but nobody's going to create custom content for a game this bad.  If you want to download CC, download OpenRCT2 and look up some custom content for that.  I'm applying for my refund right now.

reviewText:
It's just plain not working yet. This is a review from the october beta.

Issues:
-No sound or graphics options, which should be in any build of the game.
-If your coaster doesn't work, may as well just delete it.
-When you delete a part of the path it auto fills in between the two places, making it imposible to make mid coaster edits.
-The coasters fly off the curve way to easily, and there is no way to adjust the bank of a curve after you've moved past that part
-The physics need some work. There is no sense of gravity on the cars when they fly off
-There is no way to pan the camera on the mouse
-There is no real way to control the angle of the drop
-There is no real way to control the angle of the turn
-The graphics are in desparate need of AA.
-Once you make supports dissapear, you can't get them back
-The camera messes up where your mouse is poiting when you are building the coaster.

That said, I still have hope for this game. The devs really do seem like they care about the game, even if they have to work for the wonderful publishers of games like Alone in the Dark Illumination" and "Haunted House: Cryptic Graves."


Some things that lead me to have hope are:
-They are planning to update the game a lot after launch
-The overall engine seems like it is a decent base for the game
-The park management and modding tools they have described are promising
-Atari doesn't seem to be pushing them to add microtransactions
-The devs seem to want to make a good game.
-They said that the old way of making coasters will also be in the game (I'm pretty sure I heard this
date:
but I don't remember where). When combined with the current coaster editor this should help the game a lot
Source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bJxlP1GeAzw

Conclusion:
For now

reviewText:
Save Your Money

*I completely understand it's a beta, but given how bad everything is so far there is no way it will be complete/playable by December 10th. Also, idk why my playtime hours are much smaller than they should be*

After trying this beta I can easily say that the coaster builder is a total trainwreck. The controls are beyond poor and the physics are not realistic at all. There are tons of graphics/performance issues (which are to be expected in a beta), but rides fail for no reason whatsoever (i.e. work in one section during a test and fail the next test even though the track was unchanged) and whenever a ride crashes the train remains on the ground and makes the area around it invalid to place track there from then on. They should really consider trashing the current control layout and go for something similar to Theme Park Studio's, which is simpler and much more precise/powerful. I had such high hopes for this game, but now I don't even care anymore and will be getting a refund. Way to let down a diehard RCT fan Atari...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1 of Early Access pros and cons:

+Coaster builder (once you get used to it it's fantastic)
+Gameplay (kinda like RCT1 and 2)
+Fun & realistic rides and coasters
+Great base game, lots of potential for fun once you get used to it and once updates come.

-Peeps
-Graphics / FPS
-No water rides
-Peeps get on rides with terrible stats, vommit way too quickly
-Coaster stats / test results for intensity and nausea are often way too extreme
-Paths don't always connect properly
-Gaphics settings seem to change on it's own sometimes

I imagine those cons will be handled at a later time though. Great base game so far, lots of potential!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PLEASE IGNORE THE HATERS WHO WERE PROBABLY NOT EVEN BORN WHEN RCT3 CAME OUT.

When you first load the game, it has a disclaimer saying it's in alpha - I suspect the vast majority of idiots here on the rage train just skipped that without reading...

I've played this for about 3-4 hours and I can at least give this a fairer reflection than those who have played it for less than an hour and have written the most vile garbage as an authority on the subject.

Let me be blunt - it takes about an hour to basically learn how to play the game - so you can not criticise it with less than that... PERIOD.

It takes 2 hours to really start building a park (5-10 rides, 2-3 coasters, 5-10 shops etc.)

For early access - this is filling the void that RTC3 left.

Yes, there are definite issues, and one can only hope that the 50% done (figure by Atari) is legit, because if this is MORE than 50% it still has some major problems.

If you can honestly tell me otherwise how I am wrong, send me a friend request - I won't defend the game, but I will defend any idiot who has barely played it and hates it because it's fashionable.

reviewText:
Well lets see ouch look at that current review 195 with a 41% postive...... Well this is a Beta review first off, just a little FYI.

(Beta 1 Review)

So lets get started if you ever was a fan of Rollercoaster tycoon 1,2, and maybe even 3. Then this is the game you have been waiting for, or is it. Well we currently are testing the first public beta, or atleast the people that pre-ordered the game are. It's limited to just the coaster builder system, the path builder system, and some props and the ablity to edit the terrain with out a grid system like in the old RCT games.

(The Coaster Builder System)

You have several different coaster to try out and test.

Each coast has a few options for the stations.

You can change the colors of your coaster in 3 different areas rails, core, and supports.

You can change some of your coasters trains.

The new coaster builder system is kinda like a string that you can pull and turn and twist in to a pretty crazy looking rollercoaster. It sure is not the easiest thing to use by any means, infact sometimes it down right frustrating. It really shouldnt be this hard to build a coaster. I really do like the new system tho it really allows you to make a one of a kind coaster. After messing around with the coaster builder, it did get easier to use and I kinda started to enjoy making these crazy coasters.

Tho with that being said I have seen some pretty crazy bugs with the new coaster system. The main bug I see is that the supports sometimes are missing where there is no reason for it to be missing and then sometimes the coaster supports are right in the middle of another peice of track.

Not locked to a grid or a set of peices really does add to the over all freedom of the new coaster builder.


(The Path Building System)

You get a lot of different paths to pick from you even get 3 different sizes.

You are able to do straight paths , curved paths, and que lines for your rides, tho it would seem you cant do curved que paths.

You can raise the path and make some really cool path systems, saddly tho no steps but they have said they were looking into it.


(Props)

Not much to say really you get a bunch of trees, some rocks, some statues, a few different trashcans, benchs, tables, light poles, even some halloween items.

About the only thing that seemed off to me was their double flag poles where not the same ingame as they showed in the menu...

(Peeps)

You see the peeps but they are just ghosted out they look much better then last time I saw them at PAX i think it was. They was kinda like power sliding every where.

( HOW DOES IT RUN )

Well it crashes a lot...... and i can not say this enough but i mean a ungodly amount. But remember this is a beta..... When it does start up and work it seems like the game has memory problem or something. I have 8 gb of DDR 3 and they recoment 6GB and i can watch it peg my memory out over just 3 coasters and some trees...... what about all them flat rides and peeps... i Still feel like they have alot of work to do before this is ready but then again maybe this is just a older version of the game they are leting us play on. I have faith they well make this game great so i would Recommend this game but i would atleast hold out till late nov as that is when beta 2 should be out and they will open more of the game out to the public to test out.
voteText: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful

Find it odd that there are no transport ride e.g. monorail.

All in all, it is more than playable but needs quite a bit of improvement and content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to write a review on a variety of features of the game!  So far, I'm very much enjoying this with 18.5 hours played.

Scenarios
I like these.  It is fun to have a pre-built park and take on different challenges. I hope they add more to this or even allowing players to create their own scenarios that other people can play.  Campaign and Sandbox mode also available.

Social Hub
Easy to use and get other player's or friends rollercoaster creations in my game.  Amazing how talented some are with their custom rollercoasters.

Gameplay
When I first started I went right into the game.  There were a few things I was annoyed that I couldn't do well, like how shops or rides were placed.  Once I took the time to actually go through the tutorial, I solved most of the issues I was having.  Take the time to go through the tutorial, it will help you and you can open any of the various tutorials at anytime in the options.  Like I didn't have snapping on at first until I realized I needed to turn it on by pressing N once to set it on.

Coaster Building
I found it difficult at first and it definately can use some work still.  The more you use it, the better you will get.  I'm sure this will be a feature that is heavily worked on throughout early access.

Peeps
A nice diverse bunch of peeps are within the game.  They give plenty of info of what they like and don't like.  As well as a number of variables depending on what they are doing in your park, eating, etc.  I found peeps to be the most buggy aspect of the game and the developers will need to improve them.  They graphically glitch out often like on ride cameras or sliding around when walking.

Graphics Options
I saw a lot of reviews saying they were having issues and listing beasty specs.  I have an average PC and I had no problems, minus frame drops here and there.  The frame drops seem to increase with the more peeps in the park or possibly just the park getting larger.  The developers will need to optimize, but it is still playable.  Make sure to look into the graphics settings where there are a variety of options.  There is one where you can favor fps and some others depending on what you are looking for.

Developers
They do seem to be taking feedback seriously and giving updates.  Let's hope they keep that up as it is vital to most early access projects.

User Interface
The menus look fantastic!  Icons are easy to understand.  The second you get into the game,  you will understand what options are for what.

Mouse Movement
Good.  The zoom in and out with the mouse wheel is sensitive until you get use to it.  I'd like to see edge-scrolling available like on the Sims.  Maybe there was an option for it, but I don't think I saw it.

Keybindings
Yes!  They are available.  It sucks to get an early access title and those aren't available yet.  Luckily, they are here.

Paths
Paths are slightly tricky at first, but you will get better at them the more you play.  I think the developers can do some slight adjustments, but overall, the paths are decent.  The textures are attractive as well.

Rides, Objects, Terrain, Buildings
There is a good amount of rides, coasters, buildings, and objects available with a variety of themes (also consider Steam Workshop).  Coasters sometimes seem to freeze and stop running, but it usually corrects itself after a while.  The developers will want to look into that.  I was happy with the ride variety currently in the game.

Overall Thoughts After 18 Hours
This is an enjoyable game and I wanted to keep playing it and growing my park.  There is tons of potential here to grow what is already a decent base for an early access title.  There is clearly some specific graphical bugs that can look silly and the developers will want to get on that as well as further optimization on a variety of features.

I would recommend RollerCoaster Tycoon World and I'm rather surprised by the amount of very negative reviews.  Many with little time played.  Again, as I said above, I was a little annoyed at first when I started, but going through the tutorial solved many issues that I thought the game had.  The issue was that I though I could jump right in with no problems.  Take your time to learn how everything works and you will have fun!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honest Review-

Game Release- Early Access

Time played  5-6 hours

I personally think it has potential. Now I haven't played Planet Coaster or the others that people have been mentioning in the post, So i have nothing to compare them with.


The controls are a little rough and need some refining but once you get used to them it's not too bad.

The Campaign mode needs work. the tutioral does not operate like it should.

There are issues with the animations of the people. sometimes you can see them fly out of the ride. gliding instead of walking. things that can be fixed. but not a complete deal breaker.

Roller Coasters- Designing is fun. takes a few minutes to get used to the controls but once I did the fun began. However, there needs to be adjustment on the people because all my Fun" coasters make everyone get off and throw up instead of jump for joy. even the pre-made ones you can install the people will get off and puke. I mean the one I made only has one loop and a spiral for crying out loud. how is that not Fun right???

Overall I am having fun making a park and roller coasters. I really don't have that big of an issue with it.
It doesn't take too long to load. though sometimes on my laptop it can stick for a moment and lag sometimes but not too much."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've got 3.6 hours in this game and over 200+ in the other RCT games. I grew up with RCT getting my first one from a ceral box as a young child. I love RCT so That's how I'm apporaching this review. TL:DR at the bottom.

The game is buggy and has loads of issues. I've had texture problems on rides, rollercoaster work during testing than later not make it back to the station for no reason, disapearing sceneary, slowness, game systems just not working at all and a plethera of many, many other issues. The game has 6 different rollercoasters, and a handful of other rides that are mostly based on themes that you might not want in a generic park. This game is no where near release ready... but it's a prime subject for Early Access.

With a lot of games you know from the first few hours if a game has potential or not in Early Access, if it will ever get better or stay complete crap. I can say that RCTW is not the latter, this game has so much potential, it's just not there yet. As I stated above it has so many bugs and issues and lacks key mechanics like being able to tell janitors where they are alowed to go and where they should stay.

There's so many issues like how after getting off of a ride every single person on that ride will throw up. Also guests just pee everywhere, literally every where even outside of washrooms. You don't get enough feedback as to why somethign isn't working or why guests are unhappy or why they litter right beside a garbage can.

And yet, this game is just as addicting as the others. I do recomend this game but only if you go into it knowing that this is not ready, no where near ready. It fees like an alpha. If you know that, and you will not go into it expecting something like RCT3 level of completeness than I recomend this. Don't go into Early Access games expecting finished products, you than are an idiot and no sympathy is given to you.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've been a long time fan of the RCT franchise since RCT1. I was very excited about the RCTW project ever since I first heard the news that there was finally going to be a sequel. RCTW delivers everything you would expect in a modern RCT game. The greatest improvement of all is the absence of the grid. Everything in RCTW is placed and manipulated in a real time 3D environment. The Coaster Editor is the next biggest improvement. Gone are the days of piece-by-piece track building. In it's place, we have a powerful spline editor that makes creating coasters more advanced than ever before. It's entirely possible to build a track piece at any angle imaginable. And thirdly, we have an sphosticated UGC system in place to guarantee that players can create, share, and place virtually any kind of scenery object right into the game. I feel that my top needs have been met so far by RCTW and the project has a very hopeful future ahead. I'm very pleased to be a part of the experience and I'm excited to see this project carry on the legacy of my favorite theme park sim franchise.

reviewText:
I'm not sure where some of the reviewers are seeing that this game is due out in 40 days or 'a little over a month'.  The release date is 12/29/2015 which is almost TWO months prior to realease (from 10/31/2015).  Apologies to the prior reviewers as I did not see the first release date of 12/10/2015.

Is it ready?  No, but I think in TWO months it could be.  There are some definite issues in the current state.

Coaster building is very different from the prior RTC games.  I wouldn't say it's necessarily harder, just different.  It's just going to take some time to get used to it.  The camera / scrolling needs some work in that it isn't intuitive or user-friendly (for me).  I did not experience any lag.

There isn't much else to review at this point.  All-in-all I think the game looks like it could be great.  I think it would have been nice to know what the developer's intent was with this beta weekend...to test a particular aspect of the game or just give us a small taste of what the game has to offer?

While I'm in the minority for recommending the game, I do so with the caveat that we still have two months prior to release.  There is another beta weekend in December if I'm not mistaken and I feel that will be a better indicator of how we'll see the finished product.

reviewText:
PLEASE READ BEFORE READING REVIEW!!!
A beta is a beta. Don't expect everything they made by now is given to you on a dish.

The game looks incomplete, yes, does it look unfit to be released by 10 Dec? Maybe. There are a few things to consider here before you go and stab the devs in the kidney. The game is in beta and as we all know, most features are either locked or to be added at a later date. Big features were promised such as multiplayer, tunnels, various coaster types and flatrides, and other big features. If you payed attention to the Rollercoaster Tycoon blog Atari and NVizzio even stated that they want to ship the main game with the main concept by the end of the year and to release the big features through free content updates. Big features like multiplayer and tunnels (Cities Skylines devs made a good explanation for tunnels in general) are really time consuming things and require weeks or even months of extra coding and prepping for. They are stressed for time and if you remember the trailer earlier this year (Which was really bad) Atari came under fire by the community by how it looks. Plus the game was to be released by mid this year but was delayed. So do give them some sympathy for what situation they are currently in. Do take some time to read the the Rollercoaster Tycoon Blogs on their website. In fact they also stated on their blogs:  The RollerCoaster Tycoon World Beta is a technical demo focusing on our coaster building system and will show tycoons just a small taste of the sandbox experience and great parks you will be able to build when the game launches."  Source:  RCTW Blog #21[www.rollercoastertycoon.com] More proof to show that tons of the content in the game is locked.

Thank you for reading!

REVIEW
BETA WEEKEND 1

The game looks good so far

Editing the coaster was a bit buggy and especially on wooden coasters you couldn't make banked curves going down a slope so I assume that may be fixed by the next beta that is in November. Each train car on the coaster can be edited

reviewText:
I had the chance to play the week one Beta of RCT World.

And at this point, I do recommend the game. BUT of course it's no where near finished yet.
I don't know exactly how they're going to finish the game within 40 days but you have to know too, that we saw much more in the footage they've shown us.
This means:
The beta is reduced in functionality ON PURPOSE!
They stripped any options (you can't change resolution and stuff), there's no campaign yet, no goals, nothing.

All you can do yet is to start the sandbox mode and even the sandbox mode isn't fully implemented. Peeps look like ghosts, they have no skins. You can't build any houses like burger or drink shops.
You can build:
Scenery like trees, bushes, etc
Useful stuff like lamps, trash bins, banks, etc
Paths, rounded paths and queues (not rounded yet, I don't know why)
Of course, coasters.
You can build coasters of course. But you can only build some types of coasters (like 5 or so). I guess, they will add more to the finished game.
Most people think that the coaster editor is not good and too hard to use. I disagree. Even though I have to admit that it needs some time to get used to it, it's a VERY powerful tool to create coasters and with a little bit of training you can truly built your dream's rollercoaster. The spline based editor lets you create anything possible (within the physical possibilities, of course). From high curves to amazing loops. And you can set lifts, brakes, boosts and block brakes anywhere you want (even in a loop :P). That's amazing too.

The user interface looks not finished yet. It looks like an alpha but again: They've shown more in their footage.
From what I have seen now, I'm still impressed. Yes, there is not much to do yet. And yes, it looks not finished yet and it also doesn't look like they're going to finish the game within time.
But there is still a second beta weekend to come. And I expect that they will add far more functionality to the game then which is basically ready but just not enabled yet.

They want us to test the coaster editor mainly. To give feedback on how it works and how it feels. They will reduce complexity on controls a bit because people are complaining. I don't understand most of them, but well, that's how things work.

There are some cons though:
Camera movement feels weird, especially when building coasters. It makes it harder to place your tracks because when you zoom in to check what direction your coaster is going, the coaster moves away from the point you've pointed at previously. Please fix that.
There are some bugs (of course, it's a beta) like occasionally the 1st person view is not working. Or sometimes the coaster crash without any obvious reason. I don't know if there was just too much G-force on them or the track was bugged, but I would appreciate feedback on where and how and why the coaster has crashed. And maybe a G-force graph too.
There are some graphical glitches sometimes. When you startup the game it seems to be buggy (have a look at my uploaded screenshots)
Performance is not good at all. I have a GTX 670 running but my FPS are somewhere between 20 and 45 (max 60). The game looks fine, but it doesn't look THAT fine that it could explain that low fps. I hope that they will improve performance.
Well, that's all I can think of for now. I will add more if I find more to say.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Re-written for Early Access) - (Will rewrite once again as major changes are introduced)
*Day 1 patch edit*
Well, it's been 5 months, and there's content. Now we get to have a massive flood of User Generated Content thrown at it via the workshop. My experience with the workshop implementation has been pleasing. I'm happy with the 'social hub' button.

Nvizzio definitely listened to the complaints from October. Every complaint of my has been eliminated.

It's very clear that the game was nowhere near ready for full release... but it's leaps and bounds more solid than the engine preview was. The coaster builder now has classic building style as well as the freeform method... and it's seamless; you can, say, build the lift chain using the classic style, and then put in the first drop using freeform, and then finish it off with classic. Fantastic work.

I was able to get my first coaster with excellent ratings knocked out in under 20min... something that took me nearly 4 hours to do during the engine preview weekend. This is a massive improvement. I do kinda miss the live intensity preview on the track building - instead, I have to guess if it's going to work, go with it, finish the track, test it, and tweak it to perfection.

The prebuild blueprints of coasters need to be looked at by the devs, as they end up testing as complete garbage on many of them - my guess is that they were designed with the older system that they had.

Achievements... *fixed. Enjoy!

Camera control is finally able to be completely bound to the mouse, which is a giant relief - that was one of my chief complaints in the preview. In minutes I was able to master the control and look at things exactly how I wanted, instead of fighting it the whole time.

Bugs happen - it's in early access. Textures go funky, AI goes stupid, and things can get weird. I've seen full released games with more issues than this, but the RCT legacy deserves nothing less than perfect; and it's up to the fans to help Nvizzio and Atari make that happen.

Play the game, and tell them when something goes wrong, or right, or weird... just don't expect them to pull up a Ouiji board to guess what is happening to everyone... because sometimes it takes the stars to align to highlight a problem - and that's where crowdsourced testing (Early Access) plays the biggest benefit. We all win when you share your grievances and pleasures.

The day 1 patch has improved upon many of the bugs. Lots of new content was added, as well. This shows much potential for the future of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are a fan of the RollerCoaster Tycoon games then you need to buy this.  I have to be honest and say that there are definitely issues, BUT it is still good.  There are some issues with the graphics being a little rough around the edges and the staff need more options.  It is good to play another coaster game and the new coaster design is pretty good.

It is early access and I wish it wasn't, but that means that I don't have to settle with what I have.  I can make recommendations and expect them to be applied to the game.

***I am editing this to be more speific about the errors so they can be fixed!***

- The Janitors need help.  I have 16 of them and they get confused and much of my park remains filthy.  There use to be an option to drag and drop them and also to designate a certain area for them to focus cleaning.  That needs to come back.  I believe thats an absolute necessity.

- The benches are confusing.  When I first put them down only a couple of people used them ( I have many benches).  Not only that but the guests were walking through the benches.  So, I moved them to the grass.  No one walked through them anymore, but the benches aren't even being used now.

- The mechanics are as bad as the janitors.  I have 13 of them and they wonder about without a clue as to what they need to do ( most of the time).  I will have a ride break down and stay that way for ingame days before someone fixes it.  That makes no sense, because I have more mechanics than I do rides and plenty of paths for them to easily access the broken ride.

-  Some of the outlines on the guests are wonky.  You know, when you click on them and get close enough you can see the white outline?  Yeah, some of those are just not right.

- I am not sure the info kiosk updates when new stuff is built.  I have people wondering around lost.

- Why are my people angry about the souvenir stalls? They say it will have to do...Is this because it doesn't target their age-group?  Is it the prices?  Is it the color or theme?  Speaking of color and theme; these should be changeable via the actual building or, at least, the color.  All my hats are blue!!!  That is not okay.

- Placement of buildings frustrates me to no end.  Why can't I snap them to pathways?  Why must I pull them back from the path and make another path to them?  To me, that is not okay.

- There definitely needs to be a better bulldozer tool for mass-destruction.

- There also needs to be subways and such. Also water rides.  My guests want, nay, need a log flume.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

D I E  H A R D  F A N  H E R E.

I have been waiting for RCTW to release and finally get my hands on. To be honest I had struggles if I should give the game ago- I have read negative reviews different platforms and I was worried it would be a disaster; now I have tried the game and I have the following honest feedbacks:

I started the series since RCT1, enjoyed RCT2 and loved RCT3.

I do honestly hoped that RTCW, 10 years after the release of RCT3 would have been sculpted and upgarded much and have noticed the followings:

PEEPS.
peeps look terrible in RCTW. I would zoom in RCT3 and just look at happy peeps buying balloons/popping their balloons etc but now I just want to zoom out because they look like zombies. In my opinion, they need more life.

ROADS.
honestly think its a nice touch for the shift/scroll to lower/elevate ramps, it was a pain in the ♥♥♥♥ to calculate how much angle the ramp for older version. I think this gesture worked. Nice touch for adjusting road widths/ but it is difficult to connect wide roads to attractions/facilities or back to a single sized road.

COASTER BUILDER.
ok. I have read lots of bad reviews for the coaster builder. After I tried it out myself, I think it is not as bad. The control might NOT be for beginners/new RCT players, but if you were an EXPERIENCED RCT player, I do think the mechanical tool option helped A LOT, esp. to add chained/brakes tracks in a clear manner. I think the tool box is quite neat to me, but I do understand it may cause beginners a lot of confusion.

WORKERS. (JANITORS/TECHNICIANS)
very nice touch. to just add a hub and let them manage themselves. I dont care if they slack tbh. I just dont care.

RESTAURANTS.
interesting blend of food and specialities restaurants- but I think the designs are a bit lazy for different themes, and I hope they could be attached to paths at a closer distance. (and i do secretly enjoy the fact that you can manage the amount of sauce/salt/edit the menu in RCT3)

Shift+mouse scroll to rotate: i prefer a 90degress rotation in default than the default scroll-till-you-get-the-perfect-angle mode. saves my time. and some players (me) still prefer doing plannings on grid.

Snap tool is a bit off - somtimes I misplaced benches outside the path and I dont like it.

better to add a drop down menu- to filter themes. showing 4 burger shops in a row with different themes is not kool.

TERRIN TOOLS.
brilliant.

ATTRACTIONS.
I MISS THE SWAN BOATS AND METRO TRAINS TO TOUR AROUND PARK.

STATISTICS.
very clear way of presenting, loan is reasonable.

SPECIAL LOTS.
I appreciate the plaza blocks that are saved as pre-made blueprinted, saved me a lot of time and they are done beautifully.

I MISS THE OPTION TO RE- PLACE ENTRANCE/EXITS. sometimes the location is just not right.

CONCLUSION.
I think. for 10 years, the game does not evolve as much as I expected it to be (thinking about from RCT2 to RCT3 guys.... the sudden leap from axonometric cubes to first person camera view on rides. thats innovation.) except from the fact that you can change the graphics settings to very high level of detail" and "very far detailed shadow". This is not a rendering software
date: and high level of renders always make the game slow/crash. I would appreciate if more effort is put into details (design of rides) and new gameplay experience (like soak and wild for RCT3). It also remided me how great RCT3 is... especially at that time.\n\nI have a neutral feeling for this game
recommended: I remained nostalgic about the old days I spent managing my park
hoursPlayed: so YES I recommend for long-term RCT players
voteText: but maybe a NO for beginners."

reviewText:
NOTICE: this review is lengthy, if tldr, check pros/cons

In short, there seems to be a lot to look forward too for RCTW, however there are many tweaks that need to be made. That said, from what I see from forums, this game will not be as popular as the original trilogy because the coaster designer is much more complex to use than in previous itterations.

There are only 7 or 8 different coaster types currently present in RCTW and many classics from the second and even first games are missing. My guess is that additional coaster types will be offered via paid DLC, the thought leaves a bad taste in my mouth, but I can't think of another reason why certain 'cornerstone' rollercoasters such as corkscrew coasters aren't available already.

The 'innovative' Spline based coaster designer is an interesting take on coaster design, it works well if you plan on building a coaster without any inversions. However, as soon as you plan on including corkscrews, loops or any other inversion. You will almost instantly get frustrated. I found it extremely difficult to create straight lines of coaster track, perhaps because the track is always attached to your cursor before you place it, and while trying to move around simultaneously, the track quickly becomes twisted and messed up. There is a premade loop that can be used, however it does not look realistic and is way too steep. The other premade track piece is a 'vertical corkscrew'. Were the developers smoking crack when they came up with that one?

One of the only things that made me actually feel like I was playing a RollerCoaster Tycoon series game was when it came to choosing the colour design of the coaster. Perhaps this is because they did little to no innovation in this area, as none was needed.

I designed a hypercoaster in RCTW that seemed fairly successful in design, but the test statistics showed that the ride was hardly 'fun' at all. I know for certain that this coaster would've had atleast 5 excitement if I had made it with any of the original games.
It was impossible for me to judge the physics engine this game has because it was impossible to have the coaster running while maintaining a decent framerate. This, despite my computer exceeding the system requirements of the game.

There is no Options menu and there is no way to change the resolution, change graphics settings or even any audio settings. I yearn for the ability to mute the annoying music that comes on if you scroll out far enough. As well, the sounds that I am assuming come from the rollercoaster stations are really obnoxious and need to be changed. However this may work itself out as more features and other sounds are added.

Controlling the game is a bit of hit and miss, You move around the map with the arrow keys or WASD, I was unable to move around by dragging my cursor to the edge of the screen, something I think is critical for this kind of game.

There are a large variety of paths in the game and the system seems to be fairly fleshed out and competent.

All in all, if the developers manage a way to include a simplified coaster designer, in the vein of the coaster designer from the original games, I feel this game will see massive success. Aesthetically pleasing and once fully optimized, I will give this game another shot.

Pros
+decent graphics
+complex coaster designer
+painting coaster track
+fleshed out path system

Cons
-annoying sound design
-complex coaster designer
-limited amount of coaster types
-vertical corkscrew will haunt my dreams
-no corkscrew/arrow dynamics coasters
-coaster statistics function completely different
-poor optimization
-no options menu (albeit this is beta, would be nice to mute audio)
-moving around is awkward

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wouldn't recommend this for anyone who is expecting a perfect game. Rollercoaster Tycoon World is far from perfect, and it certainly isn't ready for anybody who isn't willing to deal with bugs. This game has them. Some are game-breaking (like, I can't launch scenarios without my game crashing entirely, in one case requiring a complete reboot of my ROG laptop) and some aren't (my favorite thus far are the horrible animations on the giant slide - I laughed at that for far too long). However, I feel the game is fun, and it has a lot of potential.

Some people are also experiencing issues with RAM leaks; I am one that can say that I haven't had that issue on any of the devices that I have played RCTW on. All were laptops with good graphics cards, a quad-core proc, and 16GB of RAM. I can also say that I haven't run into anything particularly problematic yet, except the scenario-issue I mentioned earlier.

And for those complaining about graphics: there's a setting that you have to disable. When we got Beta weekend 1, everyone was locked to the highest graphics possible, without any FPS prioritization. The game now adjusts automatically for the specs that it thinks the computer can handle. However, it also has an FPS prioritization setting. That  needs to be disabled to get the full quality of the game. Thankfully, my laptop (970 Geforce GTX) can handle that. Not everyone can.

If you don't have the minimum specs, the game won't run well. Period.
If you don't have the recommended specs, it will run better than not meeting minimum, but you still want recommended. The game is demanding, even with some optimizing.

For those that don't meet recommended - wait for further optimization unless you are patient.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are a lot of negative reviews, and some of them I will somewhat agree on, the coaster designer is finnicky and certainly takes time to get the hang of, so far despite my computers issues with crashing like it has been lately, I am personally loving it, yes it indeed does have a good bit of work left but if you are a fanboy of the series like myself, I think you may love it, I myself do. Again, finnicky and tough to get the hang of, but it's a lot of fun! It's really a hit or miss in the long run, if you like Rollercoaster Tycoon, give it a whirl if you want, but if you don't, then don't bother with it honestly because there's nothing here for you unless you are a fan of the series as I am myself since day one. All in all, to my personal preference, I am loving it so far, and I think it may have a bright future with how the devs are handling there blogs lately, perhaps a good direction towards a wonderful position for the game. It's a blast! But most definitely buy at your own risk, not for everybody but if you love Rollercoaster Tycoon like myself, give it a go guys!

EDIT: After banking a few more hours up, I maxed the settings and I will agree with some of the reviews, the graphics are just barely better than RCT3 in some situations, but the performance wasn't impaced all that much for me even with my ancient components, being an old Core2 Q9400, two 560's, and an nForce 790i FTW mobo, it did lag in some places but overall it did quite well, which kind of surprised be with the system requirements it lists. Overall however, if they updated the graphics, added more coasters and rides, and tweaked the optomiization for a little smoother flow it'll be perfect for me personally.   All in all, still I will say, buy at your own risk, if you love the series as I do, you'll love it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BUILD IT AND THEY WILL COME!

With early access, it's time to pull up sleeves and get to work to build the ultimate park. Well, maybe not just today.

Of course, many features are currently not available, as I'm looking foward to learn new game's basics, while the engineers are sitting and drinking coffee. Now to buisness...

General interface(IU), main or in-game menu are very good, simple to use and understand. Camera control is overall very good, but for when building coaster, it moves a bit too much automatically(even with option off). Graphics are very good but will need a little work on shadow and a few textures(nothing dramatic). Environment is great to play in and main backdrops are nice, even if the camera don't allow too much ''out-of-park'' pullback. Land modifications is simple, low cost, working fine, but need scenery auto-removal Scenery is somewhat limited but nice, and hoping for the community to pick on this, with more themes to come soon.

Items controls and locations placement, including in height are easy to use and usually correct on position. Moving tool is very good, very usefull. Most other tools are nice and easy, like grid and snap options. Path building and path objects are still a bid tricky with placement limits(maybe my rides are too close to path, blocking scenery placement).

Flat rides count is OK for this early version, with a good choice of coasters, shops and other management building. Many options for buildings and rides management are missing. Zoning for personnel is missing. Pay grade and training for personnel is missing.

Coaster design control is simply amazing, allowing you to build practically what you want, with some limits to tracks placement not allowing volontary errors to correct afterward. Piece-by-piece placement is still actual, and was hoping for it(got it!). Node control is stunning and very easy to use, splines based coaster are just the best. On board camera could be a little smoother. Coasters details are very good, but missing color choice for cars and stations. Stations control are still limited and need some improvement, but overall good. Coaster building NEEDS a auto-removal for scenary(trees and bushes) and a ground grid snapping feature.

Economy is quite simple, but will require lots of tweaking, I get many stores and restaurants that don't get many visit, even if the demand is high and place in the right location. Love the end day pay, instead of continual flow. Budget is easy to read and quite detailed. Missing lots of features for merchendinsing and sales choice control in stalls, and other venues. Missing side incomes(like on ride photo sections). Missing tech tree and research.

Peeps and personnal will need some work for behaviors, skin textures, control and options(like zoning and pay). I miss the candy side of previous opus for peeps. No choice for entertainers costumes is not fun. Mainly, the people's toughts are accurates and will spend based on need and want. Groups and family are missing babdly. Here again, nothing dramatic, and nothing from stopping me to build.

Many other features are in planning and will be greatly welcome, like transport rides. RCT3 was simply alone in it's category, and well filled with custom objects, which will come in time for RCTW. Also, they will want to put sequels, like water rides and animals out to make a few more sure bucks out of us in the future, which I agree too, but WILL NOT PAY for micro download(DLC). MISSING IN-GAME RECORDER(A ABSOLUTE MUST).

Overall, after years of patience and waiting, I give it a 8,2/10 score compared to RCT3(10/10), since it's early, it's very good, and will improove greatly. The game foundation is very strong. Community, Tycoons as well as wannabe Tycoons will rally behind this title and it's going to become a classic as well as a cash mountain for Atari. GREAT GAME. This tittle is good for all ages. Thank you Atari, but not for the waiting years.

***Line start here***
***Waiting time at this point: 5 years***
***Keep head and arms inside the vehicule at all time***
***Kindly remain seated untill complete stop.***

Abbittibbi

I wouldn't recommend this for anyone who is expecting a perfect game. Rollercoaster Tycoon World is far from perfect, and it certainly isn't ready for anybody who isn't willing to deal with bugs. This game has them. Some are game-breaking (like, I can't launch scenarios without my game crashing entirely, in one case requiring a complete reboot of my ROG laptop) and some aren't (my favorite thus far are the horrible animations on the giant slide - I laughed at that for far too long). However, I feel the game is fun, and it has a lot of potential.

Some people are also experiencing issues with RAM leaks; I am one that can say that I haven't had that issue on any of the devices that I have played RCTW on. All were laptops with good graphics cards, a quad-core proc, and 16GB of RAM. I can also say that I haven't run into anything particularly problematic yet, except the scenario-issue I mentioned earlier.

And for those complaining about graphics: there's a setting that you have to disable. When we got Beta weekend 1, everyone was locked to the highest graphics possible, without any FPS prioritization. The game now adjusts automatically for the specs that it thinks the computer can handle. However, it also has an FPS prioritization setting. That  needs to be disabled to get the full quality of the game. Thankfully, my laptop (970 Geforce GTX) can handle that. Not everyone can.

If you don't have the minimum specs, the game won't run well. Period.
If you don't have the recommended specs, it will run better than not meeting minimum, but you still want recommended. The game is demanding, even with some optimizing.

For those that don't meet recommended - wait for further optimization unless you are patient.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I just want to say to people stop constantly critisicing RCTW. I think criticism is fine but not at a level where Atari have to remove posts off their social media accounts because of it!
This game isn't perfect but it is good for all the devlopment hell it got. It's fun to play and never really boring when you start.I think to many people all ways forget about this game because of frontiers spiritual successor to rct3 planet coaster which is in its alpha.When the beta came out I thought it was good but needed vast improvements. This is also sort of how I feel about the early access version but some improvements have been added.

Pros
Good and powerful coaster editor that is spline based.
Piece by piece system for casual players.
Great UGC and tools overall.
Realistic graphics and good looking shadows.
Can hit 60fps.

Cons.
Not that great for making dark rides.
Spline based Coaster editor can feel a bit finicky at times
Lack of custom music and themes in game not on the workshop.
bugs
The UI is a bit bland.

So overall RCTW is a good game. It's not perfect but I will stick by it until it comes out.. unless they abandon it, like astroids outpost!

7\10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game was released nice and early and naturally that is because they need the support from fans to improve it.  I would like to point out some issues as of today that I know people are curious about considering all the upset reviews.  I have always loved these titles. So, I noticed reading comments that alot of people are upset with how the staff you place in your park are not great. From playing I see what they mean, but! They do get it done, although it takes time... I never really saw negative effects to my parks score. Or gotten notifications that the park was to messy. I had alot of complaints about there not being enough room as in pathways and things of that nature still no real effect on my overall score but I am sure that is something that can be fixed by simply making the park larger. And I look forward to figuring that out.  I took a picture of my park to display my overall score and all the annoying notifications everyones speaking of but I dont think i can post that here, but it shows my score is great although pesky notifications are there regarding the park staff being to low and stuff. As far as Roller coaster designing goes I am absolutely impressed!!!! The amount of control we have now when creating coasters is amazing absolutely great job done there. I have come to notice that getting the coasters just right takes some trial and error.  So far each coaster I have made is leading to puking guests. But they still ride it somehow lol. They give you pre-built track peices but you by no means have to use them. You can design whatever you want by simply editing a node this allows you to twist and turn or add speed boosters or breaks to tracks and it is very easy to use. I have not figured out if you can go underground with them yet that was always a favorite of mine. And yes there are pre-built tracks if you prefer that.
